webTitle: Four Palestinians die in revenge attacks

fields.headline: Four Palestinians die in revenge attacks
fields.trailText: Gunfire and apparent revenge attacks late Sunday and early Monday in the West Bank and Gaza Strip left four Palestinians dead, including a 10-year-old boy.
fields.body:
Gunfire and apparent revenge attacks late Sunday and early Monday in the West Bank and Gaza Strip left four Palestinians dead, including a 10-year-old boy.

The deaths included those of two Palestinian policemen killed late on Sunday on the outskirts of the West Bank town of Tulkarem, the same town were a senior activist in Yasser Arafat's Fatah movement was killed earlier in the day.

The Israeli army said the two Palestinian policemen were slain in a gun battle with Israeli forces. But Palestinian hospital officials said bones in their hands had been crushed, suggesting they may have been beaten, and that both were shot by large-caliber bullets.

The 10-year-old boy, Muad Abu Adwan, died of wounds suffered on Sunday in crossfire in the West Bank town of Hebron. A 22-year-old Palestinian man also died after being shot in the head when Jewish settlers fired on a crowd in his West Bank village, witnesses said.

The latest deaths bring to 356 the number of people killed in a 3-month-old outbreak of violence, most of them Palestinians.

Jewish settlers, angry over the ambush shooting that killed a prominent Israeli settler and his wife on Sunday, blocked the entrances of several Palestinian towns in the West Bank on Monday, vowing to "take back the roads."

Palestinians, meanwhile, held marches and demonstrations throughout the West Bank and Gaza in a show of support for the 36th anniversary of the Fatah movement. Mr Arafat founded the movement in exile, and it quickly became the dominant force in the Palestine Liberation Organization. Grassroots leaders of Fatah and other Palestinian groups have been pressing Mr Arafat to turn down US-offered peace proposals.

A Palestinian source said that Mr Arafat was expecting a call from President Bill Clinton to outline the latest peace plan. In the meantime, Mr Arafat said the Palestinians would continue resisting what he called Israeli aggression.

"I say that our people are very strong and will continue their struggles and confrontations," he said.

Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak said that if a peace deal could not be reached with the Palestinians, Israel could pursue a plan of unilateral separation, which would include setting boundaries between the two sides.

"We must part from the Palestinians. It is one of our highest priorities to do so in an agreement, but we will have to prepare to do so without an agreement if it becomes clear that the Palestinians are not interested in an agreement," he said.

webTitle: Pope attacks 'culture of death' in west

fields.headline: Pope attacks 'culture of death' in west
fields.trailText: The Pope will today mark a crowning moment of his papacy with a new year's day message condemning western lifestyles as cultural wastelands.
fields.body:
The Pope will today mark a crowning moment of his papacy with a new year's day message condemning western lifestyles as cultural wastelands.

The west's communication industries risk spreading human, spiritual and moral impoverishment to other civilisations, he will say. Advanced science and technology made an "enticing and alluring" model which the rest of the world was following with a "slavish conformity".

In a world peace day message which aides feared he would not live to make, he will accuse the west of making a fatal attempt to secure humanity's welfare by eliminating God.

"A culture that no longer has a point of reference in God loses its soul and loses its way, becoming a culture of death," he will say. "Detached from their Christian origins, these models are often inspired by an approach to life marked by secularism and practical atheism and by patterns of radical individualism."

The 24-page document, entitled Dialogue Between Cultures for a Civilisation of Love and Peace, was sent to world leaders two weeks ago.

It confirms that the Pope, 80, sees materialism as the great enemy now that communism is vanquished. He is appalled that eastern Europe, particularly his homeland, Poland, is apeing the west rather than acting as a spiritual beacon. He will say that some of the poorest nations "have reached a point of irreversible decline". Because of a growing inequality of resources.

In a veiled swipe at Tony Blair and other leaders who have backed plans to clone human embryo cells for medical research, he will condemn "irresponsible" practices of genetic engineering. "A civilisation based on love and peace must oppose these experiments, which are unworthy of man."

Abortion, euthanasia, torture, mutilation, racism, xenophobia and trafficking in women and children are also condemned.

Calling on young people to become "craftsmen of a new humanity", the Pope will urge tolerance for ethnic minorities and immigrants. No magic formulas exist to deal with the growing numbers crossing frontiers, he says, so basic ethical principles must ensure every immigrant is accorded human dignity.

The message comes at the end of a successful Vatican jubilee, or holy year, which drew almost 25m pilgrims to Rome. From a window overlooking St. Peter's Square at midnight last night, John Paul was also scheduled to give his traditional New Year's Eve greeting to crowds below.

Though stooped and in pain, his voice slurred from Parkinson's disease, the Pope has kept up a gruelling schedule.

Convinced since his election in 1978 that he was chosen to lead the church into Christianity's third millennium, the year 2000 is said to have fed John Paul's will to keep going. Speculation that he might retire after next Saturday, when the holy door of St Peter's basilica will be bricked up until the next jubilee, has faded. Only one previous pope has stepped aside: in 1294, Pietro del Murrone, a monk who had never wanted the job, abdicated after five months.

Papal trips to Ukraine and Syria are planned later this year and in late February John Paul is expected to hold a consistory to appoint around 20 new cardinals, including the Archbishop of Westminster, Dr Cormac Murphy-O'Connor. Given the lack of clear frontrunners it is quite possible that the next Pope will be among the newly elevated bishops and archbishops.

The number of cardinals eligible to vote has slipped below 100 so the new appointees could transform the balance between liberals and conservatives in the Vatican. Jubilee commitments forced the suspension of regular meetings with bishops from around the world and the Pope is said to be keen to resume updates.

Another priority is to heal divisions within Christianity but Alexei II, the patriarch of the Russian Orthodox church, is blocking the visit to Russia that the Pope yearns for.

webTitle: US papers reveal rift with allies on drugs

fields.headline: US papers reveal rift with allies on drugs
fields.trailText: American diplomats privately accused world leaders of being "tepid" in their support for the so-called war against drugs, according to a US presidential briefing paper obtained by the Guardian.
fields.body:
American diplomats privately accused world leaders of being "tepid" in their support for the so-called war against drugs, according to a US presidential briefing paper obtained by the Guardian.

The internal document reveals how Washington sought to rally leading governments behind an audacious UN plan to halt drug abuse.

The long-running US-led "war against drugs" has often been criticised by sceptical governments and other critics as a mission doomed to fail and a waste of money.

The briefing paper was written by American diplomats in the run-up to a landmark UN summit which adopted a huge, two-pronged plan - to eradicate the production of illegal drugs in the world by 2008 and to cut down significantly the number of people who wanted to take drugs by 2003.

A key stepping stone towards that summit in June 1998 was another summit - this time of the G8 leaders - which was held in Britain three weeks beforehand.

In a briefing paper to aides of the US president, Bill Clinton, state department officials wrote that the crucial US goal was to "send a strong message that the G8 will continue a vigorous fight against international production, trafficking and abuse of illicit drugs".

The US was keen to secure international backing for the wide-ranging plans of Pino Arlacchi, who had been recently appointed executive director of the UN drug control programme (UNDCP). Mr Arlacchi, who had previously helped to fight the Mafia in Italy, was seen to have shaken up the organisation.

He was committed to an approach that moved beyond the usual methods of merely catching drug smugglers.

But the state department officials noted in their paper that "other G8 governments have given only tepid and circumscribed support to the UNDCP".

They added: "We understand other governments' cautious reaction to Pino Arlacchi's ambitious plan for a global attack on illicit drug cultivations, especially coca and opium poppy."

"We all know, as does Mr Arlacchi, that the cost of such a programme must be carefully considered. The obstacles to eliminating drugs cultivations are daunting in Afghanistan and Burma, for example."

These two countries are responsible for growing the vast majority of the opium used to produce heroin. Mr Arlacchi wanted to step up the destruction of the illicit drug plantations, but this could only be done with the compliance of the two governments.

Officials were aware there would be political opposition to the idea of giving money to the Taliban in Afghanistan and the dictatorship in Burma.

"Nevertheless the UNDCP's ambitious plan for a global approach to target drug crops is on the right track; it builds on our combined experience with alternative development, eradication, and enforcement; it targets all major cultivations simultaneously so that production does not simply shift from one country to another," wrote the American officials.

The internal paper was released to the Guardian under the US freedom of information act. It also gives an insight into the high-level politicking which goes into the drafting of communiques issued at international summits.

The Americans were unhappy with the wording of the proposed communique to be released after the G8 summit in Birmingham. They were worried that the draft wording was not strong enough in its championing of the UN plans and suggested new sentences. It appears their attempt was partially successful.

webTitle: Wheels: The Honda Civic

fields.headline: Civic pride and prejudice
fields.standfirst: For years hatchbacks have been upstaged by trendy MPVs, but the pert little Honda Civic could change that, says  Giles Smith
fields.trailText: For years hatchbacks have been upstaged by trendy MPVs, but the pert little Honda Civic could change that, says Giles Smith.
fields.body:
This would be nobody's idea of a golden age for the hatchback. Where once Golfs proudly roamed the land looking very young and pleased with themselves, the fun now seems to be elsewhere and the Golf has come to seem, certainly in its new form, a little clumpy and outstripped, just one of the cluster of impersonal, interchangeable and deeply unexciting blobs which characterise the hatchback sector.

Elsewhere, people who might once have gone for a hatchback are excitedly bombing about in newly affordable combat vehicles and miniature people carriers which, despite miniaturisation, still have enough room for the children in the back to watch movies, play five-a-side football and have friends over to stay. Meanwhile, all the poor old hatchback can do is hunker down and try to sound enthusiastic while saying: "Look, if you put the rear seats down, you can get four sacks of garden rubbish inside me." Fashion can be cruel like that.

Periodically, though, a hatchback noses its way to the front of this uneasy and quietly lowing herd and makes a claim to be thought dynamic. The Ford Focus was one example and the new Honda Civic is another. It is a stern corrective for anyone who still thinks anything made by Honda should, by rights, be a motorbike.

It is less flashy than the Focus (which, for all its brilliance, does still smack slightly of a design seminar staffed by men with ponytails) and more appealing in many other respects. Things that tend now to feel like a drag about hatchbacks in general somehow appear to be pert virtues in the Civic.

It seems modest rather than merely anodyne, crisply practical rather than merely boring. It is too much, perhaps, to expect it single-handedly to turn the tide against its heartily established, non-hatchback rivals. At the same time, you look at the Civic and wonder anew what the fuss is, really, about MPVs and Jeep-alikes. And it has a cute bonnet too.

It is unusually roomy, despite taking up little space on the road. Dr Who would be impressed. You can sit in the back without having your knees plugged into your ears; and you can get out of the back without assistance from other people and winches. The result of this emphasis is that there is less boot-space than you might get from other hatchbacks. But this simply means that Honda is placing the needs of humans above sacks of garden rubbish, which cannot be an entirely bad thing.

Honda refers to the Civic's "walk-through interior", which, in the context, is ambitious. I would like to see someone try it. The point is, though, that movement around the car is entirely unhampered by lumps in the floor. It's the world's first open-plan hatchback.

Even the gear stick is removed to the dashboard, in the manner of ancient Citroëns, making it altogether easier to climb on top of the passenger next to you, should you need to for any reason. I think we can safely say that, in the matter of space distribution, Honda has thought of everything here.

The gear fob looks a little comical up there on the dash; something like the control from a long since outmoted arcade video game. But, though it feels peculiar to be fiddling about regularly on the dashboard with something which isn't the controls for the radio, I grew to love it and particularly the short distance it affords between gears, which are, highly satisfyingly, just a click apart and which made the sensation of driving the car actually quite sporty.

You can sling the car about a bit, too, without enduring muscular-skeletal damage. According to the Honda literature, "ride comfort has been improved by reducing the spring rates of the front and rear compliance bushings". I think we can all be grateful to them for that, even those of us who don't know our rear compliance bushing from our elbow.

The problem with most hatchbacks driven at speed is the noise. It is like perching inside an air-extraction unit; you emerge afterwards feeling deafened and stupid. Surely only someone with a relaxed attitude to the future of their hearing would wish to engage in an extended bout of high-speed overtaking in a hatchback.

But even here Honda comes good. No one would suggest that the Civic offers whisper-quiet motoring in the manner of a Rolls-Royce, but at the same time it did, in motorway conditions, sound less like a hand-held vacuum cleaner than other cars of its shape and size.

The Civic comes with the usual slew of toys which, until relatively recently, would only have appeared in heavyweight saloons but which now appear everywhere as a matter of course - electric windows, heated mirrors, air conditioning units, hot and cold-running CD players, etc. Extras are the new standards. Soon, in order to distinguish themselves from each other, cars will have to start giving away extraneous white goods: dishwashers, fridge-freezers and so forth.

In addition, because this is its first month on sale, the Civic is currently available at challenging launch prices. But it is not the kind of car that needs toys and discounts to speak for it. It can stand on its own.

The lowdown

Honda Civic 1.4 S
Price: from £11,991
Top speed: 108 mph
Acceleration: 0-62 in 12.1 seconds
Consumption: 44.1 mpg combined
At the wheel: Charlie Dimmock
On the stereo: Kiss FM
En route for: the dump

Surely only someone with a relaxed attitude to the future of their hearing would wish to engage in an extended bout of high-speed overtaking in a hatchback. But even here Honda comes good. No one would suggest that the Civic offers whisper-quiet motoring in the manner of a Rolls-Royce, but at the same time it did, in motorway conditions, sound less like a hand-held vacuum cleaner than other cars of its shape and size. The Civic comes with the usual slew of toys which, until relatively recently, would only have appeared in heavyweight saloons but which now appear everywhere as a matter of course - electric windows, heated mirrors, air conditioning units, hot and cold-running CD players, etc. Extras are the new standards. Soon, in order to distinguish themselves from each other, cars will have to start giving away extraneous white goods: dishwashers, fridge-freezers and so forth. In addition, because this is its first month on sale, the Civic is currently available at challenging launch prices. But it is not the kind of car that needs toys and discounts to speak for it. It can stand on its own. webTitle: Now it's the Jerusalem marching season

fields.headline: Now it's the Jerusalem marching season
fields.standfirst: The intensifying crisis in the Middle East could finally lead the Palestinians and Israelis to make the concessions needed for peace, says Derek Brown
fields.trailText: The intensifying crisis in the Middle East could finally lead the Palestinians and Israelis to make the concessions needed for peace, says Derek Brown
fields.body:
This New Year's Day sees Israel and the Palestinians standing on the very brink of final disaster. It has been brewing for months but nothing, not even the midst of the recent bloodletting, has matched the new sense of raw anger and foreboding.

At the heart of the crisis is the malignancy which has infected the region ever since Israel captured the West Bank and the Gaza Strip in 1967: the systematic colonisation of the occupied territories by militant Jewish settlers.

Close on 200,000 have staked out claims on Palestinian land, builting garish hilltop townships and lording it over the local population.

The settler movement has been encouraged by rightwing Israeli governments and tolerated by leftwing ones. Subsidised by wealthy overseas Zionists and urged on by militant nationalists, both religious and secular, the process of colonial expansion has been relentless - and frequently violent.

The inchoate rage of the Palestinians since the establishment of the Jewish state in 1948 has found, since 1967, a focus for anger in the successive waves of settlement spreading across their ancestral lands.

Now, as the latest intifada, (uprising) intensifies, it is the conflict between the Palestinians and the settlers, the colonised and the colonisers, which is at the heart of the ancient confrontation.

On New Year's Eve, militant settler Binhamin Kahane and his wife Talia were ambushed and killed in their car. Their five daughters were wounded.

It is not known whether the couple was specifically targeted, nor is it known whether Thabet Thabet, a prominent local leader of Yasser Arafat's Fatah movement, was deliberately gunned down in retaliation for Kahane murders. But assassinated he was, by Israeli security forces, barely three hours after the Kahanes died.

Overnight four more Palestinians were killed, including a 10-year-old boy and two policemen.

The overall intifada death toll now stands at 356, of whom 40 were Israeli security forces or civilians. But the statistics are irrelevant: in the new phase of confrontation what matters is blind, passionate hatred.

Militant settlers are marching on Jerusalem today to demand greater security - which for many of them means expelling the Palestinians from their native land. Fatah officials are talking of mounting their own march on Jerusalem to take it back from the Israelis.

Neither demonstration carries much military significance, for the Israeli army will simply brush aside either if it becomes dangerous. But both marches embody the rising mood of almost hysterical fear and loathing in both communities.

Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak has today repeated his dire warning to the Palestinians that they will suffer if the peace process finally break down.

Most onlookers would be forgiven for believing the process is already dead and buried.

There is a school of thought, however, that the Israeli and Palestinian leaderships will only be forced into making the concessions which are self-evidently vital if there is ever to be a lasting peace, by a truly gigantic crisis.

That crisis could now be upon us.

webTitle: Schoolgirls' bodies found in icy lake

fields.headline: Schoolgirls' bodies found in icy lake
fields.trailText: Police searching a lake for two schoolgirls who vanished during a skating trip today recovered two bodies from the icy waters.
fields.body:
Police searching a lake for two schoolgirls who vanished during a skating trip today recovered two bodies from the icy waters.

The cousins, aged 12 and 10, from Bellanode, County Monaghan in the Irish Republic, disappeared after skating on Hollywood Lake yesterday afternoon.

A coastguard helicopter with heat-seeking equipment today joined the resumed search of the area around Hollywood Lake, near Scotstown.

"The two girls went ice skating on the lake on Saturday and had a wonderful time," a police spokesman said.

"We believe they may have gone skating again on Sunday and that, with the big thaw, they may have fallen through the ice."

Relatives of the girls visited the scene of the search this morning as police divers began scouring the lake.

The bodies were located nearly 24 hours after the girls were reported missing.

Hollywood Lake was still partially covered in two-inch-thick ice when searchers made the grim discovery today.

The bodies were found lying close to each other, a few feet from holes in the ice and in about 10ft of water. The gaps in the ice had earlier been located by the helicopter.

The bodies were being transferred to a local hospital for formal identification.

The lake has been frozen over for several days, but a thaw began in most parts of Ireland yesterday.

One of the girls lived nearby and the pair had been playing on the lake throughout the weekend.

webTitle: What the papers weren't allowed to say

fields.headline: What the papers weren't allowed to say
fields.standfirst: As the 1970 cabinet papers are released, Derek Brown asks why we only learn the true nature of a government and its politicians 30 years too late.
fields.trailText: As the 1970 cabinet papers are released, Derek Brown asks why we only learn the true nature of a government and its politicians 30 years too late.
fields.body:
As the 1970 cabinet papers are released, Derek Brown asks why we only learn the true nature of a government and politicians 30 years too late.

So now we know that our intelligence service spied on trade unions, that a respectable current minister faced prosecution by a previous Labour government, and that Margeret Thatcher, when first appointed to the cabinet, proposed introducing borrowing charges on library books.

We know these things because we are permitted to know, 30 years too late for the knowledge to have any impact on our lives or opinions.

It's a New Year ritual as familiar as Auld Lang Syne, this doling out of dusty, no-longer relevant information. The 30-year-rule, which in theory allows us to find out how many paperclips the ministry of agriculture, fisheries and food used in 1970, but not in 1971, is an essential part of the paranoid secrecy which underpins our peculiar system of government.

All countries have secrets, of course, some of them highly sensitive. But no other country bases its information policy on the premise that everything, but everything, is secret for 30 years.

It is a convention deeply embedded in the psyche of our public servants, elected or otherwise. It allows them astonishing scope for arrogant dissembling and murky manipulation.

A classic example is the MI5 operation, now revealed for the first time, to infiltrate the trade unions active in the bruising dockers' strike of 1970. A stream of reports to the newly elected prime minister, Edward Heath, details private conversations and discussions about tactics. The reports were compiled using bugs, phone taps and the observation of agents inserted into the dockers' groups.

Even today, sections of the report remain blacked-out, the official reason being that the material was "given in confidence" or that it infringes issues of "personal sensitivity".

So even now we don't know how exactly our secret service agents, whom we employed (and may employ still), used our money to spy on our fellow citizens, or how far they went to influence events to the advantage of the government.

It would be naive to suppose that any government, however liberal, would expose its intelligence services, or its own internal deliberations, to instant public and press scrutiny. But the obsession in British officialdom means that issues of genuine and deep public concern are dealt with in a way that shields politicians and appointees alike from any inspection; any fear of outcry.

Only now do we now that Peter Hain, the Foreign Office minister widely tipped for a cabinet promotion, came close to being prosecuted by the Labour government headed by Harold Wilson, for his anti-apartheid campaign.

Hain headed the rowdy, and successful, 1970 crusade to halt a South African cricket tour of England. The then Home Secretary, James Callaghan, told the cabinet that Hain had laid himself open to prosecution for conspiracy - a notion never publicly aired at the time.

And it's not just the panjandrums of government who are protected from investigation. Only now, for example, can we learn from the official papers a fascinating insight into the career of a rising young journalist in 1970 - one Jonathan Aitken.

The budding reporter Aitken made a bit of name for himself with his informed insights into the Nigerian civil war. It emerges that he was given a report by a general on the observer team monitoring the war, on a strictly confidential basis.

Prime minister Heath was told that when the document was returned, the general noticed that the staple fastening it appeared to have been removed and re-attached. "When asked about this," the report laconically notes, "Aitken denied that he had taken copies".

Another eye-catching gobbet of information, long since past its sell-by date but still of socio-historical interest, is that Margaret Thatcher, on becoming Education Secretary in Heath's cabinet, was so keen to bang the cost-cutting drum that she slashed the department budget by even more than the Treasury had demanded. In her zeal she even proposed introducing modest charges for borrowing public library books - but quickly retreated when told that such a move would be wildly unpopular.

Now maybe, just maybe, the government needs to conduct its business out of the glare of publicity (except of course when it deems that publicity beneficial). But do we really have to wait a full generation to find out that a cabinet minister seriously proposed to charge us for reading our own books?

Do we not need such information to judge the quality of that minister, that government?

The authorities, of course, believe we are better kept in ignorance. Freedom of Information is a great slogan, but the current legislation of that name is so cratered with loopholes and get-out clauses, that it would perhaps be more honestly called the Freedom From Information Bill.

webTitle: Bad weather takes shine off New Year celebrations

fields.headline: Bad weather takes shine off New Year celebrations
fields.standfirst: Special report: weather watch
fields.trailText: Hundreds of thousands of revellers shrugged off snow, wind and rain to see in the New Year early today at events across the UK and Ireland.
fields.body:
Hundreds of thousands of revellers shrugged off snow, wind and rain to see in the New Year early today at events across the UK and Ireland.

An estimated 70,000 partygoers braved freezing temperatures to celebrate the stroke of midnight in Trafalgar Square, central London.

Another 100,000 braved the weather to pack the centre of Edinburgh for the city's traditional Hogmanay celebrations.

But some parts of the British Isles woke up to a wet New Year with severe flooding and flood warnings as warmer weather began melting the snow and more heavy rain was forecast.

The environment agency issued 35 flood warnings on rivers in the south west and another eight across the midlands and south of England.

The River Axe in Devon burst its banks in the early hours and washed away a bridge on the A358.

A firefighter had to be rescued when he was stranded by fast flowing water as he tried to save a man trapped by the water.

Six more firefighters had to be rescued by lifeboat from their fire engine near Stranraer, Ayrshire, after it become stuck in floods.

Three people were also rescued from rising floodwater in east Cornwall after the driver of a stranded car called the emergency services on his mobile phone, police said.

In Dorset, all the main roads were flooded but police said they were still passable.

Drivers were warned of "treacherous" conditions on roads in the Highlands and, in Dumfries and Galloway, the main A77 road was under 4ft of water.

Driving wind and rain failed to dampen the spirit of up to 10,000 partygoers at a countdown concert in Birmingham, but Liverpool and Londonderry cancelled their celebrations last night following a severe weather warning from the Met Office.

They were followed by Stirling, Brighton and Hove and Middlesbrough, while freezing conditions forced council leaders in Bristol to scale down their celebrations.

Elsewhere, revellers wrapped up warm to brave sub-zero temperatures, strong winds and blizzards.

The bad weather also brought tragedy.

Treacherous driving conditions claimed the life of a man at Maudlin, near Bodmin, Cornwall, when his Ford Sierra struck a wall on an icy country road.

The body of a man in his 30s was also discovered on Sunday near a beauty spot by a walker in the Sunnyhurst area of Darwen, Lancs.

In Scotland, a climber died on New Year's Eve after falling 100ft off Ben Nevis in Scotland, and another rescue attempt was launched for a second climber stranded on the peak.

webTitle: Entrenched rough sleepers left in cold

fields.headline: Entrenched rough sleepers left in cold
fields.standfirst: As numbers of street people decrease, some still reject hostels
fields.trailText: Peter is immaculate in a three-piece suit, button-down collar and Chelsea boots polished to a gleam.
fields.body:
Peter is immaculate in a three-piece suit, button-down collar and Chelsea boots polished to a gleam.

Alexander's white woolly jumper is spotless, though his lower half is covered by a cardboard box.

Stuart works as a school caretaker and goes home in the evenings to the doorway of a church.

They are among the 1,200 or so who sleep rough on the streets of Britain every night and none of them fits the stereotype of the workshy drug addict.

Geordie Peter, 58, served nine years in the army, on tours of duty in Germany, Belgium, Northern Ireland and Hong Kong. His wife died last year and he lost the housing association flat they had shared. His mother and father have since died, and his brother is emigrating to Canada.

Multiple shocks of this kind are a common experience of those on the streets. But Peter is chipper, and dresses as if he were on his way to a job interview.

He waves his hands expansively on the porch of the Methodist church where he sleeps. "This is God's country," he says.

He will not go near homeless hostels. "It's the idiots that's in them. The needle-pushers and the dope-swallowers. I'd rather be out here."

Stuart, 50, from Oban, agrees: "I don't want to go into a hostel. I want peace and quiet - go to my work and come home at night"

He is homeless on and off, whenever he falls off the bottom rung of the social ladder.

"It's only for maybe a week or two at a time. This job pays very low wages, and I'm struggling to get back on my feet." It was "nobody's fault but mine" that he became homeless. He walked out on his last job and spent most of his money on a holiday, then moved on to the streets when money to pay his rent ran out.

As his caretaking job pays little more than £70 a week, he is finding it hard to save enough for a deposit. For now, he shares the church porch with Peter.

Alexander, a former dustman, has spent three and a half years on the road following a bust-up with his wife.

"I just walked out on her and the flat. I look at this as a permanent camping holiday," he says, waving his fag in the direction of the stars.

The government has made homelessness a priority and aims to reduce the numbers of rough sleepers to about 600 by the year 2002. Progress is being made. Last week the homelessness charity Shelter said that the numbers of rough sleepers in British cities and towns had dropped by around a third this year.

The director of Shelter, Chris Holmes, said: "Over the last year, through the rough sleepers' strategy and the work of voluntary agencies, the number of rough sleepers has been reduced by about a third, but it hasn't in central London, where the problems are most visible and worst."

Crucial to reducing numbers is persuading the most long term street sleepers to exchange their pavements for warm beds; a job which is more difficult than it sounds.

A leading homelessness charity, Crisis, has voiced fears that street workers are concentrating on those who are easiest to help in an effort to hit government targets.

At a recent conference, the Crisis chief executive, Shaks Ghosh, claimed that some of the most vulnerable people on the streets - in particular the "entrenched", mostly male, rough sleepers who have been on the road for years and often have serious mental health and addiction problems - were being ignored because they had the greatest needs.

"They need to know that we will not turn our backs on them simply because they present us with the greatest challenge," she said.

The charities which run the street level contact and assessment (CAT) teams were stung by the criticism, and pointed out that persuading men like Peter, Stuart and Alexander to come in from the cold was no straightforward task.

All three men are clients of the homeless housing association Thames Reach, whose chief executive, Jeremy Swain, said that Peter was on a waiting list for a flat and should be housed in the next month.

Stuart's situation is, with cruel irony, more difficult because he has a job. "It's an illustration of the problem we have with London rents," Mr Swain said. "A lot of Stuart's money would be taken off him to go towards his housing because he wouldn't get much housing benefit. It's a very difficult situation."

The hope is that Stuart will be eligible for help from another homeless charity which could lend him a deposit for a cheap private flat.

Alexander's case is even less clearcut; he appears to derive genuine enjoyment from his outdoor existence, in which he supports himself by collecting street bric-a-brac and selling it from a stall at Portobello market, in west London.

Mr Swain believes he will eventually accept an offer of housing, but for now Thames Reach workers are concentrating on building up a relationship of trust with him.

The stepping stones to getting people like him housed include encouraging him to accept state help, such as unemployment benefit and NHS care.

There was an early illustration of how difficult all this can be when Natalie Lodge, an outreach worker for the charity, was late for our meeting. She had been negotiating with a homeless man, 56, and on the streets for 21 years, who was threatening to walk out of the hostel where he had been staying four days.

"His benefits weren't sorted out," said Natalie. She managed to calm him down, reassuring him that he would be able to claim benefits.

Her work can be dangerous. One man, a heavy drinker and so aggressive that no hostel will take him, lashes out at her almost every time she goes near him. Once he chased her down the street.

Many of her clients have been spewed out by the care system, or are exiles of family breakdown, escaping from physical and sexual abuse. They are scared of help.

"It's because the system has let them down," Natalie said. "If people have been in care or been abused by their parents, they haven't got trust in anybody."

The bravado of the homeless men she met could be a mask for grim personal stories, she said.

For all his bonhomie, it is evident that Peter has a serious drink problem. He swigs heavily from a Stella as we talk, and tells us about the other morning, when he downed two bottles of whisky soon after he woke up.

He may be the kind of rough sleeper that the chief executive of Crisis has in mind when she claims that the contact and assessment teams are failing the vulnerable.

"I was out with our mobile health unit," Ms Ghosh said. "I spoke to dozens of people with very severe health needs; with terrible depression, people who were detoxing. And they couldn't get access to beds.

"The homeless guys on the street are saying that they have to be seen three times in the same place by the same CAT worker before they can get access to the system."

Mr Swain argued that Crisis had got it wrong. He said that there were only a limited number of hostel beds available to his staff each night, and that putting people into hostels was not always the answer.

Evidently, some homeless people, such as Peter and Stuart, have no desire to go into hostels but prefer to sleep rough until they can move into a home of their own, but the most vulnerable rough sleepers are always a priority.

"If a 15-year-old with drug problems, somebody who's extremely vulnerable, comes on to the streets tonight we can get them off straight away.

"We would get social services involved, do whatever it takes. But for some people it may not be best to go into a central London hostel.

"If we are dealing with a 16-year-old who has come down from Stoke, the aim may not be to get him into a hostel, but to get him home," Mr Swain added.

"The risk is that in a hostel he could get involved with young people taking drugs, who would teach him the tricks of being on the street."

Peter, Stuart and Alexander will have seen in the new year under the stars. Between now and whenever they have a roof over their heads again, the slow, patient work of reaching out to these men at the bottom of the pile goes on.

 Some names have been changed.
fields.bodyText: Peter is immaculate in a three-piece suit, button-down collar and Chelsea boots polished to a gleam. Alexander's white woolly jumper is spotless, though his lower half is covered by a cardboard box. Stuart works as a school caretaker and goes home in the evenings to the doorway of a church. They are among the 1,200 or so who sleep rough on the streets of Britain every night and none of them fits the stereotype of the workshy drug addict. Geordie Peter, 58, served nine years in the army, on tours of duty in Germany, Belgium, Northern Ireland and Hong Kong. His wife died last year and he lost the housing association flat they had shared. His mother and father have since died, and his brother is emigrating to Canada. Multiple shocks of this kind are a common experience of those on the streets. But Peter is chipper, and dresses as if he were on his way to a job interview. He waves his hands expansively on the porch of the Methodist church where he sleeps. "This is God's country," he says. He will not go near homeless hostels. "It's the idiots that's in them. The needle-pushers and the dope-swallowers. I'd rather be out here." Stuart, 50, from Oban, agrees: "I don't want to go into a hostel. I want peace and quiet - go to my work and come home at night" He is homeless on and off, whenever he falls off the bottom rung of the social ladder. "It's only for maybe a week or two at a time. This job pays very low wages, and I'm struggling to get back on my feet." It was "nobody's fault but mine" that he became homeless. He walked out on his last job and spent most of his money on a holiday, then moved on to the streets when money to pay his rent ran out. As his caretaking job pays little more than £70 a week, he is finding it hard to save enough for a deposit. For now, he shares the church porch with Peter. Alexander, a former dustman, has spent three and a half years on the road following a bust-up with his wife. "I just walked out on her and the flat. I look at this as a permanent camping holiday," he says, waving his fag in the direction of the stars. The government has made homelessness a priority and aims to reduce the numbers of rough sleepers to about 600 by the year 2002. Progress is being made. Last week the homelessness charity Shelter said that the numbers of rough sleepers in British cities and towns had dropped by around a third this year. The director of Shelter, Chris Holmes, said: "Over the last year, through the rough sleepers' strategy and the work of voluntary agencies, the number of rough sleepers has been reduced by about a third, but it hasn't in central London, where the problems are most visible and worst." Crucial to reducing numbers is persuading the most long term street sleepers to exchange their pavements for warm beds; a job which is more difficult than it sounds. A leading homelessness charity, Crisis, has voiced fears that street workers are concentrating on those who are easiest to help in an effort to hit government targets. At a recent conference, the Crisis chief executive, Shaks Ghosh, claimed that some of the most vulnerable people on the streets - in particular the "entrenched", mostly male, rough sleepers who have been on the road for years and often have serious mental health and addiction problems - were being ignored because they had the greatest needs. "They need to know that we will not turn our backs on them simply because they present us with the greatest challenge," she said. The charities which run the street level contact and assessment (CAT) teams were stung by the criticism, and pointed out that persuading men like Peter, Stuart and Alexander to come in from the cold was no straightforward task. All three men are clients of the homeless housing association Thames Reach, whose chief executive, Jeremy Swain, said that Peter was on a waiting list for a flat and should be housed in the next month. Stuart's situation is, with cruel irony, more difficult because he has a job. "It's an illustration of the problem we have with London rents," Mr Swain said. "A lot of Stuart's money would be taken off him to go towards his housing because he wouldn't get much housing benefit. It's a very difficult situation." The hope is that Stuart will be eligible for help from another homeless charity which could lend him a deposit for a cheap private flat. Alexander's case is even less clearcut; he appears to derive genuine enjoyment from his outdoor existence, in which he supports himself by collecting street bric-a-brac and selling it from a stall at Portobello market, in west London. Mr Swain believes he will eventually accept an offer of housing, but for now Thames Reach workers are concentrating on building up a relationship of trust with him. The stepping stones to getting people like him housed include encouraging him to accept state help, such as unemployment benefit and NHS care. There was an early illustration of how difficult all this can be when Natalie Lodge, an outreach worker for the charity, was late for our meeting. She had been negotiating with a homeless man, 56, and on the streets for 21 years, who was threatening to walk out of the hostel where he had been staying four days. "His benefits weren't sorted out," said Natalie. She managed to calm him down, reassuring him that he would be able to claim benefits. Her work can be dangerous. One man, a heavy drinker and so aggressive that no hostel will take him, lashes out at her almost every time she goes near him. Once he chased her down the street. Many of her clients have been spewed out by the care system, or are exiles of family breakdown, escaping from physical and sexual abuse. They are scared of help. "It's because the system has let them down," Natalie said. "If people have been in care or been abused by their parents, they haven't got trust in anybody." The bravado of the homeless men she met could be a mask for grim personal stories, she said. For all his bonhomie, it is evident that Peter has a serious drink problem. He swigs heavily from a Stella as we talk, and tells us about the other morning, when he downed two bottles of whisky soon after he woke up. He may be the kind of rough sleeper that the chief executive of Crisis has in mind when she claims that the contact and assessment teams are failing the vulnerable. "I was out with our mobile health unit," Ms Ghosh said. "I spoke to dozens of people with very severe health needs; with terrible depression, people who were detoxing. And they couldn't get access to beds. "The homeless guys on the street are saying that they have to be seen three times in the same place by the same CAT worker before they can get access to the system." Mr Swain argued that Crisis had got it wrong. He said that there were only a limited number of hostel beds available to his staff each night, and that putting people into hostels was not always the answer. Evidently, some homeless people, such as Peter and Stuart, have no desire to go into hostels but prefer to sleep rough until they can move into a home of their own, but the most vulnerable rough sleepers are always a priority. "If a 15-year-old with drug problems, somebody who's extremely vulnerable, comes on to the streets tonight we can get them off straight away. "We would get social services involved, do whatever it takes. But for some people it may not be best to go into a central London hostel. "If we are dealing with a 16-year-old who has come down from Stoke, the aim may not be to get him into a hostel, but to get him home," Mr Swain added. "The risk is that in a hostel he could get involved with young people taking drugs, who would teach him the tricks of being on the street." Peter, Stuart and Alexander will have seen in the new year under the stars. Between now and whenever they have a roof over their heads again, the slow, patient work of reaching out to these men at the bottom of the pile goes on.  Some names have been changed.

webTitle: Thatcher the library book snatcher

fields.headline: Thatcher the library book snatcher
fields.trailText: Margaret Thatcher's first recorded intervention in Edward Heath's cabinet was to propose the imposition of borrowing charges on library books, and the abolition of free school milk for children over seven, which earned her the nickname Milk Snatcher.
fields.body:
Margaret Thatcher's first recorded intervention in Edward Heath's cabinet was to propose the imposition of borrowing charges on library books, and the abolition of free school milk for children over seven, which earned her the nickname Milk Snatcher.

The new education secretary told the cabinet in September that "she had been able to offer the chief secretary, Treasury, rather larger savings than he had sought on school meals, school milk, further education and library charges".

But since library charges "could be unpopular", she asked for cabinet endorsement.

"Considerable concern" was expressed about the impact of higher school meals charges.

Two weeks later, the idea of ending a free public library service was quietly dropped, after a flurry of Whitehall negotiations.

Lord Eccles, arts minister, was brought to cabinet to explain that charges would be "difficult to defend since [they] represented a volte face in Conservative policy" and would attract a meagre revenue.

webTitle: Leila Khaled freed after US pressure

fields.headline: Leila Khaled freed after US pressure
fields.trailText: Edward Heath was pushed by the US into exchanging the iconic Palestinian guerrilla fighter Leila Khaled for dozens of western hostages after the world's most spectacular multiple aircraft hijacking in September 1970.
fields.body:
Edward Heath was pushed by the US into exchanging the iconic Palestinian guerrilla fighter Leila Khaled for dozens of western hostages after the world's most spectacular multiple aircraft hijacking in September 1970.

Khaled was at the centre of a crisis sparked by the seizure of five civilian airliners by the radical Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine.

The PFLP blew up three of the aircraft for the television cameras at a disused RAF airstrip in the Jordanian desert, and 56 US and European passengers were used to bargain for the release of seven Palestinian prisoners in Britain, Germany and Switzerland.

One was Khaled, who had been handed over to the British authorities at Heathrow after an attempt to commandeer an El Al flight was foiled and her fellow hijacker, Patrick Arguello, a Nicaraguan, was shot dead by Israeli guards.

The decision to trade Khaled three weeks later was criticised by the Tory right and defended by Heath supporters on the grounds that prosecution might have failed because of a lack of evidence that the hijack attempt took place over British soil.

But the state papers show that Heath told the cabinet less than three days after her capture that he had "acquiesced in a US proposal authorising the Red Cross to offer the release of Leila Khaled, together with the terrorists held by the Swiss and German authorities, in exchange for the hostages and aircraft held at Dawson's Field".

Heath's personal file - which occupies more than 50 pages of cabinet minutes - includes a letter written by Khaled, from Ealing police station in west London, to her mother, describing her routine and promising to "return soon".

She was treated well,"as if I were an official state guest", she wrote, adding: "I do not worry about myself... The only thing that grieves and hurts me today is that I am not now carrying arms and am not sharing with my people in the battle."

Khaled, who later became a member of the Palestinian parliament and now lives in Amman, was referring to the war then erupting in Jordan between King Hussein's army and the increasingly powerful Palestinian resistance.

In a confidential annex, an astonished Heath told his cabinet that King Hussein had appealed through Britain's ambassador in Amman "for an air strike by Israel". In discussion with the ambassador, King Hussein described Colonel Muammar Gadafy, president of Libya, as a "nutcase" and the Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat as a "criminal".

webTitle: Hain opposition to cricket tour led to talk of prosecution

fields.headline: Hain opposition to cricket tour led to talk of prosecution
fields.trailText: Plans to prosecute Peter Hain - the current Foreign Office minister widely tipped for a cabinet post - over his campaign to stop a South African cricket tour of Britain in 1970 were considered by Harold Wilson's Labour government, cabinet papers released today disclose.
fields.body:
Plans to prosecute Peter Hain - the current Foreign Office minister widely tipped for a cabinet post - over his campaign to stop a South African cricket tour of Britain in 1970 were considered by Harold Wilson's Labour government, cabinet papers released today disclose.

They reveal that an anxious James Callaghan, then home secretary, warned his cabinet colleagues that a government decision to ban the tour by the side from the apartheid state would lead to "a major debate" in parliament. He said he had received from "the organiser of the Stop the 70 Tour Campaign, Mr Peter Hain, a letter asking for assurances that the police would not adopt discriminatory methods in dealing with any demonstrators".

Callaghan told the cabinet he proposed a "firm reply pointing out that... no such assurances were necessary". He added that Mr Hain laid himself open to "prosecution for conspiracy... even before such plans [to interfere with cricket matches] had actually been put into practice".

Mr Hain told the Guardian last night he knew there was talk of prosecuting him. "But I was involved in classic non-violent direct action, such as running on pitches." Some 10,000 demonstrators took part in the campaign.

Wilson warned the cabinet of the "public excitement and agitation about this visit". Though reluctant to intervene directly to stop the tour he was deeply anxious about the diplomatic consequences and a threat by African countries to boycott the Commonwealth games in Edinburgh that year.

On May 21, with the government coming under increasing pressure, Callaghan met the MCC, the governing body of English cricket. It said it was "not competent" to consider such matters as "race or Commonwealth relations", but told him that if he asked it to stop the tour, the MCC would find it "virtually impossible not to accede". He replied: "I now make such a request."

The next day the MCC told him it had informed the South African Cricket Association that the tour would not go ahead.

 The full extent to which Wilson's government was embroiled in a heated row over whether to resume arms sales to South Africa is also revealed in the cabinet papers.

In December 1967 the par liamentary Labour party erupted as word leaked out that some ministers, notably Denis Healey and James Callaghan, defence and home secretaries, wanted to break the embargo.

The minutes of an emergency cabinet meeting record Wilson as telling his colleagues: "Not only the government's moral and economic credibility were at issue. To agree to supply the proposed military equipment to South Africa would be contrary to the principles for which the government stood."

The cabinet repeatedly put off a decision.

But the Tories, who defeated Labour in the June 1970 election, were determined to break the embargo.

After bruising encounters with African leaders over the issue, Sir Alec Douglas-Home, the foreign secretary, told colleagues: "They appeared to be obsessed with the issue of racialism in South Africa to an extent which blinded them to the communist threat and made rational discussion virtually impossible."

In December, the Heath cabinet agreed to break the embargo and supply spares and arms "to maintain South African maritime defences".

webTitle: Dockers' leader passed strike tactics to MI5 agents during national stoppage

fields.headline: Dockers' leader passed strike tactics to MI5 agents during national stoppage
fields.trailText: A former president of the Transport and General Workers' Union has admitted knowingly passing information on strike tactics to the security services, after MI5 reports on a national docks stoppage in 1970 released today detailed his views and attitudes.
fields.body:
A former president of the Transport and General Workers' Union has admitted knowingly passing information on strike tactics to the security services, after MI5 reports on a national docks stoppage in 1970 released today detailed his views and attitudes.

Brian Nicholson, a London dockers' leader at the time who became a close ally of Neil Kinnock in the late 1980s, told the Guardian: "They used to play games with me and I used to play games with them. What I told them was not significant, unless to tell them things to let the other side know."

Mr Nicholson said MI5 agents "flitted around the docks posing as leftwing activists and do-gooders" during the industrial upheavals of the early 1970s, although others were associated with rightwing groups such as Catholic Action and Moral Rearmament.

"But I realised who they were," said Mr Nicholson, who had a leftwing profile and now runs a retired dockers' club in east London. "The establishment panicked easy in those days and they were on to me daily. People were paranoid at the time about leftwing takeovers. But I was never a communist - I'm a Catholic and a churchgoer."

Mr Nicholson features prominently in a string of MI5 reports to the newly elected prime minister, Edward Heath, about a two week national strike over pay by 50,000 dockers in July 1970, which led the government to declare a state of emergency and put troops on standby. The reports by MI5's director general, Sir Martin Furnival-Jones, which are stamped "top secret", are contained in Heath's personal file on the strike and are the first such accounts from the domestic spying service on trade unions in the postwar period to be released. They have been released to the public record office under the 30 year rule.

Focused mainly on the role of communists and their allies in the strike - which was led by the then TGWU general secretary, Jack Jones - the reports reveal the extent of MI5's undercover penetration and surveillance of the left at the time and contain a relatively sophisticated analysis of the private differences among the dockers' leaders.

Their release comes at a time when Stella Rimington, who headed MI5 in the early 1990s, is about to publish her memoirs in the teeth of fierce resistance in Whitehall.

Dame Stella worked for MI5's political subversion department, F branch, in the early 1970s, when its role was massively expanded in response to increasing industrial militancy on the left. She later headed MI5's "counter-subversion" operations against the 1984-85 miners' strike.

The 1970 docks strike was the first of a series of increasingly effective stoppages during the Heath administration, which culminated in the miners' strike of 1974, the three-day week and the Tories' electoral defeat.

The MI5 briefings on the July docks walkout - passed to the prime minister every couple of days and based on agents' reports, phone tapping and bugging - include accounts of private meetings between Communist party officials and dockers' shop stewards and even internal discussions about the editorial line of the Morning Star, described as "the subject of much anxious consideration".

Several parts of the reports have been blacked out, including phrases around the name of Brian Nicholson, whose views and dilemmas are described in detail, even though he was only one of several rank-and-file leaders in the London docks.

The deletions will have been made either because the words refer to "material given in confidence" or because of issues of "personal sensitivity".

webTitle: Charity 'wrong' over winter homeless crisis

fields.headline: Charity 'wrong' over winter homeless crisis
fields.trailText: The government's homelessness tsar, Louise Casey, yesterday won backing in her row with the charity Crisis over its claims that people were being left to freeze on the streets of London.
fields.body:
The government's homelessness tsar, Louise Casey, yesterday won backing in her row with the charity Crisis over its claims that people were being left to freeze on the streets of London.

The Crisis chief executive, Shaks Ghosh, said at the weekend that her charity had been forced to send 75 homeless people back on to the streets of the capital because there were no hostel beds available when its temporary Christmas shelters closed on Friday.

Ms Ghosh said: "My fear is - Crisis is really, really worried - that people actually are going to be dying in doorways because the weather is so cold."

Ms Casey responded by accusing Crisis of scaremongering - and she has been backed by a charity which carries out street level outreach work with rough sleepers.

Jeremy Swain, director of Thames Reach, said that not all the people who used Crisis's short stay Christmas shelters were genuinely homeless. Some used the facilities out of loneliness or poverty.

He said: "Crisis is a very good thing as it brings people together at Christmas. They can get a haircut and other help but the vast majority of them are not really homeless.

"I would like to see the list of the 75 people they mention. I bet they actually have somewhere to go. We have had our workers down at their shelters over the past three days and I know that anyone who really needs a bed will have been sorted out."

Crisis provided places for about 1,000 people over the Christmas period, with about 450 beds in London, said Ms Ghosh.

The Crisis chief rejected accusations that the charity was attempting to raise its profile by stirring up a row. "I am appalled by Louise's comments," she said. "We would never try to raise donations by scaremongering."

One homeless man had told her he would be leaving her charity's temporary shelter to sleep on Clapham Common, in south London, where the snow was up to two inches deep, she added.

The Guardian went out with Thames Reach workers over the Christmas period and looked at the difficulties faced by those who try to persuade long term street sleepers to accept offers of accommodation.

Thames Reach said that many rough sleepers had been victims of abuse which had destroyed their trust in authority, and made them unwilling to accept offers of help from official bodies.

Often, homeless people were reluctant to go into hostels where they might have to share the facilities with drug-takers. They preferred instead to take their chances outdoors until private accommodation became available.

webTitle: TV man breaks cover for £3m show

fields.headline: TV man breaks cover for £3m show
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The BBC is grooming the investigative reporter Donal MacIntyre to be a "face" of BBC1.
fields.body:
The BBC is grooming the investigative reporter Donal MacIntyre to be a "face" of BBC1.

After the reputation of his programme, MacIntyre Undercover, was shored up with the conviction of two football hooligans featured in one his programmes, the BBC is eager to promote him as a ratings winning presenter.

Lorraine Hegessey the controller of BBC1 has given her backing to a £3m, four-part series about the weather, to be presented by MacIntyre.

The programme, co-funded by the cable and satellite channel Discovery, will examine four extremes of weather: hot, cold, wet and dry. It will explore how people live in such conditions, and give an insight into how the weather works.

McIntyre and a production team are shortly to begin filming in Greenland.

The series will be hailed as a delivery on the BBC's commitment to keep popular science programmes in peak time. There have been concerns that under a reorganisation of BBC channels, science programmes would be relegated.

A member of the show's production team said it would be thoroughly researched - not just an excuse to put "dishy Donal in waterproofs standing in the middle of a tornado".

webTitle: Greece joins euro

fields.headline: Greece joins euro
fields.standfirst: Economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Greece today becomes the 12th member of the euro single currency zone, after sprinting less than two years ago to meet targets of lower inflation and budget deficits.
fields.body:
Greece today becomes the 12th member of the euro single currency zone, after sprinting less than two years ago to meet targets of lower inflation and budget deficits.

"Our country is already experiencing euro conditions. We all know that our inclusion in EMU ensures for us greater stability and opens up new horizons," the prime minister, Costas Simitis, said in a televised New Year message.

Greece was left out of the first single currency wave for failing to meet any of the convergence criteria, and analysts thought it faced a Herculean task.

But the double-digit inflation of the early 1990s has been cut to 4.2%, the drachma has smoothly landed on its pre-set central parity of 340.75 per euro, and the base lending rate has been cut to 4.75%.

webTitle: G2: John Sutherland on Bush's faith drive

fields.headline: Pick up thy syringe and walk, sinner
fields.standfirst:
On Bush's faith drive

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: On Bush's faith drive.
fields.body:
Ask what George W Bush did as governor of Texas and most Britons would say that he was a serial executioner and what he himself calls a "purty good delegator" (in Bush-speak, the word rhymes with "alligator"). He let other guys do the hard work so he could concentrate on his afternoon game of electronic golf.

In fact, as his campaign website proclaims, George W's proudest gubernatorial accomplishment was to make "faith-based action" the corner stone of his state's welfare programme. The "Texas experiment" offers a chilling insight into what "compassionate conservatism" will mean over the next four years for 40m Americans with substance-abuse problems.

Faith-based (Holy Joe) recovery programs had been around in the Bible Belt for ever, but never amounted to much therapeutically until Bush's advisers noticed an obscure clause in the 1996 Welfare Reform Act ("Charitable Choice") which for the first time enabled religious organisations to qualify for state funding for their work with addicts.

Up to this point, rehabilitation programmes were strictly controlled. Twelve-step groups such as AA could "counsel", but not "treat" addicts. So too the churches, which could preach but not cure. Governor Bush changed all that. Taking a faith-based recovery programme called Teen Challenge as his model, he launched in 1997 "a bold experiment in welfare reform". Texas house bills 2481 and 2482 opened the channel for state dollars through "partnership" schemes.

More importantly, the bills released faith-based programmes from "secular" control. They could now run their own show, without those pesky atheistic inspectors looking over their shoulders. Bush saw himself as "unleashing" the power of the church (that is, his church) in his war on drugs.

Bush knows at first hand about addiction. He himself underwent a "faith-based" cure for his alcohol problem under the supervision of Billy Graham. It was the prelude to a meteoric political career. From drunkard to president in 10 years. It's Horatio Alger's "Log cabin to White House" for our times.

Like his father, Bush is never strong on the "vision thing". But in his heart, he believes with his co-religionists that "Jesus cures". Is he himself not living proof? His guru on the doctrine of faith-based salvation is the University of Texas journalism professor Marvin Olasky. A one-issue Christian Conservative, Olasky helped draft Bush's 1997 manifesto, Faith in Action: a New Vision for Church-State Cooperation. Olasky believes, fanatically, that groups like Teen Challenge will make America strong, clean and God-fearing again. Hallelujah.

If you believe their propaganda (I don't), faith-based programmes have two irresistible selling points: they work and they're cheap. Their promotional material claims 80% success rates as against a paltry 10% for traditional AA and STI ("short term in-patient") therapies. Teen Challenge (since 1997 supported jointly by church donations and state funds) costs the Texas taxpayer $200 a week for full residential care. Sanatoriums like the Betty Ford charge 10 times that. Jesus saves, and so do you.

Faith-based programmes make no secret of their evangelical agenda. Read the signs outside their centres: "Drug addiction is not a Disease. It's a sin." They are hostile to the medical profession (pointy-headed experts), the social services (bureaucrats) and to AA (a cult). They deny the "disease concept" of alcoholism and drug addiction. They despise AA's wishy-washy vapourings about a non-denominational "higher power". For the faith-based movements, there is only one God to consult. Theirs. You're Jewish, Muslim, Sikh? Tough.

The faith-based recovery regime is a mixture of boot camp and Bible class. They permit no medication and rely entirely on what is called the "Jesus factor". You are not an addict but a sinner. Find your saviour and you will find sobriety. Guaranteed.

Addiction rates among the young are at epidemic levels. But many liberal observers believe that the faith-based movement is out of control in Texas. Historically it fills the vacuum left by the end of the cold war. We beat the Kremlin; now for the Devil.

Bush (with Olasky at his ear) intends to spread the Texas initiative nationwide. As president, he vowed, he would establish an "Office of Faith-Based Action" in Washington. And when he does, God help America.

webTitle: The Architectural Review's awards

fields.headline: Beautiful dreamers
fields.standfirst: If the latest architectural awards are anything to go by, the future is in safe hands, says Jonathan Glancey
fields.trailText: If the latest architectural awards are anything to go by, the future is in safe hands, says Jonathan Glancey.
fields.body:
The last issue of the Architectural Review was a treasure trove. Here was a church built by villagers in rural Bolivia, made of timber and plastic sheeting and designed by a young woman straight out of college. Here was a public lavatory designed for a Japanese park, as much public artwork as public convenience. Another page revealed a stylish house built on a sand dune. Then there was a superb mobile home named Fred, an animated viewing platform on a Norwegian mountain top, an idyllic Finnish sauna and the intriguing new Finnish Embassy in Berlin ...

This magical collection was brought together by the magazine's annual award, aimed at encouraging emerging talent throughout the world. What makes this award worthwhile is that it is truly global and the jury appears to be free of stylistic prejudices. Most architectural awards, whether for building of the year or best young talent, do little more than round up the usual suspects: yet another Dutch housing scheme designed by an earnest young devotee of Rem Koolhaas; some white box house extension that could have been designed at almost any time over the past 70 years.

This award could hardly be more different. The jury brought together architects Odile Decq (France), Will Bruder (US), Adalberto Dias (Portugal), Christoph Ingenhoven (Germany), Erick van Egeraat (Netherlands) and Peter Davey, editor of the Architectural Review, as chairman. The judges were big-spirited enough to choose as joint winners of the £10,000 prize Jae Cha's self-build church at Urubo, Bolivia, alongside Shuhei Endo's public lavatories in Japan's Hyogo Prefecture and an inflatable pretzel-like wall by Mark Dytham and Astrid Klein fronting a building site in Tokyo.

The award drew more than 700 entries from more than 60 countries. This is impressive, although it does mean the judges would have visited few of the buildings they had to consider. Yet while it's true that no final judgment should be made until a building has been experienced in the round, photographs and drawings can at least reveal those that are likely to be most inventive and delightful. The qualities the judges were looking for were, according to Davey, "courage, the ability to make some change for the good with the least input of resources, the use of materials in ways proper to the nature, and the expression of a desire to enhance human existence".

A tall order? Maybe. But just look at the church that Jae Cha has designed in Bolivia. Using cheap pressure-treated timber and sheets of corrugated translucent polycarbonate (stuff that you come across in any serious builders' merchant) and gathering these in two circles - an outer and an inner wall - she has, in the judges' words, "managed to conjure an intense feeling of the numinous. The work is the more powerful because it was partly designed by the architect on site, when the exact positioning of the translucent sheets was determined."

This was so that the fall of light inside the building could be determined. This was not only to prevent glare while ensuring there was sufficient light inside, but to allow light and shade to record the movements of the sun, like a kind of Catholic Stonehenge. The church is circular and archetypal in its geometric simplicity. It also promises to be quietly beautiful even after sunset, when soft light glows out through those translucent walls.

So often in Britain we try to make cheap buildings look fancy. We can't help tacking on decorative details to pretend a car park is some sort of Victorian civic palace or a cynically built cul-de-sac house an exercise in late-flowering Palladian design. The most moving, as opposed to entertaining, buildings are nearly always those that have integrity, whatever their style. And when there is little money to spend, simplicity is undoubtedly a virtue, although, as Cha's church proves, that need not mean keeping a lid on the imagination.

Far from it. Equally simple in its way is Fred, the decidedly cute mobile home invented by Austrian architect Oskar Kaufmann. "Everyone on the jury fell for Fred," says Davey. "He (or it) has a cheeky personality that seems capable of adaptation to almost any social and topographical location." Or, as Kaufmann puts it, "Call your trucker and next day you can live somewhere else." Ah, if only. Although Fred looks very smart in a chic way, he is also perfectly green, being well insulated and made almost entirely of appropriately resourced wood. Water can be gathered from the roof for the shower and lavatory.

Fred arrives on location as a 3 metre cube package. Settled down, whether on the deck or on stilts, he can be expanded telescopically and offers a bathroom, kitchen and sleeping area and large, handsome windows. "Fred," say the judges, "is much more elegant and unobtrusive than a typical trailer, and he could make a very great difference to the coastlines of much of Europe", disfigured as they are by insensitive trailer parks and other forms of wilfully naff cheap accommodation. Fred is probably a little too sophisticated (ie, expensive) to serve as a home for refugees from natural disasters in poor parts of the world; he would, however, make a fine building block for barrios, favelas and townships. If I had a garden, I'd give Fred a home; he would make a great guest wing or writing studio.

As for the two Japanese projects, both are great fun and utterly unexpected. Public toilets are usually horrid things tucked away behind evergreen hedges because they are an embarrassment. Not so Shuhei Endo's lavatories and park-keeper's hut. This is a brilliant, unabashed swirl of galvanised corrugated metal, its loops and spirals derived from the structural logic of this malleable material. Endo calls this enjoyable design exercise "springtecture". It's certainly jaunty and doubtless well worth spending a yen to see.

Mark Dytham and Astrid Klein's temporary "Pika Pika Pretzel Wall" stretches 34m along Omotesando, "Tokyo's Champs Elysées". There have been a lot of building site hoardings along the Omotesando recently, most of them detracting from the admittedly higgledy-piggledy streetscape.

Here was a chance to transform a basic utility into a playful architectural adventure, one that would make people smile. Made of the same high-tech fabric used in the construction of high-altitude balloons, the pretzel wall lights up internally at night. As Davey notes, many of the designs favoured by the judges in this year's award are temporary or subject to change. "Perhaps", he adds, "there is something about transience that brings out edge in design."

Certainly these schemes by young professionals are encouraging in that they prove that architects still know how to experiment with materials for their and our delight. The awards also show how the best young architects at the beginning of the 21st century, whether they come from rich or poor countries, can offer basic, cheap buildings that nevertheless have the power to raise the spirit and ennoble those who use them. The future really does look good.

webTitle: Gerbeau keeps bid alive

fields.headline: Gerbeau keeps bid alive
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, chief executive of the troubled Millennium Dome, confirmed yesterday that he would bid for the site at Greenwich if the government's latest preferred bidder, Legacy, failed to complete its proposed £125m purchase.
fields.body:
Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, chief executive of the troubled Millennium Dome, confirmed yesterday that he would bid for the site at Greenwich if the government's latest preferred bidder, Legacy, failed to complete its proposed £125m purchase.

Speaking at the dome as the building closed its doors to the public after a year, Mr Gerbeau said he was part of a consortium headed by James Palumbo, owner of the Ministry of Sound nightclub, that was prepared to pay £150m for the site. Mr Gerbeau said he had first put in a bid two months ago but the offer was handed in too late to be included with the others.

He declined to elaborate on what role Guy Hands would play in his team; Mr Hands headed the bid that the government originally accepted, from the Japanese financial group Nomura. It fell through.

"Obviously we have been talking to people about turning this place into an international entertainment venue," Mr Gerbeau said.

"The idea would be to reshape some of the exhibits and take the central arena and turn it into a space for concerts, sport and other entertainment."

David James, chairman of the New Millennium Experience Company, whcih runs the dome, said that Mr Gerbeau's "keen interest" had been noted by NMEC and the government but confirmed that the bid, believed to be for £150m, would not be considered unless the Legacy bid failed. "The government has an obligation to Legacy and as long as their bid remains, that will be the case."

Mr Gerbeau had avoided a possible conflict of interest over the dome sale, Mr James said, by volunteering to leave board meetings when the future was discussed.

Mr James said that the final liquidation of the company could take until the middle of 2002.

He would not say whether five former dome executive directors, including Jennie Page, the former chief executive, would get bonuses.

"The bonuses were always discretionary, and the board will discuss the matter at a meeting in the second week in January," he said. It would also decide Mr Gerbeau's bonus.

The chief executive was hired at a £100,000 salary with a potential bonus of £100,000. Mr James noted that the salary element was later raised to £150,000. He could receive a bonus of up to £50,000.

Mr James said that once all creditors had been paid and the dome decommissioned, any surplus funds would be returned to the lottery commission. But the commission "can't expect to get more than £10m back", he added.
