webTitle: West Bank fears new reprisals

fields.headline: West Bank fears new reprisals
fields.standfirst:
Vengeance killings by Palestinians and Israelis - and Fatah's call for more - could break peace process

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Vengeance killings by Palestinians and Israelis - and Fatah's call for more - could break peace process.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill in Ramallah, West Bank
fields.body:
Cries for vengeance resounded through the West Bank and Israel yesterday after Israeli soldiers killed a prominent member of Yasser Arafat's Fatah movement in apparent reprisal for a Palestinian ambush that left two prominent Jewish settlers dead.

Thabet Thabet was the most senior member of Fatah to die since the Palestinian uprising, which has claimed more than 350 lives, began three months ago. The Israelis have recently been assassinating Palestinians they identified as leaders of militias that have attacked their soldiers and settlers.

In Thabet's case, there has been no claim of responsibility so far and the army refused to comment publicly. While some Palestinian sources characterised him as a supporter of the peace process, Israeli media quoted army sources disputing this and hinting that he had been planning violent activities.

Three hours before the Fatah official was shot in his car outside his home at Tulkarm on the West Bank, Binyamin Kahane - leader of an anti-Arab rightwing group - had been ambushed and killed with his wife Thalia by Palestinian gunmen on a road north of Ramallah.

The Kahanes had been on a school run. Five of their six children were injured, one of them, a four-year-old, seriously. Kahane, 33, had served time in jail in Israel for his involvement in militant anti-Arab groups. His father, Rabbi Meir Kahane - founder of the hardline anti-Arab Kach movement - was shot dead in 1990 by an Egyptian-born US citizen in New York.

Israeli police thought it was unlikely the gunmen knew the Kahanes' identity, but rather were bent on firing at any settler's vehicle.

Trouble erupted all over the West Bank in response to the two incidents. Israeli settlers blocked roads and at least eight Palestinians were wounded by the Israeli army near the West Bank towns of Hebron and Bethlehem. As night fell, Palestinians were bracing themselves for more reprisals.

The mayhem could spell the end of a peace process that is already close to collapse. But equally, in the Middle East, violence can signal that compromise is coming: at such moments some elements seek to prevent progress, while others may mount a show of strength to reinforce a bargaining position.

Even before the shootings, Fatah had issued a declaration urging an intensification of the intifada over the next fortnight to mark the start of a year it hoped will bring Palestinian independence. Big rallies are planned for all over the West Bank today to mark the 35th anniversary of the founding of Fatah.

Ziad Abu-Ein, a prominent member of Fatah and an opponent of the peace process, told the Guardian after an emergency meeting of the organisation in Ramallah: "When they assassinated him [Thabet], they assassinated the peace process."

Mr Abu-Ein, who is on the Israeli wanted list and who was jailed for a bombing in 1979, vowed revenge: "This will open up hell for them [the Israelis] because they have assassinated one of the leaders of Fatah."

But while he was declaring the peace process dead, the Palestinians' political leadership set a new deadline of next Monday for a response to US peace proposals, and Mr Arafat held talks yesterday in Tunis and Cairo.

The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, condemned the killing of the Kahanes: "The murderers will not get away with it." The security forces, he said, would "continue to use all means against the perpetrators of the attack".

At the funeral of the Kahanes in Jerusalem, some mourners chanted "Death to Arabs" and some young men attacked the shops of Palestinians.

Settlers' organisations blamed the prime minister for the deaths. The Settlers' Council said in a statement: "We are paying the price for Ehud Barak's campaign for premiership." The election for prime minister is on February 6.

Mr Barak said the Palestinians had two choices: negotiate on the basis of proposals from the US president, Bill Clinton, or see Israel begin work on the forcible separation of Palestine as defined by it.

On the Arab side, the focus has shifted to a meeting of regional leaders in Cairo on Thursday. But a number of Arab countries are reluctant to take responsibility for backing Mr Clinton's plan and the compromises it would entail.

They would prefer to leave the onus of a decison on Mr Arafat, or delay in hopes of a better deal from the incoming US president, George W Bush.

webTitle: Light shed on 300-year mystery of Jupiter's eye

fields.headline: Light shed on 300-year mystery of Jupiter's eye
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: A spacecraft has taken a new look at stormy weather on the giant planet Jupiter and thrown new light on that 300-year-old mystery: Jupiter's great red spot.
fields.body:
A spacecraft has taken a new look at stormy weather on the giant planet Jupiter and thrown new light on that 300-year-old mystery: Jupiter's great red spot.

Cassini - a joint Nasa-European mission on its way to Saturn - swung by Jupiter close enough to "steal" some of the planet's energy of rotation and accelerate its own journey to a rendezvous with Saturn and its moons in 2004. As it dipped to within 6m miles of Jupiter, it captured new images of thunderstorms swirling across the planet's upper atmosphere.

Astronomers have been observing the puzzling red spot for centuries. They now believe it to be a seemingly permanent thunder storm, three times the Earth's diameter, whipped up by 300mph winds.

But Cassini, whose instruments can peer deep into Jupiter's cloud cover, has revealed smaller storms being created and sucked towards the great red spot before being torn apart by the differences in pressure, Andrew Ingersoll of the California Institute of Technology said. The implication is that Jupiter's biggest storms feed their ferocity by absorbing energy from smaller storms, which draw their power from below the clouds in the hot, gaseous planet.

"The weather is different on Jupiter," said Mr Ingersoll. "You have a 300-year-old storm. We'd like to know why Jupiter's weather is so stable and Earth's is so transient."

The Cassini mission is not the only eye on Jupiter. For a few days, scientists have had two spacecraft watching the solar system's biggest planet. Galileo, a mission designed to last only two years, is still in orbit around Jupiter after five years. It dipped to within 1,450 miles of Ganymede, one of Jupiter's moons, to photograph its aurora while it was in its parent's shadow.

Ganymede is the largest moon in the solar system, bigger than the planets Mercury and Pluto. It is the only moon with its own magnetic field, and, like another of Jupiter's moons, Europa, it may have a salt water ocean under its surface.

Liquid water is life's first requirement, so Ganymede could be another possible home for life in the solar system.

US and British scientists are preparing new probes to land on Mars in 2003 to look for evidence of extraterrestrial life (an orbiting spacecraft reported evidence of liquid water there last year) and Nasa engineers are working on an audacious plan to set down a robot on Europa, drill through its ice cap, and lower a midget submarine into its sub-surface ocean.

As Cassini soars towards the rings of Saturn in 2004, it will drop a probe on to the surface of Saturn's moon Titan. The atmosphere of Titan is mostly methane, but Titan, too, has weather patterns of cloud, wind and rain. It could answer questions about the conditions for life on terrestrial planets in a much younger solar system.

webTitle: Feud fear if loyalist leader released

fields.headline: Feud fear if loyalist leader released
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Fears grew yesterday that the impending release of the paramilitary leader Johnny Adair from jail, coupled with a failed murder attempt in Portadown, could reignite a loyalist feud in Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
Fears grew yesterday that the impending release of the paramilitary leader Johnny Adair from jail, coupled with a failed murder attempt in Portadown, could reignite a loyalist feud in Northern Ireland.

The Ulster Volunteer Force and Ulster Freedom Fighters declared a truce a fortnight ago after blood-letting claimed the lives of seven Belfast men and drove hundreds of Shankill Road families from their homes.

But Adair, the UFF Shankill leader re-imprisoned in August by the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, for allegedly orchestrating the conflict, was not party to the talks between paramilitary commanders which led to its resolution.

Mr Mandelson has challenged a preliminary finding by the sentence review commission that Adair should be freed and the commission is due to make its final ruling at a private hearing on Wednesday in Maghaberry prison, Co Antrim, where Adair is being held.

The Northern Ireland Office can appeal against a decision to let Adair out but the appeal would have to be heard the next day and he could be out within 24 hours if this went against the government.

The UVF/UFF ceasefire did not include the renegade Loyalist Volunteer Force, based mainly in Portadown, Co Armagh, in which Adair has close friends.

UVF members were blamed for shooting and injuring a man sitting in a van at a petrol station on on the outskirts of the town, on Saturday. The victim, who received only minor wounds to a finger and a leg, has LVF connections but the intended target is believed to have been another LVF man who was in the area a short time earlier.

Portadown UVF and LVF have old scores to settle, not least the murder of the UVF commander, Richard Jameson, last January at his home just a few miles from the latest shooting.

"Jameson was a big hit and the UVF have not forgotten that," said a loyalist source. "If they succeed in taking out a senior LVF man then Adair's people could tacitly back retaliation and the links are close enough to Belfast that the whole thing could reignite. Either the UVF or LVF could make the first strike."

Renewed violence between loyalists could also have indirect consequences for the overall peace process, stalled because unionists and republicans are in dispute over paramilitary decommissioning, demilitarisation and future policing arrangements.

It would put David Trimble, the first minister of the Northern Ireland assembly who has barred Sinn Fein from cross-border ministerial meetings because of lack of progress on IRA disarmament, under more pressure on two counts.

Within a few weeks, he will face renewed calls from his Ulster Unionist dissidents to withdraw from the power-sharing Stormont government unless the provisionals re-engage seriously with General John de Chastelain's decommissioning body.

Mr Trimble has always called for all paramilitaries to disarm, but republicans will argue there is no onus for them to give up guns which are silent while loyalist weapons remain active.

And confidence in the process will be further shaken if Adair is released. The government pledge to rearrest prisoners freed early under the Good Friday agreement if it believed they were involved in violence was a central plank in persuading moderates to vote for the peace accord.

webTitle: A nation divided by a dome

fields.headline: A nation divided by a dome
fields.standfirst:
After a year of hostility, high costs and targets not met, last day sees a full house
Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: It ended, much as it had begun, with queues on the Jubilee line. Yesterday the Millennium Dome, the dominant British symbol of a troubled and anti-climactic opening to the 21st century, closed to the public and a capacity 27,000 people came to see it for the last time, clogging the magnificent North Greenwich tube station in the process.
fields.body:
It ended, much as it had begun, with queues on the Jubilee line. Yesterday the Millennium Dome, the dominant British symbol of a troubled and anti-climactic opening to the 21st century, closed to the public and a capacity 27,000 people came to see it for the last time, clogging the magnificent North Greenwich tube station in the process.

A year ago to the day, opening night teething problems left hundreds of VIPs - newspaper and television executives, and politicians among them - shivering on the platform at nearby Stratford. The experience left a sour taste in their mouths and the dome battling hostile publicity it has struggled to overcome.

Yesterday's crowds, Cherie Blair and three of her children among them, were far more forgiving, however, and the dome's last house was appreciative, enthusiastic and more than a little sad that the big tent was closing.

Outside the faith zone, the one zone yesterday that did not have a queue, the seven-strong Welch family were happy they had made the effort.

"It's been good, there's so much to see," said Mike Welch, who with his wife had brought three children and two grandchildren along for the day at a cost of £120. "Given that we'll stay for the whole day, it's quite good value. We came along at the last minute because it was the last day, but I think if it was open after today we would come back. There is so much to see."

Mrs Blair, accompanied by her three eldest children, Euan, 16, Nicky, 15, and Kathryn, 12, as well as the dome minister, Lord Falconer, and Alastair Campbell - but not the prime minister, who was at home looking after baby Leo, according to Mr Campbell - said she was sad to see the dome close.

"The children love it here, it is their third time, they think it's great. It is a real shame it's closing," she said, before spotting the dome's own cartoon heroes, Coggsley and Sprinx, the duo who were among Pierre-Yves Gerbeau's first innovations. "I recognise you," she said to Coggsley, not something he can have heard too often.

Away from the official visitors, the timekeepers attraction, a crazy clocktower filled with whirring cogs, tubes and flashing lights that could have been inspired by Salvador Dali, was going down a storm. Hundreds of under-12s, hauling reluctant parents behind them, cheerfully hurled green plastic balls at each other. None looked like they thought the dome had been a waste of money.

The queues for the body zone, the learning zone and the talk zone snaked round the building all day and the live show, acknowledged by friends and critics alike as the dome's one palpable hit, played to a full arena.

In the shop, the last-day sale was crammed with people snapping up rubbers, badges and caps at knockdown prices. One day there may well be a kitsch value to Millennium Dome merchandise. Perhaps the best bargain was the two-for-the-price-of-one deal on dome stress balls, a deal that could have been hatched with chief executive PY Gerbeau and chairman David James in mind. Yesterday lunchtime the pair sat on a terrace overlooking the main arena and spoke of their feelings at the end of an eventful year. They have spoken at least twice a day since Mr James was appointed in September and have formed an unlikely friendship.

"We are an odd couple, an old conservative Englishman and this mad crazy Frenchman," said PY, looking tired after presiding at a party for the 2,000 staff in the dome the previous evening at which Lord Falconer and John Prescott gave speeches.

"It really was very emotional," said Mr James. "I've never been kissed by so many women in my whole life, never mind one night."

"I've got mixed feelings today," said PY. "I'm still trying to get credit for my staff who have stuck with me, worked so hard to make this place a success. When I took over, people were not talking about business deals and finance, they were talking about a failing attraction. We have turned this place round.

"Two numbers killed this place to start with. First was the 12m visitors. If that hadn't been there, this place would be seen as a success from the start. Second was the one year. It is crazy to try and build something and break even in a year.

"If we forget the public relations and the politicians for a moment and concentrate on the positives: we've had 6.5m visitors, we are the second biggest attraction in Europe and almost everyone left happy. That is my idea of a success."

Mr James said the dome had had a positive effect on the area. "As someone who was born less than a mile from here, the dome has brought life back into what was for more than 20 years a derelict, economically extinct area. It needed something spectacular to regenerate Greenwich and that's the dome.

"It's led the way for more than £1bn in private investment in the peninsula and the prospect of 30,000 jobs coming into Greenwich over the next eight years."

A little after 6pm it was all over. After 365 days, £958m, 6.5m visitors (88% of whom went home happy), five additional grants, three chairmen, two chief executives and one failed jewellery robbery, the dome closed its doors, for the time being at least.

At the end of the 999th and final show, greeted by a standing ovation, PY the unlikely hero took the microphone to deliver the final word. With fireworks exploding and ticker-tape falling around him he called to the stage the dome's entire staff, hosts, actors, acrobats and technicians.

After thanking them all he said: "Most of all I would like to thank you, the six and a half million people that made this happen, we love you. Goodnight and a happy new year."

For him at least the dome's promise of one amazing year had lived up to its billing.

webTitle: Kosovo troops tested for cancer from uranium

fields.headline: Kosovo troops tested for cancer from uranium
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Nato armies have started testing soldiers for cancer after a spate of deaths allegedly linked to depleted uranium ammunition used by US pilots in Kosovo.
fields.byline: Rory Carroll  in Rome and  Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
Nato armies have started testing soldiers for cancer after a spate of deaths allegedly linked to depleted uranium ammunition used by US pilots in Kosovo.

Spain, Portugal, France, and Belgium are carrying out health checks on their soldiers who have served in Kosovo to test for traces of radiation as concerns grow in the Netherlands about a "Balkans syndrome".

Italy's military prosecutor, Antonio Intelisano, is examining five deaths that some scientists link to the ammunition used during the 1999 bombing of Kosovo.

Britain is maintaining Nato's official line that no link exists. The Ministry of Defence says it will monitor investigations by Britain's Nato allies but has no plans to tests its soldiers.

In Washington, a Pentagon spokesman said there had been no problems with leukaemia or other illnesses among US troops who had served in the Balkans.

But last week Belgium's defence minister, André Flahaut, called on his European Union counterparts to investigate.

Portugal will send military and scientific experts from the national atomic institute to test radiation levels in Kosovo in the wake of the death from leukaemia of Corporal Hugo Paulino.

Citing "herpes of the brain" as cause of death, the army refused to allow his family to commission a postmortem examination.

Relatives accused Nato of a cover-up over the 31,000 rounds of depleted uranium ammunition used by US A10 ground attack aircraft to pierce Serbian armour. The Pentagon at first refused to say whether uranium shells were used in Kosovo.

Peacekeepers who served in Bosnia were also feared to be at risk as 10,800 such shells were used by Nato in the 1994-95 civil war.

Italian authorities are reportedly investigating the cases of 15 soldiers diagnosed with cancer after returning from the former Yugoslavia.

A military report leaked to La Repubblica newspaper over Christmas admitted that Italian soldiers were dying from leukaemia caused by depleted uranium.

The government resisted calls for Balkan tours of duty to be shortened but agreed to set up a scientific committee. The French, Dutch and Spanish are planning to do likewise.

The Spanish defence ministry says it will examine all 32,000 soldiers who have served in the Balkan region since 1992. A spokesman said none of the tests on 5,000 soldiers screened in recent months had proved positive.

The ministry said all returning troops are routinely given physical examinations, but the new testing is specifically directed at the question of uranium radiation.

The ministry medical chief, Colonel Luis Villalonga, said the tests were designed to calm soldiers' fears. "Spanish troops in Kosovo were deployed in zones where these arms were not used," he said.

Controversy over depleted uranium has raged since battlefields were contaminated during the Gulf war, reportedly causing cancer among Iraqi civilians and allied troops. Symptoms allegedly associated with "Gulf war syndrome" have been recorded in around 5,000 British personnel who served in that campaign.

Though the evidence is inconclusive, exposure to depleted uranium has allegedly been shown to damage the neurological and immune systems and the reproductive organs, and to cause problems that can lead to cancer.

The MoD said it was sticking to advice that depleted uranium's toxicity was dangerous only if ingested. It was safe to touch as its radiation level was no higher than a household smoke alarm.

webTitle: Hopes high as Sweden takes helm of EU

fields.headline: Hopes high as Sweden takes helm of EU
fields.standfirst:
Enlargement top of agenda as Stockholm leads union for first time

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Enlargement top of agenda as Stockholm leads union for first time.
fields.body:
Sweden takes over the EU presidency today, promising to bring a touch of Nordic pragmatism and rigour to some of the toughest challenges facing the union.

Goodwill and expectations are unusually high as Goran Persson, the prime minister, settles into the rotating hot seat after disappointment at France's rocky stewardship, which ended last night to near universal relief.

Sweden joined the club in 1995, and this is the first time it has run the rotating presidency, always a demanding job for any small country but still a golden six-month opportunity to make an impression on union business.

France will be remembered for the Treaty of Nice, an ill-tempered and unambitious affair that just about agreed the long-overdue institutional reforms needed to allow the EU to take in up to 13 new members in the coming years.

Enlargement is Mr Persson's biggest priority, not only because success is central to the future of the entire EU, but also because leading candidates such as Poland, Estonia and Latvia are situated in Sweden's own Baltic backyard.

And closely linked to this issue is the thorny question of relations with Russia and Ukraine, which will become the union's immediate neighbours when the first newcomers join.

"I find it hard to think that anything is more important for the enlargement process than that we have a good relationship between the EU and Russia," Mr Persson said recently.

The Swedish social democrat wants to quicken the glacial pace of negotiations and may even set a date for the first accessions, which France repeatedly refused to do.

But with concern growing in Germany and elsewhere about the cost of the project, and some of the toughest issues such as agriculture and aid funds still looming, it remains to be seen how much progress can actually be made.

Mr Persson has big ideas on the environment and employment. In Brussels, the Swedish environment commissioner, Margot Wallstrom, has established solid "green" credentials and the Gothenburg summit in June will be devoted to sustainable development.

Sweden also wants to use its presidency to help salvage a deal on climate change, after the collapse of the Hague conference over huge differences between the EU and US.

In March, at the Stockholm summit, leaders will review progress made since ambitious targets for social and employment policy were set in Lisbon last year.

Not surprisingly, the country that is the home to the telecoms giant Ericsson will be pushing for better opportunities to exploit new technologies and bring Europe up to enviable US levels of growth and job generation.

Transparency is a key concern - Sweden's instinctive openness has often brought clashes with more secretive member states. Its presidency website is already a model of clarity and accessibility.

Exuding probity and Scandinavian values, Mr Persson has pledged to work for a union "characterised by cost efficiency and budget restrictiveness" as well as "mainstreaming" gender equality - the theme of a ministerial strategy session later this month.

Other challenges include the difficult defence dossier, currently stuck on the crucial question of relations between the EU's nascent rapid reaction force and Nato, and specific difficulties with France and Turkey. As Sweden is a long-standing neutral which sat out the cold war, this is an especially intriguing and delicate mission.

Further afield, the crisis in the Middle East will be a test for Stockholm's ability to represent the union on the world stage, and an important time for the foreign policy supremo, Javier Solana, repeatedly upstaged by France.

North Korea, emerging from its long years as the Stalinist hermit kingdom, will be a preoccupation.

More widely, President George W Bush will be less of an enigma by the time Mr Persson greets him at the EU-US summit in June.

"Assuming the presidency for the first time is a proud moment for relative newcomers to the EU scene," commented the Brussels European Voice, widely read by Eurocrats. "It will be up to Sweden to restore faith in the current system and show that it can work in the way that it should."

Mr Persson has got that message loud and clear. "The EU is not only talk," he declared. "But it is also hard facts, delivery, a practical approach... about politics that make a difference and change the daily lives of citizens."

 The former German chancellor Helmut Schmidt said in an interview published yesterday that the EU had achieved very little over the past decade, and criticised its expansion plans.

"With the sole exception of the euro, it has achieved nothing in the last 10 years," Mr Schmidt, 82, told the Tagesspiegel daily.

As Social Democrat chancellor from 1974 to 1982, Mr Schmidt, in partnership with French president Valéry Giscard D'Estaing, helped forge the Exchange Rate Mechanism - the forerunner to European monetary union.

But in the outspoken interview, Mr Schmidt criticised the EU's latest steps aimed at accepting new members.

"The more members join, the harder it will be to change... Expectations are developing too quickly, internal rules too slowly," he warned.

Snow and scepticism

 Euroscepticism in Sweden is as familiar as crispbread, with a survey last month showing that only 37%of Swedes support membership, let alone deeper integration.

Polls show far greater support for enlargement.

 Public feeling against joining the single currency has hardened since Denmark rejected the euro in September. A recent poll showed that 62% of Swedes do not want to scrap the krone.

 Analysts say one reason for the anti-euro sentiment is confidence that Sweden has emerged leaner and fitter from a recession and does not want the shelter or the straitjacket of the single currency.

 The Swedish government, which backs euro membership "in principle", has pledged to hold a referendum on the euro, though it has not fixed a date.

 Swedes are sensitive to the EU's reputation for secrecy, and paid close attention to a fraud scandal at the European commission's Stockholm office last year.

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: • Fresh evidence that Jonathan Aitken, the disgraced former Tory cabinet minister, lied in his early career as a journalist over a classified report which appeared in the Sunday Telegraph can be found in the official papers.
fields.body:
 Fresh evidence that Jonathan Aitken, the disgraced former Tory cabinet minister, lied in his early career as a journalist over a classified report which appeared in the Sunday Telegraph can be found in the official papers.

Papers refer to a report passed on to Aitken at a dinner by General Henry Alexander, a former member of the international observer team monitoring the Nigerian civil war.

The prime minister, Edward Heath, was told: "General Alexander gave the report to Aitken stressing its confidential nature and asking that it should be returned the next day. General Alexander noticed that the staple appeared to have been removed and refastened. When asked about this, Aitken denied that he had taken copies."

 Imelda Marcos, the wife of Philippines dictator Ferdinand Marcos, drove British officials to distraction on a private visit. Diplomats complained that the tactics of Mrs Marcos - famous for her fearsome temper as well as her countless pairs of shoes - in securing an audience with the Queen had been tantamount to "blackmail".

Nevertheless, with the government anxious to promote good relations with the Philippines, diplomats were obliged to do everything they could to make her visit a success.

 Harold Wilson was keen to limit the international traffic in weapons, especially small arms but the Foreign Office and Denis Healey, defence secretary in the 1966-70 Labour governments, were less impressed. The Foreign Office said: "The supply of arms and military equipment is one of the most powerful weapons in international diplomacy. " Mr Healey responded: "I see no objection to pursuing studies in slow time".

The papers provide an insight into Labour's reasons for backing the US during the Vietnam war. If the government failed to support the US, Michael Stewart, the foreign secretary, told Wilson, it "could be expected to have profound consequences in terms of our relationship with the American administration which could... extend to all fields of Anglo-US relations".

webTitle: Leader: Overture and beginners

fields.headline: Overture and beginners
fields.standfirst:
Election 2001: all we need now is the date
Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Election 2001: all we need now is the date.
fields.body:
Some fancy April, some June. But the general expectation in politics is that Tony Blair will choose Thursday May 3 as the day he asks the country to give him a second term. He will do so in a climate greatly changed by events last year, a year which saw a kind of bonfire of the illusions. Remember when the Millennium Dome was going to be the first paragraph in Labour's next manifesto? You can see the change in the detail of the polls, which tells us so much more than the simple party ratings. You can see it too in the lines on Mr Blair's face.

Those early years seem now like a dream. Here was a new kind of politics, produced by a new kind of politician: one impatient of party dogma, even of the party he led. Here was a leader charmingly eager to please, as if set on wholly precluding the need to insist on tough and divisive measures. The year 2000 put much of this illusion to sleep.

The image of a leader above mere politics, already eroded, collapsed with a spectacular crash in the autumn, as the government bravely and rightly refused to yield to the farmers and hauliers, despite the huge public support that they won. The brief Tory lead in the polls thereafter soon melted away. But the sense that Blair and Labour were mortal did not.

A Mori poll in the Times last week found that roughly a third of electors thought Labour had made things better; about a third thought it had made things worse. The other third saw no conspicuous difference either way. It is against that backdrop that the 2001 campaign will be fought. We plan in this space this week to examine the party battlegrounds on the economy, on social policy and on Britain's place in the world.

The parties' own priorities are clearly established in their leaders' new year messages. Labour will parade itself as the party of competent economic management - reviving memories of the Tory fiasco which culminated in Black Wednesday - and as champions of the public services, especially health, education, transport and law and order. Its record of achievement here falls short of what many voters hoped for, and expected, four years ago.

Because the first two years were devoted to establishing an image of prudence and rectitude, the necessary big-spending assault on public squalor in a time of private affluence was too long postponed. Now electors will be asked to invest in the promise of progress rather than the results. Labour may be vulnerable here: its opponents will be armed with persuasive evidence that spending promises do not always produce their predicted outcomes. The dome will often be cited.

Yet here, as elsewhere across the territory, Labour has one ever-dependable ally: the Conservative party. William Hague purports to believe his party could yet win in May by majoring on tax cuts, Europe and crime. On tax, he continues to back the familiar assumption, to which Labour itself subscribed far too readily last time round, that however much people say they put better public services first, what they really want is fat tax cuts. This is one of the morals he draws from George W Bush's victory in the US elections - a reward, he argues, for Bush's commitments to bigger tax cuts and smaller government.

But that too may belong to the politics of illusion. People often say they want less government action and interference - yet when things go wrong they clamour for more. They may feel that public spending is too often wasteful: but they also sense that a party which pledges itself to spend as generously as Labour on essential public services, yet simultaneously promises substantial cuts in taxation, is no more to be trusted with the conduct of the economy than Norman Lamont. Mr Hague ought also to note that Al Gore took a higher share of the US popular vote than Governor Bush.

There is a second, more specific reason why the coming election might be just as much about the Conservatives as about Labour. The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, made much of it in his new year address. One reason why Mr Blair won a landslide on the basis of a quite modest share of the vote was tactical voting: the readiness of natural Labour and Lib Dem supporters to switch sides in places where they perceived that this was the best available means to oust a Tory. With Labour in government the big united impetus to get the Tories out which fired the 1997 result no longer applies.

Yet the course on which Mr Hague has set his party ought to ensure that the impulse for tactical voting against the Tories is still very much alive. In his early days he oscillated between two imperatives: that of winning back millions of former supporters who had drifted away, often in search of a party more strongly anti-European than was John Major's; and that of re-establishing the Conservatives as the kind of tolerant, open-minded, pragmatic party the middle ground likes. He has now bet the lot on the first of those options and the price of that choice is written all over the polls.

Thousands of voters have shed their earlier illusions about Tony Blair and New Labour. They no longer expect him to smile and do as they wish. But their confidence in the Tory alternative has barely increased. We no longer very much trust, let alone love, New Labour, they tell the pollsters: but we trust and like the Conservatives very much less. That is the judgment which Mr Hague and his fractious forces now have to reverse. Most people expect him to fail: they only ask by how much. In his heart of hearts, he probably feels much the same. Most of his senior colleagues, enmeshed in their restless doctrinal and personal feuds, all too clearly do so.

webTitle: G2: Leicester's multicultural success

fields.headline: Side by side
fields.standfirst:
In the 70s, Leicester council did everything it could to keep out thousands of Asians fleeing Uganda. But they came anyway - and it will soon be the first British city with a white minority. Esther Addley reports

Special report: what is Britain?
fields.trailText: In the 70s, Leicester council did everything it could to keep out thousands of Asians fleeing Uganda. But they came anyway - and it will soon be the first British city with a white minority. Esther Addley reports.
fields.body:
On September 15 1972, an "important announcement" appeared in the pages of the Ugandan Argus newspaper in east Africa. The announcement was financed by the ratepayers of the city of Leicester, England. "The City Council of Leicester, England, believes that many families in Uganda are considering moving to Leicester," the notice read. Its advice was straightforward: don't. Thousands of families were already waiting on the council's housing list, schools were full to bursting, social services were stretched to the limit ... "In your own interests and those of your family you should ... not come to Leicester."

For Uganda's Asian population, in the process of being expelled from their country by Idi Amin, it wasn't much of a welcome. But Leicester's city council believed urgent measures were needed. More than 10,000 Indians and east Africans of Asian descent had already settled in the area, and were now highly likely to encourage their relatives in Uganda - most of whom held British passports - to join them. The council panicked. A delegation was sent to the home secretary, Robert Carr, urging him to find homes for the Ugandan Asians - but not in Leicester.

Despite the best efforts of the city council, however, the Ugandans did come. And today, thanks in part to that influx, Leicester - a small, unassuming east Midlands city - is predicted to be Britain's first black majority city. The city council estimates that with Asian and black children already making up more than 50% of the school population, white people will be an ethnic minority in Leicester within a decade.

"It's wonderful, isn't it?" says the high sheriff of Leicestershire, Anthony Wessel. "I'm very proud of Leicester and its multicultural facets, the fact that there are so many people living side by side. You get a great buzz from it." A recent document published by Leicester city council speaks of "the joy of being a truly diverse city" - the same council that warned, in an emergency meeting in August 1972 , that "the entire fabric of our city is at risk" from immigrants.

But a revolution seems to have taken place. Steadily, and almost entirely without fanfare, Leicester seems to have become Britain's most ethnically harmonious city. "The relationship between the communities is wonderful," says Asaf Hussain, a lecturer in multi-culturalism at the university of Leicester. "I'm not just talking between the English and the Asians. I'm talking Hindus and Muslims as well."

If this story of unalloyed harmony sounds improbable, it is difficult to find anyone on the streets of Leicester who will disagree with it. "It's just crept up on us over the past 30 years," says Jean Smith, 58. The hosiery factory where she works is now Asian-owned, and most of her colleagues are Asian. "Everyone is really nice. It doesn't matter, does it? They respect our way of life and we respect theirs."

Sanjay Bulsara, a 29-year-old firefighter, did have a bit of trouble at school, when he was the only Asian person in his year. "But it only happened for about six months or so, and I haven't experienced any problems at all since then." Fifteen-year-old Martin, who is black, is out shopping with three white schoolfriends. He has never heard of any of his friends having problems either. "I don't know why it's like that here," he says, "because you do hear about problems in other places, don't you?"

Despite the fierce affection the city inspires in its residents, it is probably fair to say that Leicester never knocked anyone flat by sheer force of civic charisma. It has a prettyish city centre, at least compared to many cities in the Midlands; a couple of fine medieval buildings survive, including the city's ancient south gate, now unpardonably lassoed by a dual carriageway. The centre feels prosperous and comfortable. Leicester is relaxed with itself. There is little sense, for better or worse, of the edgy energy of Coventry or Birmingham or Manchester. Even the city's motto is testament to its unassuming steadiness: semper eadem. Always the same.

The first black immigrants arrived from the Caribbean after the war, to be followed, in the late 60s, by increasing numbers of people from east Africa. Industry may have been the initial draw, particularly since it offered plentiful employment to women as well as men - or it may simply be that the first settlers in Leicester liked what they saw, and encouraged their families to follow.

Either way, the city's charms proved irresistible. What sweetened the pill for the white population was that most of these people were middle class, often bringing capital with them. They were experienced businesspeople, and well practised at blending in. Unlike the mostly Urdu-speaking Muslim population of cities like Bradford, Leicester's Gujarati and Punjabi Asian population were on the second leg of their long journey from the Indian subcontinent. They had already developed strategies for integrating, as a minority ethnic culture, into an alien society.

Resham Sandhu, a Sikh community leader and chairman of Leicester's council of faiths, was one of those who arrived in the early 70s. "I think from the very beginning when people started coming to Leicester, there were people who were looking to make the city into one society, not just a city of sections, and they have been working very hard since then."

Gurharpal Singh, a professor of Indian politics at the University of Hull and the author of a book on Asian Leicester, agrees. "One of the factors is that in the 1980s the young Labour party leadership was very dynamic in pushing forward an agenda of equality, because they had lived through the racism of the 70s. The result, after 30 years, is a city with ethnic minority representation at the highest level. Leicester has an Asian MP, Keith Vaz, and has had Asians as deputy chief of police, chief executive of the city council, lord mayor and deputy to the lord lieutenant. Almost a third of the city's councillors are non-white.

It is a beguiling utopian vision, but one which, inevitably, is rather simplified. "There is a tendency to overstate the model community," says Singh. "The people managing multiculturalism in Leicester have a vested interest in portraying it as harmonious. But in so doing they often neglect the disenchantment and lower achievement among working-class groups." Certainly on the (still mainly white) housing estates to the west and north, one doesn't need to look too hard to find unreconstructed prejudice. "I'm not racist, but this is a white man's country," says one community leader from the Stocking Farm estate. "Most people here can't stand the idea of there being more of them, because there's already so many of them, and they have sectioned the city anyway."

webTitle: Big chill hits holiday games again

fields.headline: Big chill hits holiday games again
fields.standfirst: Click here to follow the games that are still on
fields.trailText: The big chill continues into 2001, leaving today's sporting programme at its mercy. With further snow expected overnight, football, racing, rugby union and rugby league are again facing severe disruption.
fields.body:
The big chill continues into 2001, leaving today's sporting programme at its mercy. With further snow expected overnight, football, racing, rugby union and rugby league are again facing severe disruption.

Last night all 10 New Year's Day Premiership fixtures were still intact but Leicester City announced a 9am inspection of Filbert Street and the immediate area before the game with Bradford City. Other inspections, at Premiership and Nationwide League grounds, are inevitable with the weather deteriorating in some areas.

A Leicester spokesman said last night that the game could not have gone on yesterday "because we could not guarantee the safety of supporters.

"It was decided to defer the decision to see if the temperatures rise in the next few hours and maybe lead to an improvement in conditions."

Charlton are confident the match with Arsenal at the Valley will go ahead. Staff cleared snow off the pitch yesterday and the surface was playable. "Unless there is an unexpected serious deterioration in the weather overnight we will have no problems," said a Charlton spokesman.

But by last night nine Nationwide games had been called off. The First Division matches at Crystal Palace and Crewe were postponed because of frozen pitches and there will be a 10.30am inspection at West Bromwich, with the immediate area of the Hawthorns the problem..

In the Second Division, the games at Port Vale and Colchester are off, likewise at Darlington Halifax, Hull, Leyton Orient and York in the Third, with an 8am inspection scheduled at Brighton and a 9am check at Mansfield.

In Scotland, only Celtic have a pitch inspection planned before tomorrow's programme. But there are concerns for all Scottish Premier games, with waterlogged pitches, not freezing conditions, the major threat. Rain is forecast in Scotland today. "The problem you then get is waterlogged pitches and grounds turning to mush," said the SPL fixtures supervisor Ian Blair.

In rugby union, yesterday's Premiership match between Newcastle and Harlequins was called off, and today's Bristol v Gloucester match has also been postponed.

In rugby league's Premiership today, Keighley v Hull KR is a weather victim.

Today's race meetings at Cheltenham, Catterick and Leicester are all off but hopes are high that jumps racing can go ahead at Exeter and Plumpton, though Plumpton will hold a 7.15am inspection. The all-weather card at Southwell will go ahead barring a thick snow covering this morning.

webTitle: UK news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: The Archbishop of Canterbury, George Carey, warned that humanity was "pushing our planet to the point of no return" in his New Year message yesterday.
fields.body:
Archbishop's green message

The Archbishop of Canterbury, George Carey, warned that humanity was "pushing our planet to the point of no return" in his New Year message yesterday. He said: "It is dawning on us that the life of our world is as vulnerable as the children we raise."

Express train driver hurt

A Virgin train driver was recovering in hospital yesterday after he was showered with glass when an object hit the windscreen of his express as it travelled at 90mph near Lockerbie, in Dumfries and Galloway. No passengers were hurt.

Study reveals age old problem

A study of suicide in medieval England, published in the British Journal of Psychology, has revealed a trend still prevalent today: more men kill themselves than women. The study examined records of an inquiry dating from the 12th to early 14th centuries.

Eclipse to take bite out of moon

A partial lunar eclipse will appear to take a bite out of the moon as it passes through the earth's shadow from 6.42pm on January 9.

Two share top lottery prize

Two tickets shared Saturday's £6.7m national lottery jackpot, matching the numbers 1, 7, 16, 18, 38, and 47. The bonus number was 10. The Thunderball numbers were 16, 19, 25, 29 and 32 and the Thunderball was 2.

webTitle: Previous convictions may be revealed to juries

fields.headline: Previous convictions may be revealed to juries
fields.trailText: Juries could be given details of defendants' previous convictions under plans being drawn up by the government to crack down on persistent offenders.
fields.body:
Juries could be given details of defendants' previous convictions under plans being drawn up by the government to crack down on persistent offenders.

Jack Straw, the home secretary, is said to be in favour of the change, which is likely to be one of the main recommendations in a review of criminal courts.

The police have long argued that defendants' right not to disclose their criminal records tipped the scales of justice in favour of the accused.

In all but the most exceptional cases, courts go to great lengths to avoid mention of previous convictions. However, last September previous accusations were used to help jail a rapist who had been acquitted on earlier charges.

Lawyers and civil rights groups reacted angrily yesterday to the proposed change, saying that it would undermine the fundamental presumption of innocence. The Bar Council, which represents barristers in England and Wales, said the "alarming" move could prove "extremely dangerous". Along with plans to limit the right to trial by jury, it could see innocent people convicted on the grounds they were "roughly, probably, or even maybe guilty", a spokesman said.

Deborah Clark, of the campaign group Liberty, said: "By giving details of previous convictions there is a danger people will be found guilty of offences for which enough evidence does not exist."

Under the proposals, the previous convictions of a defendant would not be disclosed automatically. The trial judge would make a ruling after hearing submissions from the prosecution and the defence.

The change, which is likely to be recommended in Lord Justice Auld's review of the criminal courts, will delight the police. In its submission to the Auld review, the Association of Chief Police Officers gave an example of a persistent thief to highlight the need for change.

Sir David Phillips, the chief constable of Kent and chairman of Acpo's policing committee, said that a man walked free after being charged with stealing three cars on the same day. His lawyers successfully argued that each should be tried separately to ensure that none of the cases was prejudiced. At each hearing the man successfully used the same defence, claiming that his fingerprints were found in each car because a stranger had offered him a lift.

Simon Hughes, the Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, said the plans amounted to "yet another brick out of the wall of the criminal justice system ... It is bad enough being determined to get rid of the right to choose jury trial in England and Wales and regularly wanting to adjust the burden of proof in criminal cases."

webTitle: Comment: Monarchy makes fools of us all

fields.headline: Monarchy makes fools of us all
fields.standfirst:
And a happy new year to the Princess Royal. Go for it, Anne

Special report: future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: And a happy new year to the Princess Royal. Go for it, Anne.
fields.body:
We had a traditional Christmas. The pilot light went out in the boiler. My mother was bad-tempered. The giblets made the dog sick. Sheffield Wednesday lost. But one unexpected incident shone more brightly than the star in the east.

Princess Anne's behaviour immediately after she had celebrated the birth of the Prince of Peace made it the most memorable season of goodwill for years. I offer her royal highness my humble congratulations and hope it is not lese-majeste on my part to add: "Keep it up, Ma'am. Keep it up."

Endpiece readers may not be familiar with what happened outside Sandringham Church - and may find the details of the story difficult to believe even when they hear them. But they were reported in the tabloid newspapers and are therefore beyond dispute. A 75-year-old lady called Mrs Halfpenny made a basket - plaiting the wicker with her own hands - and filled it with flowers. She then travelled half the length of the country in the hope of presenting it to the Queen Mother as the royal family left the Christmas Day morning service. As the object of her affection was absent she handed her gift to one of the royal princelings in the hope that it would be passed on. On hearing these details, Princess Anne observed: "What a ridiculous thing to do."

The only serious complaint that can be made about the Princess Royal's behaviour is that her understatement did less than full justice to the absurdity of Mrs Halfpenny's conduct. I suspect that somewhere in Windsor castle there is a room full of home-made wicker baskets which an under-footman will be commanded to destroy on an appropriately discreet occasion. Perhaps that is how the fire started seven years ago.

However, we can be pretty sure that at least Mrs Halfpenny has learned the idiocy of her ways. She confessed that she was so anguished by Princess Anne's reproof that she had totally "lost faith in people". Her hopes for mankind were completely extinguished by the royal suggestion that her basketwork and flower arrangements were a waste of time.

I am anxious not to add to Mrs Halfpenny's trauma, but the only plausible excuse for her conduct is the undoubted fact that proximity to a member of the royal family makes normally sensible people do and say silly things. And - since she clearly believes that the Queen Mother is sanctified - that explanation may only increase her distress.

So I simply say in mitigation of her madness that her sort of lunacy is encouraged by newspapers which write about the Windsors with what can only be described as intrusive reverence. The Halfpenny incident provided a perfect example.

Editors who thought it necessary to defend Princess Anne against the allegation that she had spoken the truth, offered the excuse that her normally equitable temper had been disturbed by concern about her daughter's health.

Apparently Zara Phillips sustained superficial cuts and bruises in a motor accident which occurred about a week before Basketgate. The notion that prolonged maternal anxiety induced Princess Anne's impatience with an elderly sycophant is difficult to sustain. However, a couple of weeks ago we were subject to an even better example of the absurd way in which newspapers treat the royal family.

The same Zara Phillips had another accident. She fell down while playing hockey. Little as I know about the game, I suspect that falling down is quite a common occurrence. But Ms Phillips's tumble became national news. And the trip or stumble was not the most sensational part of the story.

What amazed the royal correspondents was the way in which the Queen's athletic granddaughter got to her feet and resumed the game as if she was a hockey-playing commoner. The sensational news that Ms Phillips sometimes behaves normally was no more than the approach march to the main assault on our intelligence. The blitzkrieg of banality was the carefully managed photo opportunity of Prince William behaving naturally in Patagonia.

No doubt Mrs Halfpenny thrilled to the spirit of the heir to the throne (once removed) cleaning out lavatories. I just regret that a country which pretends to be grown-up salivates over such trivia. One of the most cogent arguments for a republic is that the existence of a monarchy encourages us to do and say silly things. Happy new year, Princess Anne.

The notion that prolonged maternal anxiety induced Princess Anne's impatience with an elderly sycophant is difficult to sustain. However, a couple of weeks ago we were subject to an even better example of the absurd way in which newspapers treat the royal family. The same Zara Phillips had another accident. She fell down while playing hockey. Little as I know about the game, I suspect that falling down is quite a common occurrence. But Ms Phillips's tumble became national news. And the trip or stumble was not the most sensational part of the story. What amazed the royal correspondents was the way in which the Queen's athletic granddaughter got to her feet and resumed the game as if she was a hockey-playing commoner. The sensational news that Ms Phillips sometimes behaves normally was no more than the approach march to the main assault on our intelligence. The blitzkrieg of banality was the carefully managed photo opportunity of Prince William behaving naturally in Patagonia. No doubt Mrs Halfpenny thrilled to the spirit of the heir to the throne (once removed) cleaning out lavatories. I just regret that a country which pretends to be grown-up salivates over such trivia. One of the most cogent arguments for a republic is that the existence of a monarchy encourages us to do and say silly things. Happy new year, Princess Anne. comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Woman hounded after child dies

fields.headline: Woman hounded after child dies
fields.trailText: A woman, bailed in connection with the death of a two-year-old boy, had to climb on to the roof of her home to escape an angry mob early yesterday.
fields.body:
A woman, bailed in connection with the death of a two-year-old boy, had to climb on to the roof of her home to escape an angry mob early yesterday.

In freezing temperatures, she huddled on top of the five storey block of flats in St Leonards, East Sussex, for about an hour as a gang of men and women hurled abuse at her from the street. Firefighters used a turntable ladder to rescue her.

The woman, 21, and a man, 25, had been released on bail late on Friday night after being questioned over the discovery of the body of a child the day before. Police forced their way into the flat, after a neighbour called them, and found the boy in his cot. He had been dead for around two weeks.

After the woman was rescued, police returned to disperse a group outside the flat. A local man, 26, was arrested and charged with public order offences.

Inspector Steve Brookman said: "It seems there was a disturbance in the road, and the woman felt she needed to get away from it by climbing on to the roof."

A postmortem examination on the child proved inconclusive, and a second autopsy and further tests are being carried out. Scene of crime officers are examining items from the flat, and detectives hope to speak to relatives of the couple to uncover the background to the case.

A police spokesman said: "It is a very sad case...It was a gruesome discovery for the officers who went into the flat, and counselling will be available to them if necessary."

A team of detectives is working on the case from an incident room at Hastings police station.

webTitle: Israel rejects plan for world court

fields.headline: Israel rejects plan for world court
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel has decided against signing a treaty establishing the first permanent global criminal court, an accord under which Jewish settlement on occupied lands could be viewed as a war crime.
fields.body:
Israel has decided against signing a treaty establishing the first permanent global criminal court, an accord under which Jewish settlement on occupied lands could be viewed as a war crime.

"I think it is perhaps a historic mistake that we are making today," said Rabbi Michael Melchior, Israel's minister of diaspora affairs, after the cabinet voted down the treaty yesterday, hours ahead of a deadline for countries to sign.

"We are putting a stain on ourselves, in the eyes of the world, by not wanting to join," he told Israel Radio.

The US was also holding out until the last minute, and the radio said Israel would immediately reconsider its refusal if Washington decides to sign.

The international criminal court, based on principles similar to those of the Nazi war crimes trials at the end of the second world war, would try individuals accused of the most heinous atrocities - mass murders, war crimes and other gross human rights violations. It would be based in the Netherlands.

Mr Melchior said opposition centred on a provision in the treaty which defines as a war crime "the transfer, directly or indirectly, by the occupying power of parts of its own civilian population into territories it occupies".

Legal experts have said the clause would go beyond existing international conventions that term Israeli settlements on occupied land illegal, and could make Israeli leaders indictable before the court.

Some 200,000 Israelis live in about 145 settlements in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, land Israel occupied in the 1967 Middle East war and territory which the Palestinians are seeking for a future state.

Bill Clinton has come under strong pressure from the Pentagon not to sign until Washington gets airtight guarantees that no US serviceman or other government official abroad would be subject to the court's jurisdiction.

Leading Republicans in Congress have mounted a drive against the treaty, seeking at the minimum a strong role for the UN security council, in which the US has a veto.

The tribunal comes into force when 60 countries have ratified the treaty. So far 136 countries have signed it and 27 have ratified it.

From today a country can only ratify and no longer just sign the treaty, which means it will lose influence during negotiations on the court's procedures.

webTitle: Comment: Gongs a-gogo

fields.headline: Gongs a-gogo
fields.standfirst:
The honours system reassures us that there is a reward for all. Not just lollipop ladies, but arms dealers too

Special report: future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The honours system reassures us that there is a reward for all. Not just lollipop ladies, but arms dealers too.
fields.body:
Free gifts: they're a grand, if unpredictable, thing. The last one I received was posted in a lovely silver envelope and involved several informative leaflets and a small tube of lotion intended to fight the effects of male pattern baldness. Sadly, as I don't even suffer from female pattern baldness, this generous gesture was entirely pointless.

And this is the season of free gifts. I don't mean all that emotionally booby-trapped Christmas nonsense: the duty giving, the pre-emptive appreciation of hoped-for sexual favours, the tears before bedtime and batteries not included. No, I mean the really important free gifts - the new year's honours list. Apart from the delight which suffuses the heart on hearing of a discredited politician's translation to the unelected house, or discovering that a new bevy of thrusting industrialists can add a few letters to the tail end of their names, the honours list enumerates gifts which keep on giving to every British citizen. Because they allow us to remember the fundamental truths upon which our happy society rests.

They remind us that there is a place for everyone. The lollipop lady who saves generations of toddlers from being mown down into squealing paste will always receive an MBE, the company chairman who cheerfully siphons pension funds into offshore accounts and asset-strips the livelihoods of thousands will always receive a knighthood.

This is the way things are meant to be: plucky country postmen and dog rescuers will get brisk handshakes and frankly rather tasteless little gongs: arms dealers, insider-traders and non-executive directors will bask in the hero's welcome they deserve. After all, it's difficult to win friends and influence people when you spend your days distantly overseeing the manufacture of electric shock batons. Children's hospice nurses and other do-gooders have it easy: they meet automatic respect on every side (with the exception of the Treasury). Individuals universally regarded as "rich, selfish bastards" need all the help they can get.

Alongside this superficial demonstration of nature's order we find more valuable lessons. Honours are primarily doled out at the whim of parliament and the prime minister: people who describe each other as Honourable and Right Honourable, simply because they are employed in government positions, doled out at the whim of the electorate who are not described as Honourable or Right Honourable.

When we consider the dishonourable behaviour of so many parliamentarians we learn that Britain's gloriously invisible constitution is based upon a faith in the honour of those occupying high office, a faith rendered touching because it is entirely unjustified.

The actual doling out of honours is left to royalty, members of the aristocracy representing the inherited tenacity of British honour. We know that nobility of all shades can trace its possession of honour back to upliftingly historical acts of theft, corruption, homicide, political manoeuvring and sexual malpractice. This knowledge not only allows the British public to practise generosity and forgiveness, it also encourages the patterns of thinking usually associated with artistic expression and genius. When we think of honour in Britain we cannot help but hold two equal and conflicting ideas simultaneously. No wonder we are an island of inventors and innovators.

The royal family, as the apotheosis of undeserved honour, should encourage these traits, but modern innovations and a cramped gene pool have undermined their ability to inspire. The royals are currently condemned to a life of closely observed inbreeding, crucified romance, public speaking and costume jewellery. The marital exploits of a psychopathic predecessor have left them in charge of a national religion, while their natural proclivities run towards adultery and the killing of various animals. Meanwhile, law and custom prevent the vast majority of human beings from marrying in to help them out.

This brings us an uninspiring glimpse of natural justice - the royal family have honour and wealth at our expense, but suffer accordingly. Princess Anne and Prince Philip do their best to upset this doleful balance, but more action is needed. The Windsors must be publicly funded, untaxed, given the power of life and death and a restored divine right - only then can they flourish, unburdened by responsibility and unrestrained by criminal law, as the embodiment of a very British honour.

webTitle: St Lucia worshippers set afire

fields.headline: St Lucia worshippers set afire
fields.trailText: Men with machetes stormed a Roman Catholic cathedral during Mass on the Caribbean island of St Lucia yesterday, hacked at worshippers and set them ablaze, killing a nun and injuring at least 12 others.
fields.body:
Men with machetes stormed a Roman Catholic cathedral during Mass on the Caribbean island of St Lucia yesterday, hacked at worshippers and set them ablaze, killing a nun and injuring at least 12 others.

Police identified the nun who died as Sister Theresa Egan, 72, of Ireland. It was not immediately clear how she died, and authorities did not give her home town.

More than 400 people had attended Mass at the cathedral in the capital, Castries, and many were lined up in the aisles to receive Holy Communion when the attackers entered the church, according to police.

Three of the men escaped, but people from the congregation pounced on one of the intruders and held him until the police arrived.

The motive for the attack was not immediately clear. Police were questioning the man they arrested, 20-year-old Kim John, and were searching for the three other suspects.

Cletus Springer, a worshipper and newspaper columnist, said: "The church was in flames. I saw four men methodically going around setting people on fire, chopping people. It was like a scene from hell."

One of the men doused people with a flammable liquid. Another then used a blowtorch to ignite the liquid, witnesses said.

The men set fire to the priest, Father Charles Gaillard, who was in hospital in a serious condition last night. At least 12 other people were also in hospital being treated, the authorities said.

webTitle: Giving a voice to unsung good causes

fields.headline: Giving a voice to unsung good causes
fields.standfirst:
Our Christmas appeal highlights the work of charities without high profiles or much money. Here the editor of the Guardian explains why they deserve your support
Special report: Christmas appeal 2000
fields.trailText: Our Christmas appeal highlights the work of charities without high profiles or much money. Here the editor of the Guardian explains why they deserve your support.
fields.body:
One of the great things about the Guardian is that it has never been afraid to espouse unfashionable causes. It is part of the reason we work here, and we like to think it is part of the reason you buy what we produce.

It should come as no surprise, then, that the charities we select as partners for our Christmas appeal tend not to fit the usual mould for media "good causes". Under-resourced and under-recognised, they toil at the coalface of issues that society would very often choose not to dwell on.

A salutary reminder of this, and of the unglamorous - indeed, morally ambiguous - nature of much charity work, was brought home to us all this year by the case of the so-called Cambridge Two, Ruth Wyner and John Brock, who were jailed for turning a blind eye to the peddling of drugs at the Wintercomfort day centre for homeless people where they worked.

Last month the pair lost an appeal to clear their names. Their immediate response was not one of self pity (though having served 207 days in prison, they could have been forgiven that) but one of concern for all others working with homeless drug addicts.

"These are doing the most difficult job with some of the most difficult people. I don't think they need this," said Ms Wyner.

Not for this kind of charity work is there the glitz of £100 a plate fundraisers at top London hotels, the heart-tugging appeal of a telethon or the financial security of corporate sponsorship. Nor, very often, is there the big name patron.

The Queen, the biggest name in patrons, is on the letterheads of some 250 charities; Prince Charles on those of almost 100. Matthew Smith, of the charity information company CaritasData, which collates such figures, said recently: "Work in the charity sector is all about influence. If you have influence, you can gain an edge over the next person."

What the Guardian Christmas appeal is about is, in a small way, helping to counter that. Our four charities do not have much edge and do not have much money. But they do have a determination to tackle some of the most pressing social and environmental problems, in this country and overseas, and in our judgment they are doing so effectively and efficiently.

Over the past few weeks, we have reported on the work of our charities. We have told how Refuge rescued Catherine, a mother of four, from a decade of violence by her husband. "You have nobody to talk to about what's happening," she said. "You are sitting there quaking with the baby and fearing for your life."

We have described how the Place 2 Be worked with Femi, an eight-year-old Nigerian, who was withdrawn and frightened at his new primary school in south London. After weekly counselling sessions at the school, his proud father reported: "He is working hard, able to concentrate and, above all, is not afraid to let his opinions be known."

On the global stage, we have shown how Field is helping the people of the Pacific islands wrest some control of the way the western biotechnology industry is taking their traditional healings and turning them into hugely profitable commercial products. As Carolina Lasen Diaz, a Field lawyer, said: "You end up with the product being licensed back to the countries from where it originates."

And we have told how Action on Disability and Development (Add) is working to improve the lot of impoverished disabled people in developing countries - 90m in India alone - whose lives are so doubly blighted. People like Panneer selvam, disabled through polio, who has set up a tailoring business in Pudukkottai, Tamil Nadu, thanks to a loan from an Add micro-credit scheme. "Now I have got a lot more self-confidence," he told us.

With the demands of Christmas over, and the new year almost here, I would like you to reflect on our good causes and, I hope, resolve to do more for people like Panneerselvam, Femi, Catherine and the villagers of the Pacific islands.

Help us help those who are helping them in such unsung, unfashionable ways. Let us redress the balance a little. Let us give them some of that edge.

webTitle: Wiping out debt is only a start

fields.headline: Wiping out debt is only a start
fields.standfirst:
Special report: debt relief
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: Last year we celebrated a new millennium. And in doing so, we reaffirmed the promise that by working together we can improve the human condition for all people - especially the world's poorest.
fields.body:
Last year we celebrated a new millennium. And in doing so, we reaffirmed the promise that by working together we can improve the human condition for all people - especially the world's poorest.

This millennial spirit has been perhaps best captured by an extraordinary movement - inspired by the biblical concept of Jubilee - to cancel foreign debt in the world's poorest, most heavily indebted countries. Religious leaders, rock stars, and concerned men and women around the world have galvanised public action and inspired official policy.

This spirit has been central to the mission of the World Bank, and nowhere more indelibly than in the area of poor country debt relief. Four years ago we launched with the international community the first global response to the debt crisis in the world's poorest countries, and in October 1999 we emboldened the programme by making the relief deeper, broader, and faster. The objective of the plan, called the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries Initiative (HIPC), has remained straightforward: to eliminate debt as an obstacle to poverty reduction.

What has been accomplished? First, we have met our goal of having debt relief in place for 22 countries, with 20 already completed. Second, the programme is cancelling an enormous amount of debt: relief stands at some $35bn (£23bn); in co-ordination with other forms of debt alleviation, total debt in these countries could be slashed by more than two-thirds.

New resources will enable governments to sharply increase desperately needed social investments. After relief, social spending is rising to between two and three times debt service obligations. As a result, millions more children will have a chance to learn to read and write; health clinics and rural roads and sanitation facilities will be built; Aids programmes will reach the afflicted; and already, people, working with their governments, are charting their own development course.

We can do much more and ask the bigger, tougher questions. Most important: will these achievements endure? Will the child born today in Africa stand a better chance of reaching his fifth birthday because of what we have done together? Will fewer poor women die giving birth? Will the endless work of farmers and mothers and doctors and entrepreneurs be enough? If debt relief is our only, or even, primary response, the answer is no. If, however, we extend our demands, and our efforts, to address the deeper causes of poverty, we can make a difference.

First, while debt relief is critically important, it will only help reduce poverty if developing countries continue the hard work of improving economic management. There is much to discuss about which policies best support poverty reduction. But there is no argument that runaway deficits and inflation punish the poor most; subsidies which benefit elites are unfair; and corruption strangles the weakest first. Fortunately, real progress is under way.

Take Uganda and Mozambique, the earliest qualifiers for HIPC debt relief, and until a decade ago two of the most troubled lands on earth. Both have sustained strong economic growth while reducing absolute poverty and lifting primary school enrolment. This progress is due not only to debt relief but to the hard work and ideas from the people.

Debt relief which supports such efforts is a sound investment. But it cannot replace development assistance. And here is where a vigorous public debate is badly needed. There is a widely held fiction that masses of money is poured into aid. In fact, industrialised countries spend roughly one-quarter of one percent of their gross domestic product for assistance to the world's poor countries. Aid works, and we can do more to make it work for more people.

What about future lending? Access to external capital is fundamental to any country's development, but borrowers and lenders need to be vigilant about the long-term sustainability of the resulting debt. In many instances this will mean shifting to grants and strictly limiting new lending to only the most generous terms.

The World Bank, which provides resources to the poorest countries interest-free, is exploring new instruments, including grants, for such pressing needs as HIV/Aids, the environment, basic education, and health.

Next, it is time to get serious on trade. Barriers to developing country exports in industrialised markets continue to severely disadvantage poor countries. Last year, industrialised countries spent more than $300bn on agricultural subsidies - roughly equal to the total GNP for all of sub-Saharan Africa. Debt relief without increased market access is futile.
