fields.bodyText: Last year we celebrated a new millennium. And in doing so, we reaffirmed the promise that by working together we can improve the human condition for all people - especially the world's poorest. This millennial spirit has been perhaps best captured by an extraordinary movement - inspired by the biblical concept of Jubilee - to cancel foreign debt in the world's poorest, most heavily indebted countries. Religious leaders, rock stars, and concerned men and women around the world have galvanised public action and inspired official policy. This spirit has been central to the mission of the World Bank, and nowhere more indelibly than in the area of poor country debt relief. Four years ago we launched with the international community the first global response to the debt crisis in the world's poorest countries, and in October 1999 we emboldened the programme by making the relief deeper, broader, and faster. The objective of the plan, called the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries Initiative (HIPC), has remained straightforward: to eliminate debt as an obstacle to poverty reduction. What has been accomplished? First, we have met our goal of having debt relief in place for 22 countries, with 20 already completed. Second, the programme is cancelling an enormous amount of debt: relief stands at some $35bn (£23bn); in co-ordination with other forms of debt alleviation, total debt in these countries could be slashed by more than two-thirds. New resources will enable governments to sharply increase desperately needed social investments. After relief, social spending is rising to between two and three times debt service obligations. As a result, millions more children will have a chance to learn to read and write; health clinics and rural roads and sanitation facilities will be built; Aids programmes will reach the afflicted; and already, people, working with their governments, are charting their own development course. We can do much more and ask the bigger, tougher questions. Most important: will these achievements endure? Will the child born today in Africa stand a better chance of reaching his fifth birthday because of what we have done together? Will fewer poor women die giving birth? Will the endless work of farmers and mothers and doctors and entrepreneurs be enough? If debt relief is our only, or even, primary response, the answer is no. If, however, we extend our demands, and our efforts, to address the deeper causes of poverty, we can make a difference. First, while debt relief is critically important, it will only help reduce poverty if developing countries continue the hard work of improving economic management. There is much to discuss about which policies best support poverty reduction. But there is no argument that runaway deficits and inflation punish the poor most; subsidies which benefit elites are unfair; and corruption strangles the weakest first. Fortunately, real progress is under way. Take Uganda and Mozambique, the earliest qualifiers for HIPC debt relief, and until a decade ago two of the most troubled lands on earth. Both have sustained strong economic growth while reducing absolute poverty and lifting primary school enrolment. This progress is due not only to debt relief but to the hard work and ideas from the people. Debt relief which supports such efforts is a sound investment. But it cannot replace development assistance. And here is where a vigorous public debate is badly needed. There is a widely held fiction that masses of money is poured into aid. In fact, industrialised countries spend roughly one-quarter of one percent of their gross domestic product for assistance to the world's poor countries. Aid works, and we can do more to make it work for more people. What about future lending? Access to external capital is fundamental to any country's development, but borrowers and lenders need to be vigilant about the long-term sustainability of the resulting debt. In many instances this will mean shifting to grants and strictly limiting new lending to only the most generous terms. The World Bank, which provides resources to the poorest countries interest-free, is exploring new instruments, including grants, for such pressing needs as HIV/Aids, the environment, basic education, and health. Next, it is time to get serious on trade. Barriers to developing country exports in industrialised markets continue to severely disadvantage poor countries. Debt relief without increased market access is futile. Finally, the Aids epidemic, particularly in Africa, makes action in all of these efforts more crucial. In some of the hardest-hit African countries, life expectancy over the coming decade may fall from 60 to below 30. Ambitions for health care, education, agriculture, energy and other development areas are endangered by the simple prospect that there will not be enough teachers, students, farmers and workers alive to realise them. Hope, however, persists. In countries which have undertaken education, testing and treatment programmes, infection rates are falling. Encouraging partnerships are under way to build on these efforts, but it will require a sustained effort. The challenges of the new century are daunting. But we confront them with renewed confidence. For those who have kept the spirit of Jubilee and fought for debt relief, we know what can be accomplished by working together. We must keep this spirit alive, this year and for years to come. There is no alternative.  James Wolfensohn is president of the World Bank

webTitle: More chaos feared after five die in icy weather

fields.headline: More chaos feared after five die in icy weather
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Blizzards, freezing rain and howling winds hit the country last night, threatening to add to the five deaths caused by the bitter winter weather over the weekend and cancelling many New Year celebrations.
fields.body:
Blizzards, freezing rain and howling winds hit the country last night, threatening to add to the five deaths caused by the bitter winter weather over the weekend and cancelling many New Year celebrations.

Forecasters warned people in Scotland, Wales, the north and Northern Ireland to expect more vicious storms, with up to 20cm (8in) of snow in some spots and gales of up to 70mph, before milder weather sets in. They predicted a thaw would spread across Britain in the early hours of today.

Icy conditions claimed several lives over the weekend. A 48-year-old woman died after she was hit by a car as she was wiping snow from her windscreen on the A460 in Staffordshire, while at Maudlin near Bodmin, Cornwall, a motorist died after his car hit a stone wall along an icy country road. A 22-year-old male front seat passenger was taken to hospital with serious injuries.

Another driver, in his 20s to 30s, was found floating in icy water on farmland in Camber near Hastings, East Sussex. The farmer who owned the land called police after spotting an unattended, frost-covered car. They believe the death was accidental.

Walkers found the body of a man near the Earnsdale reservoir in Darwen, Lancashire, yesterday.

The man, who was in his 30s, has not yet been identified, but a police spokesman said he matched the description of one of two men seen drinking in the area on Saturday night. Officers are not treating the death as suspicious.

Kent police said they believed the body of a man found frozen in fields at South Darenth near Dartford, Kent, on Saturday was that of a 50-year-old postman who went missing two days before Christmas. The man, who has not been named, was known to be depressed.

In the Highlands, the bad weather prevented a rescue helicopter from reaching a climber who had fallen and suffered head injuries yesterday afternoon. A companion reported that he had fallen 100ft on Ben Nevis, Britain's highest mountain.

A man who nearly drowned after being trapped on rocks by the rising tide near Llansteffan, west Wales, was saved after he used his mobile phone to call his next-door neighbour 200 miles away in Milton Keynes, Buckinghamshire. The neighbour alerted the coastguard.

The man was washed off the rocks and made a second call to his neighbour before coastguards and police in helicopters rescued him from the freezing sea. His body temperature had sunk to a dangerously low 27C, but he made a good recovery in hospital.

Despite the sudden blast of snow, it seemed that the end of the big freeze was in sight last night. A Met Office forecaster said that temperatures would rise as a band of warm air swept across the country bringing rain.

Promises of an imminent thaw were little consolation to new year revellers as officials in Liverpool scrapped two firework displays and an outdoor concert.

In Middlesbrough, thousands of residents were disappointed by the cancellation of events including the lighting of the Millennium Beacon.

But many cities continued with big open air celebrations despite fears that the weather might discourage people from attending.

In Edinburgh, where police expected the centre to be as crowded as ever for hogmanay, a spokesman said: "You can't cancel something like that or we'd have a lynch mob on our hands. It's horrendous up here - we've got snowflakes falling like 50p pieces. But the town is incredibly busy so it doesn't seem to have dampened people's spirits."

London's New Year's Day parade is also set to go ahead, with organisers predicting that more than a million people would be turning out. Last week they warned that they might have to forgo the huge inflatable decorations if the winds were too strong. Around the country police warned motorists that road conditions were still extremely icy and urged them to take care as heavy mists developed. Snow and strong winds closed several roads yesterday, including the A7 and A68 main routes into Edinburgh and the A66 trans-Pennine route into Cumbria.

Rail and most air travel seemed to be getting back to normal, but EasyJet passengers faced further delays as staff struggled to clear the backlog caused by cancelled flights.

Police were called to Luton and Liverpool airports over the weekend as angry travellers who had booked with the budget airline were stranded by icy conditions and freezing fog.

webTitle: New asylum row erupts

fields.headline: New asylum row erupts
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: A bitter row over asylum seekers erupted last night when the former Tory deputy prime minister Michael Heseltine said many claims were bogus, made by people simply seeking a better quality of life.
fields.body:
A bitter row over asylum seekers erupted last night when the former Tory deputy prime minister Michael Heseltine said many claims were bogus, made by people simply seeking a better quality of life.

Mr Heseltine, who is regarded as one of the few liberals left in the Tory party, was accused by the Refugee Council of making "inflammatory and prejudiced" remarks that could incite racial violence.

In an interview with the BBC's The World This Weekend, Mr Heseltine said: "Let's not mince our language here. Why on earth should British citizens go without the houses they want, or take longer to get treatment they need, in order to make way for people who have cheated the immigration rules?" Mr Heseltine, who established his credentials as a One Nation Tory when he pleaded with his party to help black people in the wake of the inner-city riots in the early 1980s, said he was not making racial remarks.

"This is not a racial business - no one has a better record than I for standing for racial harmony," he said. "This is simply a question of dealing with people who claim to be running away from tyrannical regimes when actually what they want to do is become part of the prosperity of our particular society."

His remarks came a fortnight after William Hague, the Tory leader, was accused by Labour of playing the race card, in the wake of the murder of 10-year-old Damilola Taylor, after he criticised the Macpherson report into the murder of Stephen Lawrence for lowering police morale. Earlier last year, Mr Hague was accused of lurching to the right when he called for asylum seekers to be locked up.

Mr Heseltine's remarks drew a sharp response from the Refugee Council, which warned that he he was distorting the truth and might be encouraging racists to attack asylum seekers.

Nick Hardwick, the council's chief executive, said: "In a week when an asylum seeker was nearly murdered on the streets and the great faiths are celebrating goodwill to all men, language like this just fuels ignorance, resentment and racial hostility against a backdrop of dramatically increased racially motivated attacks."

Mike O'Brien, the Home Office minister, dismissed the former deputy prime minister's remarks as ill-informed.

Mr Heseltine's outburst ends his recent honeymoon with the centre left, which was inspired by his relentless criticism of Mr Hague's European policy. His strong language yesterday will revive memories of the "Hezza" of the 1980s who became a hate figure on the left when, as defence secretary, he led the Tories' assault on CND.

The row came as the government faced claims that its controversial system of dispersing asylum seekers around the country is near collapse.

The Home Office admitted that only 10,850 refugees have been placed under the dispersal system, which is designed to relieve pressure on London and the south-east. This is a long way short of the 65,000 people who were meant to be dispersed by next April, a figure that was revised down to 44,000 in October.

Under the dispersal scheme, which was launched in April, refugees will only be given help with accommodation if they go where they are told to by the national asylum support service. If they refuse, they are still entitled to vouchers to buy food and other essentials.

Councils and refugee groups say the asylum seekers dispersed around the country are returning to London and the south-east because they hate the conditions so much.

Mr Hardwick said: "People are opting to stay in London. The dispersal experience has to be made less horrible."

Asylum seekers are finding themselves subject to racial harassment, unable to get proper legal advice and isolated after being dispersed, say refugee groups.

Mr Hardwick said the dispersal system was in a "critical condition" because of a contradiction at the heart of government policy.

"The government has to decide whether the main point of the current system is to deter people, in which case it should make it as horrible as possible, or to take the pressure off London and the south-east, in which case it has to make it less harsh. So long as dispersal is seen as a punishment it won't work."

According to the latest figures, since April the dispersal scheme has seen 553 asylum seekers placed in the east midlands, 198 in London, 199 in Kent and Sussex, 1,699 in the north-east, 2,836 in the north- west, 1,110 in Scotland, 309 in the south-west, 15 in Wales, 1,000 in the west midlands, and 2,931 in Yorkshire and Humberside.

webTitle: Pressure on Blair to name £2m donor

fields.headline: Pressure on Blair to name £2m donor
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was facing mounting pressure last night to open up Labour's books and name a mystery donor who has contributed £2m to the party's general election campaign fund.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was facing mounting pressure last night to open up Labour's books and name a mystery donor who has contributed £2m to the party's general election campaign fund.

The former cabinet minister David Clark said that Labour should always strive to be transparent, while one of the party's most generous donors said that the current system was no way to fund political parties.

Lord Haskins, the chairman of Northern Foods, who always publishes the amount he gives to the Labour party, said: "Some people want to remain private. But this is not the right way to fund political parties. Openness is always the best way. It stops the speculation."

Reports that Labour has banked a £2m donation come weeks before "anti-sleaze" legislation requiring details of gifts to be disclosed comes into effect. The Labour party refused to discuss the donation last night, saying: "We do not discuss individual donations and we do not give a running commentary."

Labour has not broken any rules because the name of the donor will be published later this year in the party's annual accounts, which list the name of anyone who gives more than £5,000. But it will be impossible to identify the £2m donor in the list, which had the names of 68 donors last year.

This system, which has been criticised as vague, will be changed on February 16, when a new law, the Political Parties, Elections and Referendums Act, requires the names of donors and the size of their gifts to be disclosed to a new electoral commission. Donations received before then will escape the new rules.

Labour faces pressure to open up its books because of past criticism that the government has granted favours to large donors. Mr Blair faced his first real test as prime minister in the autumn of 1997 when Labour sought to cover up a £1m donation from the formula one boss Bernie Ecclestone. It later emerged that the sport had temporarily been exempted from a ban on tobacco advertising shortly after Mr Ecclestone's donation.

Andrew Lansley, Tory Cabinet Office spokesman, said: "People may reasonably expect Labour to confirm the source and the amount of this donation so that we can see whether it is another formula one-style donation."

The independent MP Martin Bell, who sits on the Commons standards and privileges committee, said Labour should publish the donor's name. "If it is good enough to publish names of donors in February, then it is good enough to do so now," he said.

The Labour party's silence contrasts with its openness in 1999 when the science minister, Lord Sainsbury of Turville, gave £2m, setting a new record for a single donation. Downing Street said that Lord Sainsbury had decided to disclose the donation to allow the Labour party to appear "transparent and above board".

The latest £2m donation is likely to have been from one of Labour's regular business donors who may have wanted to avoid being identified as such a generous benefactor when the new rules come into force. Last year's donors included Robert Bourne, whose Legacy consortium is in negotiations to buy the Millennium Dome; Lord Gavron, the former chairman of the Guardian Media Group, the parent company of the Guardian; and Gulam Noon, whose company, Noon Products, supplies curries to Sainsbury's.

The latest donation is said to have been secured by the multi-millionaire music impresario Lord Levy, Labour's chief fundraiser. Mr Blair was said to be so delighted with Lord Levy, who recently took on a role as the prime minister's envoy to Latin America in addition to his work in the Middle East, that he invited him to a party at Chequers on Boxing Day.

webTitle: Judge to head wider inquiry into Shipman murders

fields.headline: Judge to head wider inquiry into Shipman murders
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Shipman trial
fields.trailText: The government is to dramatically widen the scope of the official inquiry into the serial killer Harold Shipman, throwing it open to the public and replacing the proposed civil servant chairman with a senior high court judge.
fields.body:
The government is to dramatically widen the scope of the official inquiry into the serial killer Harold Shipman, throwing it open to the public and replacing the proposed civil servant chairman with a senior high court judge.

The new hearing, expected to start next month, will also look at up to 200 suspicious deaths instead of only 38 - all concessions demanded by relatives of former patients of the Greater Manchester GP.

The u-turn by the health secretary, Alan Milburn, was welcomed yesterday by the families, not only in Greater Manchester but in Todmorden, West Yorkshire, where Shipman's murderous career may have started much earlier than previously thought.

The judge, Dame Janet Smith, 60, who was brought up in Lancashire and has wide experience of medical negligence cases, is expected to start public sessions of the inquiry in February. Subject to approval by parliament, she will take over from Lord Laming, former chief inspector of social services, whose narrower inquiry, due to be held in private, was halted last month when victims' relatives won a judicial review.

Mr Milburn, who is expected to announce the strengthened inquiry and its timetable in Manchester later this week, was praised for "listening to the relatives' arguments" by the families' solicitor, Ann Alexander.

She said that the public hearings and extended scope of the inquiry were exactly what relatives had considered essential to unravelling how the GP got away repeatedly with murder.

Shipman, 54, was convicted last January of killing 15 patients in the Hyde area of Greater Manchester, where he preyed on elderly women for reasons that have yet to be fathomed. After he was given 15 life sentences, the police said that they had enough evidence to charge him with 23 other deaths, but the crown prosecution service ruled out new proceedings on the grounds that a fair trial would be impossible after previous evidence and the publication of at least two books.

Ms Alexander said the new inquiry would be able to look at "gaps in the NHS system" that allowed Shipman to continue quietly killing patients for years, and possibly decades.

Ms Alexander said: "The families are really pleased with the choice of chairman. Dame Janet is very well respected and is also from the north of England. She has a lot of experience of medical matters and all the characteristics that the families wanted."

webTitle: Larger lavatories for the discerning golfer

fields.headline: Larger lavatories for the discerning golfer
fields.trailText: When you are a member of one of Scotland's most upmarket golf clubs, tabloid reading matter in the little boys' room just will not do.
fields.body:
When you are a member of one of Scotland's most upmarket golf clubs, tabloid reading matter in the little boys' room just will not do.

So the Prestwick club is spending thousands of pounds on upgrading facilities, including widening its lavatory cubicles to accommodate broadsheet newspapers.

The west coast club, formed in 1851, was the birthplace of the Open Championship and has one of the country's most distinguished membership rolls, including Edward VIII, who was club captain in 1934 when he was Prince of Wales.

It has not played host to the Open since 1925, but this year will stage the Amateur Championship and celebrate its 150th anniversary, and officials felt some refurbishment was needed. Almost 100 lockers installed in 1882 at a cost of £350 are still in use.

The changes to the cubicles were the subject of a club memo: "The lavatory stalls are dimensioned so that a broadsheet newspaper may be read in comfort.

"While the importance of this characteristic to some members is recognised, it is not at this stage planned to supply reading material."

The club chairman, Colin MacGregor, said: "Some of the members are quite large and a number of them said that when we did the refurbishment they wanted plenty of room."

webTitle: TV and Radio: Mark Lawson's column

fields.headline: Fortysomething
fields.standfirst: After the success of The 1900 House, Channel 4 send a family back to 40s wartime conditions. The results make fascinating viewing, says  Mark Lawson - and make us realise how good we have it now
fields.trailText: After the success of The 1900 House, Channel 4 send a family back to 40s wartime conditions. The results make fascinating viewing and make us realise how good we have it now.
fields.body:
Caricatured by its critics as obsessed with youth and the future, Channel 4, in its New Year programming, is all tin-hat and gas-mask. Opening up one wartime front tomorrow with the story of a British soldier's quest for heroism in an adaptation of Evelyn Waugh's Sword Of Honour trilogy, the channel completes a pincer-movement with The 1940s House (Tuesday, 8.30pm), in which three generations of a modern clan are challenged to live for nine weeks under the conditions of rationing and black-outs.

When the history of Channel 4 is written, one section will have to deal with the station's quiet but persistent role as TV's estate agent.

They've put more people into houses than many local councils. There was Location, Location, Location - in which the network helped renting contestants to find bricks and mortgage - and then the now celebrated incarceration of 10 people in an East London house which led, among other things, to an unknown Liverpudlian called Craig aiming for the pop charts.

But, before Big Brother, there was a precursor of house-arrest television in The 1900 House, in which a South London address was returned to Victorian culinary and plumbing arrangements and a contemporary family lived there observed by hidden cameras. The 1940s House pushes this inspired idea four decades on to the homefront of the second world war. As in the previous series, the intention is to offer a history lesson, with a small subsidiary course in psychology, via the more palatable format of a game-show.

The Hymers from Yorkshire - granny, grandpa, mum and two young sons - were selected from a regiment of volunteers. Their casting itself offers a historical commentary. The second and third generations of the Hymers - Kirsty, Ben and Tom - are a single-parent family. Although such arrangements were officially rare in the 40s by choice, they were almost uniform by force: most men were away at war.

And so the mid-20th-century family is best impersonated by a very 21st-century kind.

Other aspects of the conflict are harder to imitate. Even after Big Brother, television's regulators would look askance at bombs being dropped on contestants, and so the climate of fear and uncertainty is provided by a committee of historians. Meeting in Churchill's war rooms, this cabinet resembles a soap-opera script conference in which the characters are real and the plot-twists historical.

Letters pushed through the door of the house send the Hymers to the air-raid shelter or fine them for black-out violations. Compressing the events of six wartime years into nine weeks, the invisible committee also decides which goods should be available in the shop to which the women take their ration-books. American intervention puts Spam onto the shelves, the derivation of the name - Specially Pressed American Meats - explained by the greengrocer in an educational aside. The show is very good at such footnotes which kick, softly mentioning, for example, that mothers died during the blackouts, plunging down steep stairs as they went to comfort a crying child.

While the military threat is blessedly metaphorical, the other privations are real and this pressure creates tensions to rival the expulsion of Nasty Nick from Big Brother. Used to regular meals and snacks, the Hymer boys become visibly hungry. When mum fashions her allotted eggs and chocolate into a cake for them, granny is accused of half-inching a slice. Her speech of guilty justification - about how she is last in the food-chain in the house - will give moral indigestion to most viewers of a series screened in the post-supper slot. Commercial breaks are usually stuffed with ads for fast-food but not, you suspect, during this series.

The committee's rigours mean that character is revealed in a way unmatched by most dramas. An academic who knows about the wartime tobacco flow suddenly removes it from the shop, resulting in the first instance outside of addiction clinics of adults giving up smoking against their will. In another sequence, 10-year-old Ben becomes a fanatical Fuel Warden, rising in the night to monitor his mum's and gran's use of the light-switch.

Although similar in concept, the two series of this flashback project lead the viewer to very different conclusions. The 1900 House encouraged triumphalism about the century's advances in technology and social equality. Even Norman Tebbit would have struggled to suggest that many of the Victorian values on display were worth restoring.

The relationship of The 1940s House with the present-day is much more complicated. Though never overtly editorial, the series inevitably becomes a critique of modern materialism and complacency. Because the nature of the experiment keeps the family in isolation, there's no risk of the most familiar manifestation of second world war nostalgia: the great community spirit.

Yet the sight of a family under-fed, with heat and light restricted and entertainment dependent on invention, forcibly illustrates the extent of our over-provision in these areas. The trick of good history-teaching - particularly to a younger audience - is to communicate the experience of living in previous times. Like its Victorian ancestor, The 1940s House is a virtual experience museum. A still new-ish channel is becoming notably skilled at the old.

Live and indirect

In his documentary Changing Stages last year, Richard Eyre boldly used a television series about theatre to advance the view that theatre doesn't work on television. Live drama, he argued, is the snowman of the arts. You need to be there at the moment of creation.

This notion challenges a small but cherished television genre. For decades, arts broadcasters have seen it as their duty to record major theatrical performances. Tonight, for example, Channel 4 screens the 1999 RSC Macbeth (6.05pm), starring Antony Sher and Harriet Walter.

In the theatre, Gregory Doran's production was the most visceral and illuminating staging of the play for decades. The recording certainly serves as a reminder of the evening's genius. But could it convince a newcomer tuning in?

The fundamental question in these attempts is whether the tape is a record of what happened in the theatre or a free-standing television piece. Channel 4's version of Trevor Nunn's Carousel, screened on Christmas Day, was recorded in the original theatre with an audience. For Macbeth, the play is filmed in a warehouse, which creates a feel halfway between a theatre and a TV studio. The third option - Highlands locations - is ruinously expensive and brings dubious gains.

Is Eyre's case made? Despite some visuals specific to the new medium - the Weird Sisters are grainily shot as if on surveillance video - I fear it is.

While Sher and Walter have rethought their performances with close-up reactions, much of the acting feels too declamatory, calculated to reach the balcony. You keep feeling you should be sitting in the dark, a programme in hand.

And yet I can understand why the attempt was made. How can it be right that a production of this brilliance should vanish while posterity will be bequeathed every single episode of, for example, Blankety Blank on tape? But such is cultural reality and Richard Eyre's prophecy will loom over future translations like Banquo's ghost.

webTitle: Obituaries:  Eric Todd

fields.headline: Letter
fields.trailText: Harry Griffin writes: Eric Todd (obituary December 15) was not just a Guardian football and cricket correspondent. He was a man of immensely varied talents who could be Stanley Holloway one moment, an excellent amateur classical pianist the next.
fields.body:
Harry Griffin writes: Eric Todd (obituary December 15) was not just a Guardian football and cricket correspondent. He was a man of immensely varied talents who could be Stanley Holloway one moment, an excellent amateur classical pianist the next, a gifted comedian and raconteur, the leader of any group of people by the force of his personality, and my close friend for nearly 70 years. Before the loss of Margaret, his much-loved wife of half a century, and his latest illness, he always seemed to be on a high.

I was best man at his wedding in 1939 - Eric in bell-bottoms before his Royal Navy commission - and we were together on one evening paper for several years. Eric was easily the most popular member of staff, uniting us all by his vilification of an unpopular editor. He led us in all sorts of japes, from a night-time performance of Mutiny On The Bounty on the giant presses in the paper's machine-room - where he would be Captain Bligh and I Mr Christian - to wild leaving parties in superior hotels where this lifelong teetotaller would always seem the wildest. Many old newspapermen will regret his passing.

webTitle: Obituaries: Jacques Laurent

fields.headline: Jacques Laurent
fields.standfirst: Writer with two enemies - Sartre and de Gaulle
fields.trailText: Writer with two enemies - Sartre and de Gaulle.
fields.body:
In October 1981, a week before the French presidential elections, Jacques Laurent, who has died aged 81, had dinner with François Mitterrand and a few of his friends. He complained that he was always referred to as a right-wing writer and asked why this should be. "Because you worked for Vichy and you were in favour of keeping Algeria French," replied Robert Badinter, the future justice minister. According to Laurent, at this, he and Mitterrand exchanged amused glances; Badinter had effectively provided a portrait of France's next president as well.

Laurent worked for the wartime Vichy collaborationist government - as did Mitterrand. They got on well and might have met before the war when Laurent frequented the Brasserie Lipp, on the Boulevard Saint-Germain in Paris, with other young far-rightists. Laurent had many contacts with right wing extremists in the conspiratorial La Cagoule group which had been defended in court by his father, Laurent-Cély (to give him his full name).

Since Laurent was a follower of the far-right Charles Maurras, his connection with Vichy was natural. But with Laurent there were always surprises. In 1944 he seems to have been among those who negotiated between the leader of Vichy, Marshall Pétain, and the Free French. The failure of those talks led Laurent to join a resistance group. The episode remains mysterious, but enabled him to avoid postwar retribution.

I knew Claude Martine, who became Laurent's first wife, and thus met him in 1947 and 1948. He was writing a novel, but the book he gave me was about France's position in Europe and the author's name appeared as Albéric Varenne. Laurent explained that in France you were expected to write only one sort of book, so that if you changed your role as an author you had to change your name.

I only appreciated this later when Martine gave me a lift in a magnificent Buick. She explained that Caroline Chérie was a best-seller - it also became a 1950 film. I then realised that Jacques Laurent was also Cécil de Saint-Laurent, the best-seller's author. (He had also been writing pseudonymous detective novels). His finances transformed, he completed two novels, which had a limited success and then for 17 years Jacques Laurent wrote no novels, although Cécil continued on his profitable way.

He had two enemies. One was Jean-Paul Sartre and his intellectual dominance (Laurent used the word "terrorism"). He wrote a devastating pamphlet, Paul et Jean-Paul (1951), which argued that the prevailing Marxism and existentialism were designed to reduce the writer to "revolutionary worker". In 1953 he founded a revue, La Parisienne, as an answer to Sartre's Les Temps Modernes. By being open to all literary genres the right checked the left in the name of artistic autonomy and quality.

The second enemy was Charles de Gaulle. Laurent had ignored him when writing about France in 1940, but when François Mauriac published a hagiographic account of de Gaulle in 1964, Laurent responded with two violent attacks on the president. This landed him in court where he was ordered to remove 20 pages of his Mauriac Sous de Gaulle.

He opposed de Gaulle giving independence to Algeria and showed sympathy for the French settlers's secret army which committed violence inside France. He maintained the Vichy accusation that de Gaulle was a British creation in 1940, but his arguments in favour of a Pétainist resistance to the Germans are more readily accepted today.

After a visit to Vietnam in 1967 and 1968, which resulted in an anti-communist book and a violent attack on the French intellectuals for supporting north Vietnam, Laurent returned to novel-writing and produced his finest work. Notable are the Prix Goncourt-winning Les Bêtises (1971) and Les Miroir aux Tiroirs (1990). The first, beginning with an account of the war and of adventures with the resistance, becomes a study in the inadequacies of autobiography and narrative. The later novel is a study of a man's relations with a number of women, while retaining his idea of freedom. Both are witty and picturesque. He was elected to the Académie Française in 1986.

Laurent's writings are carefully constructed. Yet he could be very careless in the actual writing. He would, for example, ask Claude Martine to write a passage while he did something else. She used to say that she would describe a female character and go into great detail concerning her clothes. He would then take up the story and promptly undress the character.

For a time, from 1954, Laurent owned and edited the weekly Arts magazine. Interested in the cinema, he entrusted film reviews to such people as future film-makers Francois Truffaut, Jean-Luc Godard and Eric Rohmer. He wrote several film scripts. The Caroline films, mixing historical drama and eroticism, were a great success, and Lola Montès (1955) and his adaptation of Stendhal's De L'Amour (1954) were well received. His one venture into film production, 48 Heures d'amour (1968), was a failure.

Laurent was one of the rightist writers who were referred to as the Hussards, but he was very different from the others. He had a lively sense of humour. After the death of Gide, a telegram was sent to François Mauriac which read, "There is no Hell. Have a good time. André." It was widely assumed that it was sent by Laurent. He would answer questions as his interviewer hoped he would. He explained to an English journalist that he changed his girlfriends according to colour - thus a black woman would be succeeded by a blonde Swede. He told a serious questioner about the Brasserie Lipp that he could remember when customers were looked after by a groom, who was a dwarf.

For years Laurent appeared to be a spent force, spending days chez Lipp. Then suddenly he would produce a book. His last novel was Moment Particuliers (1997). Last October, after his third wife, Elizabeth, died he published a letter to her, describing the happiness of their life together over many years. He insisted that Figaro should publish a photograph of them in bed together. His conclusion was that, with her gone, life had become a nightmare.

 Jacques Laurent-Cély, writer, born January 5, 1919; died December 29 2000.

webTitle: Obituaries: Sir Jack Jacob

fields.headline: Sir Jack Jacob
fields.standfirst: Lawyer who ushered England's civil courts into the present day
fields.trailText: Lawyer who ushered England's civil courts into the present day.
fields.body:
Sir Jack Jacob, who has died aged 92, was the outstanding British exponent of civil court procedure during the 20th century. He was the first to fully grasp the relationship between court rules and the social dynamics which lay behind their operation. He had the ability to enter the minds of the special pleaders of centuries ago, to understand their thought processes, and to reconstruct the essential features of the English system into a modern framework.

His vast industry was harnessed by a streak of naiveté in his outward-going personality into a quest to bring the civil court system up-to-date. For he knew better than most the function which procedure plays in protecting fundamental liberties, a role enshrined in article six of the European Convention on Human Rights.

As master and senior master of the high court (1957-80) he was not simply the general editor of the bible of rules, the White Book. He established and developed civil procedure as a subject of university study and helped bridge the gap between the academic and professional worlds, culminating in his directorship of the Institute of Advanced Legal Studies.

His procedural philosophy, described in his 1986 Hamlyn Lectures, was based on the belief that the parties to civil disputes were best served by a fairly balanced adversary procedure with the court playing a passive, non-interventionist role. Thus he was initially opposed to Lord Woolf's recent reforms of the civil rules, dominated as they are by notions of court control, but he came to accept the need for radical change on the basis that the judiciary would be able to adequately oversee the new regime. Paradoxically, the Woolf changes were constructed on foundations which Jacob had created or influenced.

Jacob was born in Shanghai and educated at the public school for boys in the city, his father having settled there from Iraq as an employee of the Sassoon merchant family. At 18, he emigrated to England where he became a brilliant London University student, gaining the Cecil Peace Prize. He was called to the bar at Gray's Inn in 1930.

After war service, which he ended as a staff captain, he built up a leading junior practice - regularly taking women pupils - becoming expert in very technical areas such as hire purchase. On the brink of taking silk during the mid-1950s, with the prospect of a high court judgeship beyond, his confidence faltered. A temporary trough at the bar led him to doubt whether his limited powers of advocacy would be able to maintain a young family. He applied for, and obtained, the post of high court queen's bench master, a sub-judicial official dealing with routine pre-trial work. At the time it was considered a low-grade job for failed barristers, who presided over a round of short procedural hearings often attended by inexperienced court clerks.

The appointment transformed him. His powers of concentration and his ability to rapidly write enormous amounts of material were harnessed to a desire to reform the legal system based on theory as well as application. First came his editorship of major practitioners' works such as the White Book, Atkin's Court Forms, Bullen & Leake On Pleadings and Chitty's Queen's Bench Forms. In his hands these volumes were thoroughly revised in conjunction with the 1965 rules revision in which he participated.

Next, he laid the foundation of an academic reception for civil procedure. As visiting professor at University College, London, with Professor Ash Wheatcroft, he pioneered a master's course in the subject. His seminars, for which he lectured until he was nearly 80, became world famous. With his friends, Ben Kaplan of the Harvard Law School and the Italian educator, Mauro Cappelletti, he played a leading role in encouraging international studies in the subject.

Jacob wanted to set his own discipline within a cultural and social setting. He became a facilitator for the establishment of socio-legal studies. He had a hand in the foundation of Birmingham University's institute of judicial administration and Oxford's centre for socio-legal studies. He was involved in a large number of research initiatives. A stream of books, essays, lectures and reports flowed from his pen. Students, teachers, and judges from all over the world consulted him. His capacity for instant and long-lasting friendships was legendary.

Jacob sat on many government committees concerned with court reform. Of these the most important were those on personal injuries litigation (1968) and on the enforcement of judgment debts (1969), which he largely wrote. The former started the process of moving civil procedure towards a much earlier exchange of information and away from the culture of "trial by ambush", beloved by so many litigation lawyers. The latter proposed the radical step of the establishment of an enforcement office that would oversee the process of debt recovery, having regard to the judgment debtor's overall means. To Jacob's regret, faced with an over-complex and wordy set of proposals, successive governments found little difficulty in shelving the plan,

As senior master and queen's remembrancer (1975-80) he presided over events such as the trial of the Pyx, which tests the quality of the Mint's coinage. To his amusement he also found himself involved in the detail of the sale of London Bridge to Arizona.

Jacob was knighted and given honorary silk. He was invested with academic and other honours from institutions all over the world. At the celebrations for his 90th birthday at Gray's Inn in 1998, attended by luminaries led by Lord Woolf, he made a speech calling for further reforms in civil procedure.

He was devoted to, and dependent upon, his wife Rose who died in 1995. He was immensely proud that both his sons had followed him into the law. The elder is a high court judge, the younger a law lecturer.

webTitle: Peace eludes Bethlehem

fields.headline: Peace eludes Bethlehem
fields.standfirst:
500 metres is a world apart for Jews and Palestinians
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Yigal Ohana, an Israeli student, and Nick Makhlouf, a Palestinian casino worker, live directly opposite one another, separated by one of the most beautiful valleys in Israel. It is famous for its olives and, during the last three months, for its gun battles.
fields.body:
Yigal Ohana, an Israeli student, and Nick Makhlouf, a Palestinian casino worker, live directly opposite one another, separated by one of the most beautiful valleys in Israel. It is famous for its olives and, during the last three months, for its gun battles.

As the death toll in the region rises and the chances of a diplomatic settlement recede, pessimism on both sides of the valley is pervasive.

Mr Ohana's and Mr Makhlouf's houses are on the frontline, only 500 metres apart, and they can clearly see one another's hilltop homes. Mr Makhlouf's home is part of the Palestinian West Bank; Mr Ohana's is disputed, with the Palestinians claiming it is part of the West Bank, though in any peace agreement it will almost certainly go to Israel.

Mr Ohana, aged 32, lives on Ha'anafa Street, in the mainly Jewish settlement of Gilo, with his mother, father, brother and sister. His flat stands out, flying an Australian flag rather than the Israeli one his neighbours fly. He lived in Melbourne for seven years, working in fast-food joints, and says: "I put up the Israeli flag at first, but it did not help much. A soldier was shot outside my window."

Before a two-week lull in fighting around Christmas, he says, the shooting from Beit Jalla, the Palestinian-Christian village across the valley, often began at 5pm, as night fell, and continued beyond midnight.

"When the shooting begins, we close the windows and turn off the lights. The windows have thick double-glazing." Would that stop a bullet? "I do not know. I guess so." But the family takes no chances, opting to huddle in the kitchen. A bullet would then have to pass through two walls.

The value of their house has dropped by 35% since the Palestinian uprising began, as have others nearby. Some families have opted to leave. His family, which has lived in Gilo since it was established almost 20 years ago, intends to stay, though he would like to go to Australia.

He holds out no hope of a deal between the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, that would satisfy both sides.

Mr Ohana is no die-hard rightwinger, and dismisses as "fanatics" the Israeli settlers entrenched in the more isolated parts of the West Bank. But when the election for prime minister comes on February 6, he will back the hardliner Ariel Sharon. Mr Sharon will be more hawkish, he says. "Once the goverment changes, we will see things change." The Palestinians know Mr Sharon will not negotiate until the shooting has stopped.

Since September, tens of thousands of bullets have been exchanged across the valley, and most houses on the frontline in Gilo have bullet holes.

The damage on the Palestinian side is much worse, because the Israelis respond with machine-guns, tanks and helicopter gunships. In Beit Jalla, previously a lovely village, many of the houses are ruined.

Mr Makhlouf, looking across the valley to Mr Ohana's home, says: "I hope they [the politicians] get this peace agreement and end this war." But, even if they do sign an agreement, he does not expect it to end the 52-year-old conflict: "You can have peace on paper but the real issue - feeling safe in your home - I do not think it will happen."

Like Mr Ohana, he has lived abroad, studying in Canada for five years. Aged 24, he works in Jericho, managing slot-machines in a casino that is now closed because of the fighting.

He lives in Baton Street, with his mother and father and two younger brothers, and, until recently, his grandparents. His father made souvenirs from olive wood, but is redundant because there are no tourists. His mother is a cleaner.

He accuses the Israelis of reacting with excessive force: "The only thing they have not hit us with is a small nuclear bomb." His uncle's house next door was hit by a helicopter gunship missile which passed through three walls.

"As soon as we hear gunfire, we hide. It is not safe here. We are in the line of fire." His grandfather, Hanna, 75, handicapped and unable to join the rush to safety in the basement of a neighbour's house, has taken refuge in Canada. "Four days after he left, the veranda was hit," Mr Makhlouf says. It was 4.45pm, the time when his grandfather usually sat there.

He dismisses the US peace proposals. He does not believe that the Haram al-Sharif holy site in Jerusalem can be divided between Palestinians and Jews. And, whatever the practical difficulties, the Palestinian refugees scattered round the Middle East should retain the right to return. The US wants them to give this up.

He is apprehensive at the prospect of Mr Sharon becoming prime minister: "He hates Arabs very bad. He has lots of hatred for the Palestinians."

Until the fighting began, Mr Makhlouf regularly went to Gilo for its shopping mall, its theatre and McDonald's. Mr Ohana visited a friend in Beit Jalla a year ago. Neither would dream of doing so now, or in the near future.

webTitle: Family found dead in fume-filled house

fields.headline: Family found dead in fume-filled house
fields.trailText: A family found dead in a fume-filled bungalow several hours before a church New Year's Eve party are thought to have been victims of boiler or gas fire problems.
fields.body:
A family found dead in a fume-filled bungalow several hours before a church New Year's Eve party are thought to have been victims of boiler or gas fire problems.

Joan Stone, who was restaurant manager at a conference centre in Cumbria, was discovered with her husband, Peter, and their teenage daughter, Emma-Jane, after police and firemen smashed down their front door.

A neighbour called emergency services to the £70,000 bungalow in Crossfield Road, Cleator Moor, Cumbria, after hearing the smoke alarm ringing in the afternoon and seeing the windows misted over.

Firemen were initially forced back from the house by fumes, but found the victims when they re-entered using breathing apparatus.

The parents were slumped together in the living room and Emma-Jane, 16, their only child, was in another room.

"We suspect that carbon monoxide was the cause of the deaths, but an investigation is under way to establish that," said a spokesman for Cumbria fire brigade. "It appears to be a tragic accident."

Mr Stone, who like his wife was in his 50s, had recently taken early retirement from an IT post at the Sellafield nuclear plant.

The couple were well liked locally, and Emma-Jane was described by neighbours as "a lovely girl, mad keen on horses" and had a horse of her own.

A black scarf was looped last night round a snowman which the family had built in the garden, close to where their Mercedes and Mini-Cooper cars still stood. Bunches of flowers were also laid nearby by neighbours.

"Everyone who knew them is overcome by what's happened, especially at this time of the year," said Alfred Sheil, 52, who lives across the road from the bungalow.

Emma-Jane was a pupil at Whitehaven comprehensive, a highly rated local school, and shared her father's interest in computers and IT.

Her mother ran the restaurant at the Summergrove hotel and conference centre, owned by British Nuclear Fuels and used for meetings by Sellafield managers and visitors.

David Clague, a neighbour, said: "It appears that they were overcome by carbon monoxide.

"It's a terrible thing to happen, and none of us can quite believe it."

Another neighbour, Hilda Fitzpatrick, said: "We're all in a state of shock. It's a close community, on the edge of town, and the Stones were a nice family."

A church party to see in 2001 was cancelled out of respect as news of the tragedy spread.

Sheila Richardson, who also lives in Crossfield Road, said: "Everyone was so shocked and devastated, and it would have been insensitive to go ahead."

Forensic specialists from Cumbria police have started an investigation at the large, modern bungalow, along with British Gas and staff from the health and safety executive.

The town was swept by renewed blizzards last night.

webTitle: Comment:  Torrid tales of misery at Luton airport

fields.headline: Apologising is easy - but it doesn't make things better
fields.standfirst:
Torrid tales of misery at Luton airport. Then 'sorry' says the pilot

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Torrid tales of misery at Luton airport. Then 'sorry' says the pilot.
fields.body:
Welcome, this dire, storm-lashed season, to Crisis Centre UK. Welcome to torrid tales of human misery, boiling anger, weeping frustration - and media hype. I'm (to choose terms carefully) sorry about this: but welcome to Luton airport. Once upon a not-too-distant time, nobody was ever particularly sorry about anything. Trains and boats and planes either ran or they didn't. You paid your money and you took your (alas, nationalised industry) chance. There was an assumption that whatever was out there, failing to arrive, was an act of god. And then came customer relations.

Mrs Thatcher began it with privatisation. The first apologies, acknowledging that all was manifestly not well, began to creep over Tannoy systems. John Major picked up her baton: stuck on the M1, travellers could pick up a mobile phone and call the cones hotline for a ritual grovel. Full credit, though, to Tony Blair and the Irish potato famine; they have finished the job. Sorry isn't the hardest word any longer; it is the glib panacea to meet all ills. I am not, to be clear, picking on the admirable Stelios of easyJet fame, nor on the proud town of Luton. They have both had a dreadful Christmas.

On good days, easyJet provide the cheapest, most flexible way for grandfathers of new babies in Barcelona (me) to get out to Catalonia fast and worship at the crib. On bad days, cheapness and flexibility are expected pawns, to be offered up without undue complaint. You get mostly what you pay for, and less ought, in logic, to mean less.

What happened? Mundane stuff happened. On the way out, the call to the gate for 17.05, followed by radio silence. Eventually the electronic boards showed a 21.20 departure - but suddenly Tannoy Teresa was on air and sorry. Take no notice - repeat, no notice - of electronic messages: reality was chalked on a board by duty free. Reality was 22.30. Sorry about that. The road back was a sorry one, too."Sorry," said our jovial pilot, "two snowflakes and everything goes down the drain." Time lost on two two-hour flights: 29 hours.

And so to Luton Parkway railway station in the dark of early evening. Sorry, said the electronic board, Thameslink were down to two trains an hour because of weather conditions and lack of rolling stock. Sorry, the words of Tannoy Tanya, echoed from platform two: the 16.01 to Bedford had now been cancelled and the 16.16 would be 38 minutes late. "Thameslink regret any inconvenience to passengers this may cause."

Oh! Sorry - and one more thing - please be careful of the snow and ice on platforms and walkways. Nobody, it seems, has had the time or inclination to do any sweeping up. "I dunno," says my infinitely predictable taxi driver, "I reckon this country's falling apart."

No, not any more than usual - but it just keeps apologising, as though that were enough. There are often decent reasons why things go wrong. The flight out of Luton was three hours late, it transpired, because the crew on an incoming plane had been diverted to Stansted and couldn't make it back through the murk. Most passengers can understand, and sympathise, when a de-icing sub-contractor isn't up to snuff. The trouble isn't life's little deprivations - it's the assumption that saying sorry is enough to turn away wrath.

Meaningless apologies, parroted by rote, are worse than no apology at all. If you're told about "operational difficulties", you want to be told what they are. If you're informed that an outgoing plane is late "owing to the lateness of an incoming plane", you want to know what made it late in the first place. Leave out half the story and all that's left is a redundant, pre-emptive cringe. I quote a single-sentence item from yesterday's Sunday Times, headlined "Sales fear". It reads, in its entirety: "Shoppers have been warned that lack of stock could lead to a premature end of the sales." I'm sorry, we've sold out.

Such things, over years, matter more than we suppose, for they become part of our culture. When Mr Blair issues his new year message about the coming of "Opportunity Britain", we don't salute him, bright eyed, because we remember John Prescott apologising to the Stansted pilgrims about their long night in a deserted airport. We remember the holes in the road, the deserted cones. We are used to being told how desultory our life is - but not why, or how we can make it better.

Telling the Irish we're sorry about the potato famine (before we or they were born) may seem like disarming honesty: but, on examination, it lacks all resonance. The words are easy because they carry no true emotion. Telling taxpayers the same thing about the dome is probably little better. Why apologise for a part- fiasco when it's obvious that any politician with his head screwed on can see nothing worth defending? The words are futile because they carry no weight. The Britain I came back to through the iced needle of Luton is a curious place, no embryo territory of any superstate. There's the illusion of confidence: an economy of continuing strength, a tolerably popular government savouring re-election, energetic young ministers talking modernisation; 2001 could still be a good year. But somehow the underlying mood is bleaker than that.

The hospitals are under intolerable pressure again. Staff shortages (and the weather). Sorry. The schools are thousands of teachers short of a load. Staff shortages (and pay). Sorry. The police are the thinnest blue line against chaos, fear and Ann Widdecombe. Staff shortages, pay, early retirement and that most useless of indefinable concepts, "morale".

Opportunity UK? It would be nice to think so, to ladle out the evidence of cheer and move on. Yet our incomings never seem to fit our outgoings. Operational difficulties at every turn, impending inconvenience at every corner. We are customers devoid of relations - and I'm sorry, I just thought I'd get that off my chest.

I am not, to be clear, picking on the admirable Stelios of easyJet fame, nor on the proud town of Luton. They have both had a dreadful Christmas. On good days, easyJet provide the cheapest, most flexible way for grandfathers of new babies in Barcelona (me) to get out to Catalonia fast and worship at the crib. On bad days, cheapness and flexibility are expected pawns, to be offered up without undue complaint. You get mostly what you pay for, and less ought, in logic, to mean less. What happened? Mundane stuff happened. On the way out, the call to the gate for 17.05, followed by radio silence. Eventually the electronic boards showed a 21.20 departure - but suddenly Tannoy Teresa was on air and sorry. Take no notice - repeat, no notice - of electronic messages: reality was chalked on a board by duty free. Reality was 22.30. Sorry about that. The road back was a sorry one, too."Sorry," said our jovial pilot, "two snowflakes and everything goes down the drain." Time lost on two two-hour flights: 29 hours. And so to Luton Parkway railway station in the dark of early evening. Sorry, said the electronic board, Thameslink were down to two trains an hour because of weather conditions and lack of rolling stock. Sorry, the words of Tannoy Tanya, echoed from platform two: the 16.01 to Bedford had now been cancelled and the 16.16 would be 38 minutes late. "Thameslink regret any inconvenience to passengers this may cause." Oh! Sorry - and one more thing - please be careful of the snow and ice on platforms and walkways. Nobody, it seems, has had the time or inclination to do any sweeping up. "I dunno," says my infinitely predictable taxi driver, "I reckon this country's falling apart." No, not any more than usual - but it just keeps apologising, as though that were enough. There are often decent reasons why things go wrong. The flight out of Luton was three hours late, it transpired, because the crew on an incoming plane had been diverted to Stansted and couldn't make it back through the murk. Most passengers can understand, and sympathise, when a de-icing sub-contractor isn't up to snuff. The trouble isn't life's little deprivations - it's the assumption that saying sorry is enough to turn away wrath. Meaningless apologies, parroted by rote, are worse than no apology at all. If you're told about "operational difficulties", you want to be told what they are. If you're informed that an outgoing plane is late "owing to the lateness of an incoming plane", you want to know what made it late in the first place. Leave out half the story and all that's left is a redundant, pre-emptive cringe. I quote a single-sentence item from yesterday's Sunday Times, headlined "Sales fear". It reads, in its entirety: "Shoppers have been warned that lack of stock could lead to a premature end of the sales." I'm sorry, we've sold out. Such things, over years, matter more than we suppose, for they become part of our culture. When Mr Blair issues his new year message about the coming of "Opportunity Britain", we don't salute him, bright eyed, because we remember John Prescott apologising to the Stansted pilgrims about their long night in a deserted airport. We remember the holes in the road, the deserted cones. We are used to being told how desultory our life is - but not why, or how we can make it better. Telling the Irish we're sorry about the potato famine (before we or they were born) may seem like disarming honesty: but, on examination, it lacks all resonance. The words are easy because they carry no true emotion. Telling taxpayers the same thing about the dome is probably little better. Why apologise for a part- fiasco when it's obvious that any politician with his head screwed on can see nothing worth defending? The words are futile because they carry no weight. The Britain I came back to through the iced needle of Luton is a curious place, no embryo territory of any superstate. There's the illusion of confidence: an economy of continuing strength, a tolerably popular government savouring re-election, energetic young ministers talking modernisation; 2001 could still be a good year. But somehow the underlying mood is bleaker than that. The hospitals are under intolerable pressure again. Staff shortages (and the weather). Sorry. The schools are thousands of teachers short of a load. Staff shortages (and pay). Sorry. The police are the thinnest blue line against chaos, fear and Ann Widdecombe. Staff shortages, pay, early retirement and that most useless of indefinable concepts, "morale". Opportunity UK? It would be nice to think so, to ladle out the evidence of cheer and move on. Yet our incomings never seem to fit our outgoings. Operational difficulties at every turn, impending inconvenience at every corner. We are customers devoid of relations - and I'm sorry, I just thought I'd get that off my chest.

webTitle: Mitterrand's son may be freed from jail on legal technicality

fields.headline: Mitterrand's son may be freed from jail on legal technicality
fields.trailText: The son of the late French president François Mitterrand, who was jailed before Christmas on suspicion of arms dealing and money laundering, could be released within days because of a procedural fault, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The son of the late French president François Mitterrand, who was jailed before Christmas on suspicion of arms dealing and money laundering, could be released within days because of a procedural fault, it emerged yesterday.

Two lawyers acting for other suspects in the case said they had filed an urgent appeal for all proceedings in the case to be dropped, alleging that a key judicial document that led to the arrest of their clients and of Jean-Christophe Mitterrand had been wrongly dated.

Guillaume Weill-Raynal, representing the secretary of the accused arms dealer Pierre Falcone, said the document - a search warrant application, dated July 3 - contained information that the investigating magistrate who signed it could not possibly have known at that time.

"The document is crucial to the prosecution's case and quite plainly it has been deliberately pre-dated," Mr Weill-Raynal said. "This amounts to forgery of public documents and the defence reserves the right to file a formal complaint on those grounds."

The appeal is scheduled to be heard on January 12.

The case, which has threatened to blow the lid off France's shady secret dealings with its former colonies during the Mitterrand era, has dragged in several well-known names, including a top presidential adviser, Jacques Attali; Charles Pasqua, a former interior minister; Jean-Charles Marchiani, a senior state official; and a best-selling author, Paul-Loup Sulitzer.

Mr Mitterrand, who was his father's senior adviser on African affairs from 1986 to 1992, was arrested and jailed earlier this month on suspicion of peddling influence, complicity in arms trafficking, and abuse of funds relating to sales of Russian-made weapons to Angola in the early 1990s.

The deals, worth an estimated £350m, were allegedly orchestrated by Mr Falcone's trading company, Brenco International - which subsequently paid some £1.3m into Jean-Christophe Mitterrand's numbered Swiss bank account.

Police believe the late president's son - whose secretive and controversial role as head of the Elysée palace's "Africa cell" gave him outstanding contacts with a variety of African leaders - played a key part in the Angola deals, and maybe others. Mr Mitterrand has said the money represented fees for legitimate consultancy work.

Mr Weill-Raynal said the contested document had allowed the investigating magistrate, Philippe Courroye, to search the offices of a well-known Paris tax lawyer, Alain Guilloux, and eventually to place Mr Mitterrand and several other suspects under investigation.

But, the lawyer alleged, it contained evidence that the magistrate could only have known about after the offices were searched.

A Paris appeals court last week rejected a request from Mr Mitterrand, 54, to be released on bail. His brother, Gilbert Mitterrand, a Socialist MP, said yesterday that the investigating magistrates had "invented a new crime - bearing a famous name".

He said the magistrates had "taken some extremely serious steps in a case that is utterly devoid of evidence as far as my brother is concerned."
