webTitle: G2: Claire Armitstead on the Archers

fields.headline: Serial farming
fields.standfirst:
On January 1 1951, the Archers first went on air, and for half a century many Britons have grown up with a daily dose of fairytale farming. For Claire Armitstead, the soap links three generations of her family across two continents, despite the fictional lives of Ambridge bearing little or no resemblance to her own. So why does the show exert such a hold over us?

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: On January 1 1951, the Archers first went on air, and for half a century many Britons have grown up with a daily dose of fairytale farming. For Claire Armitstead, the soap links three generations of her family across two continents, despite the fictional lives of Ambridge bearing little or no resemblance to her own. So why does the show exert such a hold over us?
fields.body:
So they're 50, those country folk whose everyday tales provide a ghostly link across two continents and between three generations of my family. One of those generations is now as much a memory as Grace Archer, Mark Hebden and poor old Jethro Larkin. You see, my mother died 13 years ago of breast cancer (how I cried when Ruth found that lump).

The family connection goes much further back than that, though. I was born four months after the terrible twins, Shula and Kenton Archer, so I can calibrate my life against their fallings out and in. It is true that I don't have a farm to squabble over; I haven't lost my husband to a tree; I didn't, for that matter, have a twin - but what are the details of mortality when set against the great fiction of parity in age? I remember the death of Grace Archer as if it were yesterday: all that shouting; the roar of the flames; the frantic neighing of horses.

Well, truth be told, I don't remember it at all. It was passed down to me by my mother, as part of the family anecdotage - alongside fond recollections of how I lost my first tooth, or when my brother locked himself in the loo all day. In Nigeria, where my mother found herself with two small children, the Archers represented a connection with home in those unimaginable days before email, when telegrams were reserved for births and deaths, and a letter would take a fortnight to arrive.

My father's connection with the series was more tangential. He never had much time for radio, but he once wrote a Nigerian version of the Archers to encourage farmers, in what we loftily referred to as "the bush", to adopt modern farming methods. Once a week, both my parents would retreat to the study - he to write his scripts, and she to pen crinkly blue airmail letters to the grannies.

This was in the early 70s, at pretty much the same time that the real Archers abandoned its founding principle to educate. Since my father worked in the cigarette industry, he was - with an irony he would never have recognised - presumably exhorting those poor, benighted farmers in Nigeria to grow bigger, more lucrative tobacco crops.

It is an irony that certainly would be recognised by the latterday Archers cognoscenti, for isn't BSE - the destroyer of Ambridge's cattle wealth - the product of an over-intensive farming industry that was directly encouraged by Godfrey Baseley, the first producer of the Archers, in his revolutionary new agriprop programme? As my mother often told me, when the first episode of the Archers went out, on January 1 1951, Britain was still in rationing, with farmers being exhorted to produce more, by whatever means, in order to feed the nation.

It's not that I attribute any guilt to Baseley (any more than I blame my father for the evils of the multinational tobacco industry). It is just a poignant reminder that simply by surviving in this frantic, mouse-brained world of ours, you become part of history - and history is never innocent.

I began listening regularly to the Archers as a student in the late 70s. My flatmate - a clever, agricultural student - regarded those struggling tenant farmers, the Grundys, as clowns, and they delighted her with their incompetence. At that time, Eddie and Joe were at the bottom of the heap, with the gentleman farmer Brian Aldridge at the top, the good yeoman Phil Archer at the centre and the scatterbrained Tony Archer and his wayward wife, Pat, drifting somewhere below the middle. It was a comfortably conservative model of a society that knew its heirs from its disgraces.

Today, the Grundys are finished, and we see it as a terrible injustice. Phil - the middle-scale owner-farmer - is lost in agricultural limbo (the only way to save his farm, he is told, is to specialise, intensify or to sub-contract. Where does that leave the countryside? Where the next generation?). You can't look to landowning Brian for a way out - he is little more than a puppet, controlled by an asset-stripping conglomerate.

It is Tony and Pat (particularly yoghurt queen Pat) who are emerging as the success story: the waywardness of the 70s has become the flexibility of the millennial marketplace. My old flatmate - if she works in agriculture at all - is probably into organic vegetables. She would barely recognise the orthodoxy she once represented.

A soap, though, doesn't simply exist in a historical space; it provides a way of tallying that space with our own personal experience. I don't listen to the Archers every day - it drifts through my consciousness along with the ironing and the tax return, which always becomes urgent at about the time that the first lambs arrive at Home Farm.

But I feel that I know exactly what is going on, and I am following Ruth's cancer plotline avidly. It is oddly reassuring to be informed that the side-effects of chemotherapy are so much more controllable today than they were when my mother gave it up as a fate, literally, worse than death. (You will notice that I am suffering from a well-known symptom of Archersitis - my primary identification is with the characters whose stories most closely reflect my own.)

It is only when you stand back and look at what this information actually represents - at best a case study, at worst a nice solo turn for the actors involved in playing the characters - that the mendacity of the whole exercise becomes clear. But whose mendacity is it? Why should any soap (a word, incidentally, not invented in 1951) be burdened with representing the world? Does the fact that the Archers runs in daily doses - rather like a chat over the garden fence with the neighbours, only with a repeat in case you missed it the first time - mean that it is aspiring to the condition of "real life"?

You certainly wouldn't think so if you happened to have listened in to the preparations for the Christmas show, which traditionally unfold like a rather long and woozy cast party, but this year seem to have acquired Shakespearean pretensions, with tiffing lovers and revenge capers.

The chief quality any long-running soap opera has in common with its listeners is an ability to move with the times. The producers of the Archers have certainly bought into post-modern archness. They play a mean hand in the ratings war, with dramatic deaths, shower scenes and even guest appearances by royalty to offset their continuing earnest approach to the issues of the day. Sometimes their plotlines seem to be driven by pure mischief (as when, just as England was settling into Thatcherism, Pat Archer forsook the Express for the Guardian); and sometimes the old propaganda muscle twitches (note the uproar that greeted Ambridge's response to Tony Blair's countryside policy speech early last year).

But those are mere details alongside the one immutable fact - the Archers, in real time directly related to our own, is 50 years old. It's tempting to mock, and yet this corny old programme, showing a fairytale rural world, has somehow acquired the right to represent not what we are, but what we would like to think we are. As a Londoner, I buy deep-frozen New Zealand lamb and make summer pudding in winter. But in Ambridge, there will always be lambing season and blackberry-picking. That is how we like it.

The story so far ... 50 years of life in Ambridge
Oliver Burkeman

1950s

As the last gasps of feudalism give way to commercial farming, the squire of the Ambridge estate sells up. One Daniel Archer buys Brookfield Farm, while his son and daughter-in-law, Jack and Peggy, snap up the Bull, a local watering-hole. An eventful decade follows, featuring - among other fine moments - the crashing of a jet aeroplane into a nearby field and the accidental shooting dead of a poacher by Dan's cousin, Tom Forrest. But it's the tragic, 1955 death of young, beautiful Grace Fairbrother in a stable fire that stuns most listeners and plunges her suitor, Lothario-of-the-haystacks, Phil Archer - another of Dan's progeny - into mourning.

1960s

Phil buys his first herd of cows, takes over Allard's farm, moves there with his new wife, Jill, and thus begins his lengthy transformation from thrusting representative of the agricultural future to crotchety old farmer. Sid Perks arrives in Ambridge to work for self-made businessman Jack Woolley, who later buys the estate. Jack Archer's daughter Jennifer gives birth to her first child, by a local farmhand, and Sid's new wife Polly suffers a miscarriage after she's caught up in a raid at the post office. Unconnectedly, a spate of mysterious arson attacks is eventually attributed to her father, Frank Mead, who is hospitalised.

1970s

A highly localised economic boom strikes Ambridge: Jack Woolley opens his Grey Gables country club; Sid and Polly take over the Bull and hire promiscuous barmaid Caroline Bone, while the enterprising Sid also provides the basis for many a plotline by restarting the village cricket club. But things turn nasty when Jack is assaulted during a robbery, then suffers a heart attack on hearing that his wife, Valerie, wants a divorce. Kenton - son of Phil and Jill, twin brother of local horse enthusiast Shula, and brother of young farmer David and airhead Elizabeth - leaves to join the merchant navy. Garrulous rogue Eddie Grundy moves in with his father Joe at Grange Farm.

1980s

As greed-is-good ultracapitalism sweeps the rest of the country, Ambridge folk concentrate on getting married (Eddie to Clarrie Larkin; Neil Carter to the already-pregnant Susan Horrobin; Sid, after Polly's car crashes into a milk tanker, to newcomer Kathy Holland), or just having affairs (Kathy Perks with local policeman Dave Barry, and Caroline with businessman-farmer Brian Aldridge, Jennifer's husband). Useless dairy farmer Mike Tucker is declared bankrupt, and busybody Linda Snell moves into Ambridge Hall.

1990s/2000

Events progress at breakneck speed, tragically breaking several necks in the process. Shady Scot Cameron Fraser purchases the estate, gets Elizabeth pregnant then abandons her in a motorway service station; she has a traumatising abortion. Jack Woolley marries Peggy Archer; Guy Pemberton becomes the new owner of the estate and the new love of Caroline, who - despite being seriously injured in the horse-car collision which kills Shula's husband Mark Hebden - manages to romance him and marry him, whereupon he dies of a heart attack.

Shula, after years of IVF treatment, gives birth to Daniel, her son by her dead husband, and Borcheshire's most luckless post office is raided again, this time by local good-for-nothing Clive Horrobin, whose sister Susan (now Carter) is jailed for six months for harbouring him, sparking national outrage. Ethnic diversity makes a token appearance in the form of lawyer Usha Gupta, whose partner Richard Locke ruins things by having an affair with Shula.

Tragedy strikes as John Archer - son of grouchy farmer Tony Archer - is killed when his tractor overturns; his brother Tom gets into no end of trouble for trampling crops on Brian's farm. Sid has an affair with line-dancing enthusiast Jolene then dumps Kathy for her, general fecklessness forces the Grundys temporarily into a Borchester tower block, and the vexed question of which Archers are going to inherit Brookfield splits Phil's family down the middle. It is also rumoured that, in between all this, some farming was undertaken.

Sid has an affair with line-dancing enthusiast Jolene then dumps Kathy for her, general fecklessness forces the Grundys temporarily into a Borchester tower block, and the vexed question of which Archers are going to inherit Brookfield splits Phil's family down the middle. It is also rumoured that, in between all this, some farming was undertaken.

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Gulf defence pact signed
fields.body:
Gulf defence pact signed

Six Gulf nations signed their region's first defence pact yesterday, pledging to come to each other's aid in the event of attack.

The pact comes a decade after the Gulf war, when the six - Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Bahrain, Qatar, Oman and the United Arab Emirates - realised their small armies could not do much alone to ward off an adversary such as Iraq.

In practice, the area will still rely on America for its defence.
AP, Bahrain

Local elections in Pakistan

Pakistanis went to the polls yesterday in staggered local elections that the country's military rulers say will be the first step towards a return to democracy.

Seats have been allocated for women and the poor - a change the military says will help create a more egalitarian country.

Seats in 18 of 106 districts were voted for yesterday. The remaining local elections will be take place in the next few months.
AP, Islamabad

Iranian admits ordering deaths

A former head of the Iranian intelligence ministry confessed on Saturday to ordering the murders of liberal dissidents, in the third closed-door hearing of a trial.

The official news agency IRNA said Mostafa Kazemi, a former head of internal security, "confessed to his role as the mastermind of the killings of writers and intellectuals".

Eighteen men, including secret police agents, are accused of the 1998 murder of four dissidents.
Reuters, Tehran

Blast destroys Corsican office

A bomb blast destroyed offices at a government environment office in the Corsican town of Corte, police said yesterday.

No one was injured in the blast, which police said caused F500,000 (£48,000) worth of damage. Corsican nationalists claimed responsibility for three previous attacks on the building.
Reuters, Ajaccio

Elephant keeps victim's body

A wild elephant pulled a man from a tree, trampled him to death and for two weeks has refused to part with the corpse, police in India said yesterday.

The man was attacked after climbing the tree to escape a herd of wild eleph- ants rampaging through his village in Assam.
Reuters, Guwahati

Giant carpet on the move

After three years of work by 500 weavers, Iran has shipped a £3.5m hand-woven carpet to Oman.

Mostafa Qannadha, director of the Iran Carpet Company, said the 5,000 square metre carpet was shipped at the weekend to Muscat, where it will be placed in a mosque.
AP, Tehran

webTitle: Letters: Lorna - the writer's cut

fields.headline: Lorna - the writer's cut
fields.trailText: As Trevor Walter (Letters, December 30) will presumably recognise, the plot of my TV adaptation of Lorna Doone follows the book in every major respect.
fields.body:
As Trevor Walter (Letters, December 30) will presumably recognise, the plot of my TV adaptation of Lorna Doone follows the book in every major respect. It hardly seems necessary to point out that the programme lasts two and a half hours, the book 650 pages or so - inevitably there are omissions and changes that make the film accessible to a modern audience. Any other creative decision would be impossible and even absurd.

If Mr Walter misses the things that no reasonable TV or film adaptation could include, I'm pleased to say he can still find them in the novel. Given that overall my version follows Blackmore's story faithfully, I am bemused and offended by the implication that his "sound moral purpose" has in some way been subverted.
Adrian Hodges
Screenwriter, Lorna Doone

webTitle: Letters: Sentencing and prison life

fields.headline: Prison only breeds hate
fields.trailText: Politicians should confront the fact that sending more people to prison for longer has little effect on the crime rate (Top judge attacks prison 'cancer', December 28).
fields.body:
 Politicians should confront the fact that sending more people to prison for longer has little effect on the crime rate (Top judge attacks prison 'cancer', December 28). It may keep them off the streets for a time, but when they come out they are likely to have lost their home and job, to feel resentful and hence to reoffend. Prison is the ultimate social exclusion; it splits up families, which politicians claim they want to keep together. Crime prevention strategy should be a combination of social measures, to reduce the pressures towards crime and increase motivation to keep within the law; and security measures - but covering the country with CCTV cameras is no substitute for personal supervision (station staff, park keepers, shop assistants).

The response to crime should start with help for the victim. Offenders should be required to apologise and make reparation, whether through compensation, work for the victim or the community or by cooperating with whatever will help them avoid crime in future: skills courses, anger management etc. Various forms of this victim-centred "restorative justice" are being used in many countries, and research shows high satisfaction ratings. Coercion and deprivation of liberty should be used as a last resort.
Martin Wright
London

 I have just been released from the "Hate Factory", as Wandsworth prison is known by inmates, which last year was given 12 months to reform itself. My experience only strengthens one's determination to have the whole Victorian dungeon closed down. It will be interesting to see the conclusions of the BBC documentary shot last year and what degree of truth the authorities allowed the camera crew to be witness to.

It is horrifying to consider that this centre of daily human rights abuses is right in the heart of our capital city and an appalling reflection of the general apathy and ignorance of a society completely out of touch with our disastrous criminal justice system.
Duncan Williams
London

webTitle: Letters: Sport commentator David Coleman

fields.headline: Sporting life
fields.trailText: We are glad Frank Keating shares our appreciation of David Coleman, who has stamped his authority on sports commentating for nearly 50 years (A legend to the bitter end, December 30).
fields.body:
 We are glad Frank Keating shares our appreciation of David Coleman, who has stamped his authority on sports commentating for nearly 50 years (A legend to the bitter end, December 30). But I am saddened by the growth of a myth that David's departure from the BBC is somehow reluctant and unsung. David announced two years ago that his then contract with the BBC would be his last. Although that contract is coming to an end, we have made it clear the door will always be open to talk about further projects. To suggest the BBC would peremptorily sever its relationship with such a distinguished and long-serving commentator is untrue and unkind.
Peter Salmon
BBC director of sport

 David Coleman has managed to retain work with the BBC way beyond his sell-by date. For a long time now his commentaries have not been acceptable; his efforts in the Olympics were embarrassing. Had he resigned with his skills intact, his going would have been marked with respect and gratitude, by both broadcasters and public. He will be appropriately remembered by the eponymous column in Private Eye.
David Tomlinson
Disley, Cheshire

webTitle: Letters: Jubilee 2000

fields.headline: Jubilee debt
fields.trailText: The achievement of Jubilee 2000 (Leaders, December 30) is all the more remarkable if the humble origins of what was to become a worldwide movement are recalled.
fields.body:
The achievement of Jubilee 2000 (Leaders, December 30) is all the more remarkable if the humble origins of what was to become a worldwide movement are recalled. It was founded at the University of Keele in 1990 by Martin Dent following discussions with a group of students interested in finding ways of helping poorer countries.

Dent's pioneering work, and the efforts of Bill Peters, (without any public financial support) laid the foundations on which Ann Pettifor and her small team have subsequently built magnificently. Happily, Martin Dent's great contribution to debt relief was recognised in 2000 by the award of an OBE and of an honorary doctorate by the University of Keele.
(Prof) William Tordoff
Chapel-en-le Frith, Derbs

webTitle: Rawlings hails successor

fields.headline: Rawlings hails successor
fields.trailText: The Ghanaian president, Jerry Rawlings, wished his newly elected successor, the opposition leader John Kufuor, well yesterday, a week before he steps down after two decades in power.
fields.body:
The Ghanaian president, Jerry Rawlings, wished his newly elected successor, the opposition leader John Kufuor, well yesterday, a week before he steps down after two decades in power.

At a ceremony marking the anniversary of his 1981 coup, Mr Rawlings pledged to do everything possible to ensure a smooth transition. "Let me seize this opportunity to congratulate Mr Kufuor on his election," he said in an address broadcast to the nation.

"I wish him well and hope he and his colleagues will be able to deliver their promises."

Mr Kufuor's victory in the December 28 presidential run-off over the vice-president, John Atta Mills, marks the first real transfer of power through the ballot box in the west African country. A two-term limit on presidents prevented Mr Rawlings contesting the election himself.

Ghana's history since independence in 1957 - political instability, army rule, bloody purges, socialist central planning, democracy and free mar ket reforms - has mirrored the experience of many other African countries.

The election, following a peaceful transfer of power through the ballot box in fellow west African state Senegal last March, brought good news to the continent at the end of a turbulent year in many places.

Mr Rawlings first seized power in 1979 as a junior army officer. He handed back power to an elected president later that year but launched a second coup in 1981 when his successor appeared unable to stem resurgent corruption.

webTitle: Two-year's jump from world's tallest towers

fields.headline: Two-year's jump from world's tallest towers
fields.trailText: Eleven skydivers from five countries yesterday leapt from the world's tallest skyscrapers just before 2000 ended - and landed in 2001.
fields.body:
Eleven skydivers from five countries yesterday leapt from the world's tallest skyscrapers just before 2000 ended - and landed in 2001.

The jump off the 390-metre (1,483ft) Petronas Twin Towers in Kuala Lumpur was fraught with difficulty. The biggest worry, however, had been the threat of a thunderstorm.

In an earlier practice jump, skydivers from the United States, Germany, Sweden and Saudi Arabia jumped off the towers, setting what they claimed was a new world record for the greatest number of people to parachute off a building.

In Australia, the focus of celebrations was the Sydney Harbour Bridge, where around 80,000 fireworks were released.

Record-breaking was a common theme around Asia as it welcomed 2001. Students from China, Japan and South Korean planned to set a new one by tripping thousands of coloured dominos in a Beijing auditorium.

While official celebrations went on at the millennium monument in Beijing, Falun Gong protesters turned out in Tiananmen Square as the banned spiritual movement took its battle against Beijing into a third year. They were swiftly arrested. Earlier yesterday at the Great Wall outside Beijing, 500 Chinese couples celebrated a mass millennium wedding.

Taiwan marked New Year's Day by lifting a 51-year-old ban on voyages from tiny Taiwanese-controlled islets near the Chinese coast to the mainland. Supporters look on the first legal voyage to the mainland today - along a route taken by smugglers for years - as a step toward easing tensions with Beijing.

The New Year in some countries, however, was less than festive.

In Pakistan, Shabab-e-Milli, the youth wing of the Islamic country's most organised religious group, the Jamaat-e-Islami, warned revellers against partying because it was contrary to the tenets of Islam, the newspaper Nawa-e-Waqat reported.

Policemen in mainly Muslim Bangladesh conducted a similar crack-down on revelry.

webTitle: Letters: Policing hooliganism

fields.headline: The view from the terraces
fields.trailText: Like every genuine travelling England fan, I applaud the proposals of Lord Bassam's committee to stamp out hooliganism, including using fans as stewards (Radical plan to tackle England's hooligans, December 29).
fields.body:
 Like every genuine travelling England fan, I applaud the proposals of Lord Bassam's committee to stamp out hooliganism, including using fans as stewards (Radical plan to tackle England's hooligans, December 29). Self-policing has been requested by genuine fans for years, but the response from both the FA and government was to ignore any approaches then throw their hands up in despair after every incident. While genuine fans tried their best to distance themselves from hooligans, the police repeatedly put out scurrilous press releases about travelling hooligans which often caused problems. Nothing much changes as a new edict accompanies propagandist cant regarding far-right conspiracies and racist chanting.

I have stated on many occasions that the riot in Marseille was wholly avoidable and commonsense stewarding would have prevented it. However, for stewarding to work, both the FA and police must hand over some of the control and information to steward fans. They will face huge initial problems and need to tread a very fine line to ensure their credibility holds up, as some attitudes cannot be reasoned with except with a smack in the teeth. When that happens, if history repeats itself, they will find the politicians throwing up their hands in horror.
Colin Ward
Author, Steaming In, Armed For the Match etc

 "In many respects the behaviour at England football matches mirrors that demonstrated in high streets every weekend... It is hostile, anti-social and dismissive of all things not stereotypically English." (Bassam report). What chance for improvement when William Hague's party and his tame newspapers appear to promote such behaviour as positively virtuous?
Meurig Parri
Talysarn, Gwynedd

 I support Kate Hoey for having the courage to open up a debate which has been taboo for too long (Hillsborough families attack sports minister over backing for terraces, December 23). All Ms Hoey asked for was that the new evidence available is looked at to see if it is applicable to the British game. She has listened to representation from supporters from around the UK and decided to look at the facts with an open mind. It is undemocratic to stifle legitimate debate. One wonders what the FA and Premier League are so frightened of.
Mark Longden
Chair, Independent Man Utd Supporters Association

 On May 29 1985 I stood on a dilapidated terrace in Brussels and witnessed the deaths of 39 people as fellow Liverpool fans, fuelled by a high-octane mixture of nationalism and alcohol, ran amok. On Monday April 17 1989, I attended work to find that the quiet 19-year-old I had lunched with for the previous 12 months had been crushed to death at Hillsborough. The Taylor report resulted in changes that have considerably reduced the chances of history repeating itself. Perhaps Mr Hopper (Letters, December 27) can explain how the excesses of human nature have changed to such an extent over the last 11 years that we should abandon the bitter lessons of Burnden Park, Ibrox, Heysel and Hillsborough and reintroduce terracing.
PD Hughes
Warrington

 I am allowed to watch football from the terraces by virtue of my team (Cambridge United) being in Division Two, and so far too undistinguished to constitute any kind of health hazard to those present (other than decapitation by misplaced shots). I have done so for 24 years. What killed the Hillsborough 96 was not terraces, but incompetent police and perimeter fences. What Kate Hoey suggests is only what I and many thousands of others already do in perfect safety.
Bill Hawkes
Whitstable, Kent

webTitle: Letters: The monarchy

fields.headline: More honoured in the breach...
fields.trailText: As one of your contributors who holds no candle to the establishment, I think Mark Lawson (Comment, December 30) should hang his head in shame.
fields.body:
 As one of your contributors who holds no candle to the establishment, I think Mark Lawson (Comment, December 30) should hang his head in shame. His rubbishing of the Queen's speech for saying what she believes rather than, like her government, saying what spin doctors tell her the great British public want to hear, is pathetic. Her desire to live by the precepts of Jesus, the young dissident rabbi (however imperfectly, like all who try) has never been fashionable, but Mail, Telegraph, yes and Guardian readers might find it wholesome medicine.
Rev Dr Paul Oestreicher
Coventry

 We read through your articles about the honours list with growing astonishment. To find no mention whatsoever of the knighthood awarded to John Sulston beggars belief. Surely this honour, in recognition of his team's extraordinary accomplishment in completing the first draft of the human genome, merited prominent coverage? We had thought that, at the beginning of the 21st century, science had taken its proper place as part of our culture. Evidently there is still some way to go.
Laurence & Deirdre Smaje
London
zdk40@uk.uumail.com

 Isn't it time we dropped the "Order of the British Empire", 50 years since there was an empire? It is an insult to say we are giving you recognition, but it has to be according to your rank as it was 50 years ago. Fraser Kemp MP produced a 10-minute bill last year and had a majority of 153 to 58 to replace it by an Order of the United Kingdom.
Doug Lawrence
Brighton

 I was disappointed that the worst thing you could find to say about the new year's honours list (Leader, December 30) was that it was "innocuous", on the grounds that previous lists have been much worse. Harrison Birtwistle receiving a gong does not "improve" the honours system, while Jim Davidson receiving a gong does not makes it "worse": it is the principle of the system that is at fault, not the names on any one list. It is time for it to receive an early (order of the) bath.
Glenn Archibald
Oxford
glenn.archibald@libertysurf.co.uk

webTitle: Leader: Farewell, 20th century

fields.headline: Farewell, 20th century
fields.standfirst: Even pedants accept that its days are done
fields.trailText: Even pedants accept that its days are done.
fields.body:
A year ago, along with much of the country and much of the world, the Guardian bade farewell to the 20th century and the second millennium and welcomed the dawn of the 21st and the third. But amid the celebration, a small group stayed silent. We were witnessing, these people argued, a historic global miscalculation. The opening of a new century ought to be marked at the end of a hundred years, the start of a new millennium at the end of a thousand; and that meant the whole operation was being staged 12 months too soon.

Such people were fiercely maligned, and saddled with designations such as "pedant" - once, in more scholarly times, a term of approval, but not so now. Prominent among their champions was a resident of Hythe in Kent called Denise Rayner who in May 1999, armed only with yellowing copies of late 19th-century newspapers, persuaded a meeting of townspeople to carry a resolution "that Hythe shows its independence and common sense by greeting the 21st century and the third millennium on the correct date of January 1 2001 and not a year earlier". No other municipality followed Hythe's lead.

And yet, as the year progressed, the dissenters' case seemed to grow stronger. In the final months, powerful new voices declared themselves on the side of those who asserted that the junketing took place too early, while newspapers hitherto sceptical began to assert almost as a matter of course that the choice of the date had been wrong. In her Christmas message, the Queen appeared to suggest that the birth of a new millennium should be celebrated on the anniversary of Christ's birth - Christmas Day. As eminent an authority as the science writer Arthur C Clarke endorsed the case for marking the change at this new year rather than at the last one. Cuba has all along stuck out for today as the true moment of transformation, while our own Royal Observatory, which certainly ought to know, has tried to reconcile the two sides by describing the year 2000 as Millennium Year - the 12 months which prepared the way for the new millennium.

We have also heard the posthumous voice of Victorian England. As a piece in G2 pointed out last week, they saluted the end of the 19th century and the birth of the 20th on the night of December 31 1900. The poet laureate, Alfred Austin, produced a (putrid) poem to mark the occasion. A century launched on the final day of 1900 but allegedly completed a year ago must therefore have been the first century ever to have its life cut short at 99 years.

This debate is now essentially over, in that those who for the last 12 months have been marooned in a different century and millennium from the worldwide majority are this morning reunited with the rest of the human race. No doubt they will have celebrated last night with just as much fervour and alcohol as others did more publicly 12 months ago. That they could not mark the occasion by opening a dome or running a wall of fire down the Thames will hardly have spoiled the occasion for them.

webTitle: Letters: The national lottery

fields.headline: Not-for-tax lottery
fields.trailText: So the lights have at last gone out on the dome (Letters, December 30) and while Sir Richard Branson licks his wounds on his Caribbean island and Dianne Thompson of Camelot spends quality time with her family, the lottery's single biggest winner sits smiling in No 11 Downing Street.
fields.body:
 So the lights have at last gone out on the dome (Letters, December 30) and while Sir Richard Branson licks his wounds on his Caribbean island and Dianne Thompson of Camelot spends quality time with her family, the lottery's single biggest winner sits smiling in No 11 Downing Street. The lottery has never been long out of the headlines, yet the smash and grab raid by the UK taxman is unreported.

From each £1 ticket brought by Joe Public, 12.5p goes to Gordon Brown. In the year ending March 1998, Camelot handed over £708m to him. Over the next seven years at least £5bn will paid out by punters to fill the Treasury coffers. No wonder Lord Burns, a former permanent secretary to the Treasury, was so keen to ensure the minimum of risk to the chancellor's cash cow.

If the government is really committed to the maximum amount going to good causes, Gordon Brown could begin by abolishing the lottery tax and giving all the current tax take to good causes. This would pay for five more domes or, better still, fund the National Deaf Children's Society for 1,000 years. So come on Gordon, hand it over - it would be a heck of a lot more than Branson had hoped to achieve with a not-for-profit lottery.
Mark Astarita
Deputy chief executive,
National Deaf Children's Society
mark@ndcs.org.uk

 Jonathan Glancey (Reach for the skies, Saturday Review, December 30) rightly praises Tate Modern. However, it is wrong to contrast its visitor numbers (3m) with the dome's (6m). Entrance to the dome was expensive (£20) while the Tate is free.
Peter Evans
Norwich
peter_evans@onetel.net.uk

webTitle: Letters: Lesbian cheat

fields.headline: Lesbian cheat
fields.trailText: I cannot share Arthur C Clarke's dreams of "the modification of many planetary environments to make them suitable for human habitation" (G2, December 29).
fields.body:
 I cannot share Arthur C Clarke's dreams of "the modification of many planetary environments to make them suitable for human habitation" (G2, December 29). I see the future as being a time when everyone on earth will be obliged to take steps to make our own planet "suitable for human habitation".
Dr AD Laurence
Moss, Norway

 The only thing I could think of that might be wrong with the poster of the lesbian embrace (Letters, December 30) was the nagging suspicion that the two women in the picture might turn out not to be lesbians after all. That really would be offensive.
Catherine Rose
Olney, Bucks

 If we have to suffer advertising overloaded with sexual themes, I am delighted to see some gay imagery to balance the rampant heterosexuality. Unfortunately, I still can't work out what they 're selling.
Rev Geoff Reid
Bradford

 Although I left Bristol over 40 years ago, I still have difficulty sorting "area" from "aerial" (Letters, December 30). However, I find I can still formulate a question in the way I did as a child - "Yer, were dist thee get that to?" or "Theess gottle be kidding I, asn't ee". Thank you for reminding me of my heritage.
Betty Bezant
Birmingham

 My granddaughter is a Bristolian and a grrl; her mum is a Londoner and a girl.
Soo Brookstone
London

 Barry Thorpe (Letters, December 30) misses the point: "in terms of" is a colloquial recognition of social complexity. At the end of the day, "must surely be" is far more irritating a phrase and only equalled by his inappropriate application of the word spatchcock.
Richard Turpin
Liverpool

webTitle: TV and Radio: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Au Revoir Les Enfants | The Truman Show | Life is Beautiful
fields.body:
Au Revoir Les Enfants
(Louis Malle, 1987)
6pm, FilmFour

Malle's restrained and moving autobiographical tale is set in a Roman Catholic school in occupied France. Gaspard Manesse plays the 12-year-old Julien, who is deputed to look after an introverted new boy, Jean (Raphael Fejtö). After a halting start a close friendship develops, and Jean's secret is revealed: he is Jewish, and is being hidden from the Germans by the headmaster (Philippe Morier-Genoud). A sombre, delicate film that ranks alongside Malle's other masterpiece about the occupation, Lacombe Lucien.

The Truman Show
(Peter Weir, 1998)
6pm, Sky Premier

For those who find Jim Carrey a little hard to take, this is an eye-opener: his Truman Burbank is played straight and is all the better for it. Truman is unaware that he is the subject of a round-the-clock TV show, and that his friends and family are in fact actors playing roles. But doubts start to form, and he has to fight for his freedom. A sharp satire on the media-mad 90s that is emotionally stirring too.

Life Is Beautiful
(Roberto Benigni, 1997)
8pm, FilmFour

Can you make a joke out of the Holocaust? Benigni thinks so, and his effort met with both critical ire and Oscars for best foreign language film, best actor and best music. He starts with a light pastoral romance as his Guido woos and weds the haughty Dora (Nicoletta Braschi); the film then elides into the horror of the concentration camps, always leavened, though, by Guido, who protects his son by presenting it all as a big, daft game.

48 Hours
(Walter Hill, 1982)
10.10pm, Sky Cinema

A frenetic, funny tale of a mismatched duo: bad-tempered, gravel-throated cop Nick Nolte, and - making an inspired debut - Eddie Murphy as a fast-mouthed con on 48 hours' leave from the slammer. They are hunting an exceptionally nasty pair of villains through the deadly streets of San Francisco, but spend as much time cursing each other as looking for the bad guys.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Weekend TV

fields.headline: The girl can't help it
fields.trailText: Monica's Postcards | Snow In Japan | Lenny Henry In Pieces
fields.body:
'I have lived here all my life," Monica Lewinsky told us in Monica's Postcards (Sunday, Channel 5). "And there are still some things I haven't seen." Of course, Bill Clinton's penis isn't among those things, but throughout her exploration of America, she didn't really mention that for which she is most famous - her doings in the Oval Office.

In fact, for her travelogue charting the diversity and variety of her country, she only went from New York to California and back again. (And presumably she was in New York before Hillary got elected as senator, otherwise she would have ended up burnt at the stake in Times Square.) There wasn't even a passing nod to all those states in middle America whose names start with vowels.

Yet for all her not talking about her claim to fame, it came up at every opportunity. By opting to ride on an "antique rollercoaster" with a man in a T-shirt printed with the legend "Thrill Rider", Monica demonstrated her distinct lack of awareness before noting "There's a sign that says 'Stay seated'. As if I am going to stand up." A motto to live your life by, apparently.

Then, it was off to her favourite bar where she met some friends in a bonkette. Keeping her New Year's resolution, she didn't slide under the table eagerly but soon enough she was eagerly fingering balls. She was only hosting the bar bingo but we knew what she was thinking.

Yosemite National Park was next, where she fretted the bears might steal her food (they'd have a fight on their hands by the looks of things), then it was on to Los Angeles where she drove round in a Cadillac with a licence plate spelling Pinkky. Either Monica is exceptionally dim and the producer was deliberately trying to humiliate her or she is exceptionally trusting and the producer was deliberately trying to humiliate her. Place your bets.

Whichever the case, the problem with Monica's "I'm just a presenter" demeanour is that she so obviously isn't. She lacks the wit or skill of even the most amateurish presenter, and as we know her as the woman who went down on Clinton, everything she says or does is - rightly or wrongly - informed by knowledge of that act. From her assertion that she has been on "the scariest ride in America" to the moment hot rocks were put on her face at a beauty spa, every act is filtered through one she performed years ago. Out damn spot? Will this dress never be clean? She should be so lucky.

In an altogether more serious and interesting travelogue, Snow In Japan (Saturday, Channel 4), Tall Jon Snow was investigating whether Japan can recover from its recession and what price its people will pay for such a restoration.

Travelling from Osaka - "the Birmingham of Japan" apparently (though that seemed a bit cruel) - to Tokyo, Snow and his chum and translator, Mayu, uncovered the soul of Japan. They bumped into some religious people in white cagoules and matching jockstraps, saw the ashamed unemployed living under bridges, and encountered ineffectual politicians not one of them younger than the Queen Mum.

A fascinating and in-depth - though perhaps not in-depth enough - exploration of Japan, once seen as the apogee of the global economy, Snow's progress took him from a farm where huge government subsidies fertilise the land to a view of yet another international airport, the construction of which is designed to kick-start the economy. "It's completely insane", Snow noted eloquently, musing on the failings of the patrician state. And on his travels, the only man taller than Tall Jon was in a red jacket. He was on a horse.

Following the trend set by the latest offerings from Victoria Wood and Jennifer Saunders, Lenny Henry In Pieces (Saturday, BBC1) was disappointing, though the evening brightened up considerably thanks to Alistair McGowan's 2000 Impressions (Saturday, BBC1). With a smashing spoof of Big Brother, a cracking impression of Peggy Mitchell and the (slightly overrated) Posh and Becks, McGowan and Ronni Ancona provided proof that there is rather amusing mainstream comedy out there.

And is it because his surname sounds vaguely seasonal that Dale Winton is ubiquitous on BBC1? It would seem there is no escape from the Michelle Collins of light entertainment. New year, same old camp nonsense.

webTitle: G2: A country diary

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: The Lake District
fields.trailText: The Lake District
fields.body:
Today's diary exactly completes 50 years of my contributions from the loveliest corner of England, the Lake District. The first one appeared in the Manchester Guardian, as it was then, in the first days of 1951, when George VI was on the throne and Clement Attlee the Prime Minister. It was two years before Tony Blair was born.

There have been 1,300 of my diaries altogether - most of them about hills, sunlit snows, clouds suddenly swept away from a ridge, and the dale, far below, leaping up at you, exciting climbing and skiing days, long days walking the tops, mountain views, golden eagles, red deer and many other important things. Hundreds of people have written to me about these simple pieces and their letters encouraged me to carry on.

All the articles - except for a handful from the Alps and the Rockies - were written from a succession of homes in and around Kendal that always looked out to the hills. Indeed, from the windows of one home, from which 30 years of diaries were written, I could at one time - before Whitehall messed about with the counties - see hills in four counties.

Father Time, though, is unforgiving. I kept up my rock-climbing until I was 78, and carried on skiing until I was 80, but today I just potter about the hills - mostly little ones - in geriatric fashion. I know where to go for quietude when the district is choc-a-bloc with traffic, but my greatest concern will always be that Lakeland is not further despoiled by the excesses of mass tourism and the greed of big business. May I wish you all a wonderful New Year in the hills.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Janeane Garofalo's work experience

fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: The stars before they were famous.
fields.body:
Janeane Garofalo in Late For Dinner (WD Richter, 1991)

Who? Stand-up comic and sometime actress who's made a career out of being sullen (but funny). She first appeared with her eponymous ex-boyfriend on The Ben Stiller Show, then in his directorial debut Reality Bites (1994). The zenith of her persona, however, came with Paula, the sullen booker on The Larry Sanders Show. Her film parts have hardly departed from the black-clad, sarcastic, cute-if-only-she'd-smile format.

Her biggest movie, The Truth About Cats And Dogs, saw her playing a woman who thinks herself so ugly she sends neighbour Uma Thurman on a blind date instead of her. She was then sullen in Romy And Michelle's High School Reunion, 200 Cigarettes, and even managed to play a sullen superhero in Mystery Men (1999) alongside old pal Stiller. Good news - she gets to star alongside Robert De Niro in her next film. Bad news - it's The Adventures Of Rocky And Bullwinkle.

The role: Counter Girl in a Red Riding Hood-themed burger bar. It's 1991, but Willie and Frank, cryogenically frozen in 1962, have just awoken.

Best line: When the newly thawed Frank tries to buy a plain burger, she says his order is "close to a What Great Big Teeth You Have burger without the chilli sauce, or a Big Bad Wolf without the bacon and the sprouts".

Cringe factor: Slight. She has her shtick and is sticking to it.

Other wannabes: Marcia Gay Harden, who plays Frank's wife Joy, went on to appear in such diverse films as Flubber, Meet Joe Black, and last year's Space Cowboys.

Critical judgement: "Movingly acted," remarked Leonard Maltin, "but the transition from loopy comedy to deeply felt sentiment doesn't quite come off."

Also not starring in: A 1994 horror short called Suspicious, as "Woman."

 Late For Dinner, 9pm, Wednesday, 3 January, Carlton Cinema.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The Archers | On The Town | Live From The Stables
fields.body:
If you are a fan of The Archers (7pm, Radio 4) you will be well aware that the 50th anniversary edition brings a stunning twist in the plot. If, like me, you can't stand the ever-tedious population of Ambridge, switch to two entrancing hours of Leonard Bernstein's On The Town (7pm, Radio 3). It's a recording of last year's concert performance at the Royal Festival Hall by an Anglo-American cast.

Cleo Laine and John Dankworth, looking for somewhere to enjoy regular sessions with their musical friends, eventually realised that the answer was to convert the stable block at their home near Milton Keynes. That was 30 years ago, and the place has been jumping ever since, with performers ranging from George Shearing to Nigel Kennedy. Now it has been refurbished as a 300-seat concert hall and welcomes in the (authentic) new millennium with Live From The Stables (8.30pm, Radio 2), the first of four celebratory performances.

webTitle: G2: Uzbekistan's secret art collection

fields.headline: Savitsky's secret hoard
fields.standfirst: Igor Savitsky built up a vast collection of Soviet art from the 1920s and 30s, saving it from communist destruction. To keep it safe, he housed it in a small, inhospitable town in remote Uzbekistan. Now it is being rediscovered.  Amelia Gentleman  made the trip
fields.trailText: Igor Savitsky built up a vast collection of Soviet art from the 1920s and 30s, saving it from communist destruction. To keep it safe, he housed it in a small, inhospitable town in remote Uzbekistan. Now it is being rediscovered. Amelia Gentleman made the trip.
fields.body:
By three o'clock on a clear afternoon there are still no visitors at the Nukus art museum. Neither the ticket-sellers nor the guard at the door seem to expect any. Outside, the desolate Soviet streets of this former military zone are virtually empty. Towards the outskirts of the town, a few lone figures are visible herding bony cattle past iron-roofed shacks to look for water.

Beyond these buildings, there is nothing for miles in any direction but the scrubby wasteland of the Uzbek desert, parched still further by the worst drought the region has ever experienced. Not many people here have time to think about art.

But within the walls of its modest two-storey building, the town gallery hoards one of the world's greatest, almost unknown, collections of Soviet art from the 20s and 30s. It contains state-approved socialist realism alongside dissident, decadent art repressed and rejected by the communist regime. Many of the artists shown here were sent to mental hospitals, died in the gulag labour camps, or were executed during Stalin's purges. Until the freedom that came with Mikhail Gorbachev's perestroika, their work was never hung on the walls of Moscow's leading galleries.

It was only because of the remote location of the Nukus museum - in a far-flung central Asian backwater, hundreds of miles from Moscow and even from Tashkent, capital of the now independent state of Uzbekistan - that these pictures could be shown here. Created by an eccentric, fanatical collector, Igor Savitsky, this highly unusual museum helped to preserve the work of artists which otherwise would have been lost for ever. Savitsky was able to build up a collection that could never have been formed in regions more accessible to the watchful eye of the KGB.

Long forgotten, the gallery has only recently begun to gain international recognition - and the sudden excitement over this discovery has manifested itself in somewhat surreal fashion. In 1998, 85 American art historians and dealers chartered a private jet to fly from New York to the tiny, dusty Nukus airfield. Photographs, fading and curling in the heat, of these expensively dressed, bemused-looking sophisticates arriving at the museum have been pinned to a noticeboard in the entrance hall. Conscious of how desirable this era of Soviet art has become, some of them had hoped to buy up a few of the 90,000 pieces in the Savitsky collection. The offers were rejected.

Al Gore was one of the first foreigners to see the collection, drawn to Nukus by the region's only other sightseeing attraction - the Aral Sea, the world's worst ecological disaster spot, an hour's drive away. He came to study the effects of the catastrophe - caused when Soviet planners diverted the nearby Amu Darya river to irrigate cotton fields - and spent his spare time in the gallery, describing the collection as remarkable.

The museum interior is unlike most galleries. Savitsky did not believe in giving paintings space. Every wall is crammed from floor to ceiling. The pictures - some roughly framed in wood, others unframed - are strung up with what appears to be white plastic garden twine. Thousands more paintings are stacked in long rows in darkened storerooms in the basement.

The ceilings are patched with board and brown water stains trickle down the walls. There is such a confusion of images that it is at first hard to focus, but image after image catches the eye: the self-portrait by Vladimir Lysenko against a background of constructivist shapes; workers labouring within a scene of smoking factories by Alexander Shevchenko; beautiful, disfigured dead parrots painted by Mikhail Sokolov on his return from the gulag.

Some of the artists, such as Robert Falk and Lyubova Popova, are familiar names. Others fell so out of favour with the establishment that they were forgotten and never made it into the canon of Soviet art.

Marinika Babanazarova, who became curator after Savitsky's death, describes the museum as "the most objective evaluation of artistic life at the beginning of the 20th century in the Soviet Union". She also claims that it is the second best gallery of Russian avant-garde in the world after the Russian Museum in St Petersburg and while it is hard to gauge the accuracy of this claim, the sheer volume and range of the artists gathered here make it an undeniably serious collection.

The extraordinary story of Savitsky's museum highlights the history of art in the 20s and 30s and the trials of Russia's artists in the post-revolutionary era.

Born into a rich, aristocratic family in 1915, Savitsky trained as an artist and later moved to Uzbekistan, where he, like many other artists of his generation, felt inspired. Concerned that the traditions and folklore of the region were swiftly disappearing beneath the new Soviet culture, he talked the authorities into letting him set up a museum to preserve local crafts.

It was beneath the cover of this eminently respectable venture that he was able, in the early 60s, to begin the dangerous task of collecting the works of dissidents. In 1966 he persuaded the Uzbek government to allocate funds to set up a separate art museum - where he discreetly displayed the nonconformist paintings amid more acceptable Moscow artists and local painters. He focused on the period immediately after the revolution through to the 30s - an era which saw the development of the Russian avant-garde, with its explosion of experimental styles: cubism, futurism and constructivism. It was in 1932, with the succession of socialist realism, that all but the most mainstream art, dedicated to glorifying the achievements of Soviet society and boosting the regime, was outlawed. Any deviation from the socialist realist norm was regarded with deep suspicion.

With a shrewd eye for unconventional talent, Savitsky began to gather works by many artists who, excluded from Russia's art establishment when experimental art ceased to be tolerated, were denied membership to the all-important artists' union (and the privileges of cheap materials, meals and studio space that went with it) and left to struggle alone. These artists were never given the opportunity to exhibit and as a result their work was rarely bought; they never received lucrative commissions from museums and public galleries or orders to decorate public buildings. Most died unrecognised.

Savitsky began travelling regularly to Moscow, where he would persuade widows and families of dissident artists to sell him work. As late as the 60s, the avant-garde remained outside the bounds of acceptability in the Soviet Union and many paintings had lain abandoned for decades, rotting in attics and basements, lying in dusty piles beneath beds and behind bookshelves. One work was extracted from the rafters, where it had been placed to keep out the rain.

Most of the relatives were so delighted that someone was finally prepared to put the work on show that they were thrilled to part with the paintings. Those who were reluctant soon changed their minds after a taste of Savitsky's notorious charm. He became known as the widows' friend.

Savitsky used to travel back to Nukus by train - a wearying three-day trip from the capital - with his compartment and several others crammed with canvases. The money granted to him by the Uzbek authorities did not stretch to buying works by artists such as Kazimir Malevich and Marc Chagall who were famous abroad, but he paid reasonable prices for the works of forgotten artists. He was a hoarder who liked to take everything away with him so that, he said, visitors to his museum would be able to see the development of an artist's talent. Handwritten files in the museum archives show that several artists are represented by more than 1,000 pieces each.

Until perestroika, museum staff never advertised the presence of these nonconformist artists within the collection - which also houses a fine collection of socialist realism. They were reluctant to draw attention to something that would only cause trouble. To people who knew anything about art, the remarkable diversity of the collection was immediately obvious and it became quietly famous in dissident circles. Apart from one occasion - when a KGB officer inexplicably decided that an innocuous picture of a bull by Lysenko was anti-Soviet and demanded that it be removed - security officials left the museum alone.

In 1982, when the museum held an exhibition of drawings by Nadezhda Borovaya from the gulag where she spent seven years in the 30s, the catalogue informed visitors that the pictures were imaginary representations of life inside a German concentration camp. The drawings, made on scraps of rough brown paper and smuggled out of the camp, showed emaciated prisoners with cadaverous faces. One picture shows a mother carrying her dead child, another shows women with strips of cloth wrapped around their heads marked with their identity numbers.

"Most people didn't know that the Soviet Union had deprived people of their identities like that," says Babanazarova. "It was thought that that was something done only by the fascists. The pictures would never have gone on show - even in Nukus - if we had said they had depicted life in a Russian gulag."

Savitsky's collection has regained acceptability and popularity over the last decade, but the museum faces financial problems. Staff fight a constant battle against the harsh elements of the desert. There is no money to buy humidifiers. Instead staff arrive at dawn every morning, open all the windows and place trays of water on the wooden floorboards of every room to stop the arid air cracking the paint. The heat is so fierce that by mid-morning the water has evaporated.

Because of the ecological disaster, the Aral Sea region has been registered as the dustiest place on the planet and the dried-up seabed lets loose a daily storm of sand and toxins which also threaten the pictures. Every time it rains, staff have to rush to carry canvases from rooms with leaks to those that are watertight.

With several paintings worth more than £1m, around 70% of the annual state grant goes on maintaining an alarm system within the converted government office block that houses the museum. It was long ago deemed unsatisfactory and work on a new building began in 1976. The still-unfinished structure, a great hulk of concrete, stands in the town's central square. An extravagant flight of stairs to the main entrance has been completed, but the rest is a shell. There is no sign of construction work. "The government granted us £5m this year for the building, but we need £625m," says Babanazarova. "At this rate it will be at least another 60 years before we can meet the cost of it."

Most visitors are tourists. "People who live here are concerned with the problem of survival, not with culture. It is very difficult to think about art when your stomach is empty," she says. But Nukus is not exactly a top tourist destination. A former high-security centre for the development of chemical weapons, it was closed to foreigners entirely until the late 80s and since then there has been little reason to develop the place for tourists. There are no restaurants, not even in the main hotel; just a few roadside food stalls.

Babanazarova wonders sometimes about moving the gallery from its current remote position in one of the world's more remote locations to a spot more accessible to visitors. "Evacuation would make sense because more people would be able to see the exhibition and that would attract more financial support. But we don't even want to think about it," she says. "This was the place that gave shelter to these artists in a hard time. It would be a betrayal to move them now."

webTitle: Arts: Can art be a family business? No

fields.headline: Families that play together...
fields.standfirst:
When it comes to a career in music, following in your parents' footsteps can be disastrous, writes Stephen Johnson

In the name of the father
fields.trailText: When it comes to a career in music, following in your parents' footsteps can be disastrous, writes Stephen Johnson.
fields.body:
Art as a family business? To modern minds the idea grates. Every biographical cliche protests against it. Becoming an artist is all about finding a voice, an identity that can only be forged alone - in the words of James Joyce, "in the smithy of the soul". And yet the three composers most frequently ranked as the world's greatest - JS Bach, Mozart and Beethoven - all came from professional musical families.

Mozart and his brilliant pianist sister Anna ("Nannerl") were the proud exhibits of father Leopold Mozart, violinist and composer. There is evidence that Mozart sometimes longed for a more nurturing musical father - as in the effusive dedication of his six "Haydn" Quartets to Joseph Haydn (46 years his senior, hugely influential and a much more benign figure than Leopold). But in terms of craft and vocation, Mozart was a chip off the paternal block.

Beethoven - canonised as music's greatest iconoclast and innovator - was son and grandson of musicians. Like Leopold Mozart, Beethoven's father Johann planned to capitalise on his son's talents. He was also coarse, violent and an incurable drunk. There are stories of him dragging little Ludwig out of bed after the taverns had closed to perform for his disreputable friends; and if Ludwig's playing wasn't felt to be up to standard, beatings followed. It's possible the effects of Johann's behaviour reverberated in Beethoven's feelings about God the Father. As the conductor Wolfgang Sawallisch put it, trying to explain why Beethoven's Missa Solemnis leaves a complex impression: "I'm not sure he always thought God was such a good thing."

Still, when it comes to musical family firms, the name Bach admits no competition. According to surviving records there were something like 75 musician Bachs. Johann Sebastian - the composer Beethoven referred to as "the immortal god of harmony" - drew up a genealogy, identifying Veit Bach (d. 1619), baker and lutenist, as the founder of the dynasty. JS Bach may be the star name in the family tree, but he had distinguished predecessors - great-uncle Johann Christoph, for instance, creator of several expressive choral works.

JS Bach is sometimes pigeonholed as a conservative, intensifying his essentially baroque style while the rest of the musical world edged towards romanticism. That would fit with the notion of a composer proudly inheriting a dynastic tradition, rather than striking out for new shores. But the truth is more complicated. And anyway, one of Bach's most talented sons, Carl Philipp Emanuel - as much product and upholder of Bachian family values as his father - became one of the most forward-looking, iconoclastic composers of the 18th century.

It was CPE Bach that Haydn had in mind when he wrote: "Bach is the father, we the children." Or, as CPE wrote of his father, JS: "He, who possessed the most profound knowledge of all the contrapuntal arts, understood how to make art subservient to beauty." In other words, the revolutionary learned innovation at the workbench of his apparently conservative, solidly pedagogical father: not the way it's supposed to happen.

The Bachs may be the outstanding musical family, but they weren't the last. The 19th century saw the rise of the Strausses of Vienna - composers and performers all. Johann Strauss I tried to prevent his sons from making a career in music, but Johann II, "The Waltz King", studied in secret and entered the musical scene as a rival to his father. They also ended up supporting opposite political sides in the revolutions of 1848 - Johann II being on the side of the revolutionaries. A classic Oedipal conflict. Perhaps the Bachs were, after all, a weird, unrepeatable anomaly.

Although in our own time there are examples of families with more than one composer under one roof, it is much more common to find multiple-performer families. Steven Isserlis can make up a string quartet with other members of his family, as can fellow cellist Tim Hugh. Musical family ensembles have also entered popular mythology via The Sound of Music's Von Trapps. Many of us will have seen something similar in real life: kids clutching half-sized string instruments being herded out of the people carrier, primed for exhibition at the next school concert.

There's something disturbing about such spectacles. Was it luck that those three children chose violin, viola and cello respectively, or was the choice made for them? The latter ought to be a recipe for disaster, although avoiding having two children playing the same instrument can be good psychological strategy.

No doubt it is a help for a musician to grow up in a house where music is in the air. But the history of musical families is strewn with casualties, victims of hothouse teaching or internecine strife. Even the survivors can provide notes of warning. The conductor Leonard Slatkin had famous musical parents. His father, Felix Slatkin, partly trained as a conductor but became famous as a violinist and as founder/leader of the Hollywood String Quartet, and his mother, Eleanor Aller, was cellist in the Hollywood. Not following his father directly was important, Slatkin has said; significantly it was only when his father died that his career really began to pick up speed.

There are tales of open rivalry between conductors Erich (father) and Carlos (son) Kleiber. Damning parental criticism may not have prevented Carlos Kleiber from achieving greatness, but it may have helped turn him into the bizarre recluse he has become. Yan Pascal Tortelier was wise not to follow the same course as his world-famous cellist father Paul Tortelier; instead he has established a firm reputation for himself as a conductor. But conductor Maxim Shostakovich, son of one of the biggest names in 20th-century music, hasn't been so lucky. Nor has Igor Oistrakh: a fine violinist, throughout his career he has had to endure comparisons with his legendary violinist father, David Oistrakh. Does he ever wish he'd taken up the tuba?

There is a painful testimonial in the film Hilary and Jackie, based on a book by Jacqueline du Pré's sister Hilary - a talented flautist whose career collapsed as her sibling's grew, and who found herself duty-bound to continue making sacrifices for brilliant but crazy Jackie (including offering up her own husband for sex). Jackie emerges as a monster, Hilary as a saint. It all smacks of deep hurt and bitter revenge.

Still, it's possible to see Hilary and Jackie as a valuable cautionary tale. The idea of gathering your family together to play quartets on balmy summer evenings may appeal. It can even work out well, if the parents are reasonably worldly-wise. But before you try turning your children into performing Mozarts, Von Trapps, or even the Jackson Five, see Hilary and Jackie and think a little harder.

It was CPE Bach that Haydn had in mind when he wrote: "Bach is the father, we the children." Or, as CPE wrote of his father, JS: "He, who possessed the most profound knowledge of all the contrapuntal arts, understood how to make art subservient to beauty." In other words, the revolutionary learned innovation at the workbench of his apparently conservative, solidly pedagogical father: not the way it's supposed to happen. The Bachs may be the outstanding musical family, but they weren't the last. The 19th century saw the rise of the Strausses of Vienna - composers and performers all. Johann Strauss I tried to prevent his sons from making a career in music, but Johann II, "The Waltz King", studied in secret and entered the musical scene as a rival to his father. They also ended up supporting opposite political sides in the revolutions of 1848 - Johann II being on the side of the revolutionaries. A classic Oedipal conflict. Perhaps the Bachs were, after all, a weird, unrepeatable anomaly. Although in our own time there are examples of families with more than one composer under one roof, it is much more common to find multiple-performer families. Steven Isserlis can make up a string quartet with other members of his family, as can fellow cellist Tim Hugh. Musical family ensembles have also entered popular mythology via The Sound of Music's Von Trapps. Many of us will have seen something similar in real life: kids clutching half-sized string instruments being herded out of the people carrier, primed for exhibition at the next school concert. There's something disturbing about such spectacles. Was it luck that those three children chose violin, viola and cello respectively, or was the choice made for them? The latter ought to be a recipe for disaster, although avoiding having two children playing the same instrument can be good psychological strategy. No doubt it is a help for a musician to grow up in a house where music is in the air. But the history of musical families is strewn with casualties, victims of hothouse teaching or internecine strife. Even the survivors can provide notes of warning. The conductor Leonard Slatkin had famous musical parents. His father, Felix Slatkin, partly trained as a conductor but became famous as a violinist and as founder/leader of the Hollywood String Quartet, and his mother, Eleanor Aller, was cellist in the Hollywood. Not following his father directly was important, Slatkin has said; significantly it was only when his father died that his career really began to pick up speed. There are tales of open rivalry between conductors Erich (father) and Carlos (son) Kleiber. Damning parental criticism may not have prevented Carlos Kleiber from achieving greatness, but it may have helped turn him into the bizarre recluse he has become. Yan Pascal Tortelier was wise not to follow the same course as his world-famous cellist father Paul Tortelier; instead he has established a firm reputation for himself as a conductor. But conductor Maxim Shostakovich, son of one of the biggest names in 20th-century music, hasn't been so lucky. Nor has Igor Oistrakh: a fine violinist, throughout his career he has had to endure comparisons with his legendary violinist father, David Oistrakh. Does he ever wish he'd taken up the tuba? There is a painful testimonial in the film Hilary and Jackie, based on a book by Jacqueline du Pré's sister Hilary - a talented flautist whose career collapsed as her sibling's grew, and who found herself duty-bound to continue making sacrifices for brilliant but crazy Jackie (including offering up her own husband for sex). Jackie emerges as a monster, Hilary as a saint. It all smacks of deep hurt and bitter revenge. Still, it's possible to see Hilary and Jackie as a valuable cautionary tale. The idea of gathering your family together to play quartets on balmy summer evenings may appeal. It can even work out well, if the parents are reasonably worldly-wise. But before you try turning your children into performing Mozarts, Von Trapps, or even the Jackson Five, see Hilary and Jackie and think a little harder.

fields.headline: In the name of the father
fields.standfirst:
When it comes to a career in music, following in your parents' footsteps can be disastrous, although not if you are a Brubeck, says John Fordham

Families that play together...
fields.trailText: When it comes to a career in music, following in your parents' footsteps can be disastrous, although not if you are a Brubeck, says John Fordham.
fields.body:
There are always a few stray jazz musicians in the album collections of just about any genre or generation of music-lovers, whether or not the majority vote is for hip-hop or Wagner. These days you'll probably unearth the odd Jan Garbarek, Keith Jarrett and maybe Courtney Pine - almost certainly a Diana Krall or two. In the 1960s, amid the Beatles and Grateful Deads in everybody's stack of vinyl, there was usually Miles Davis's Kind of Blue, pianist Errol Garner's Concert by the Sea - and some Dave Brubeck.

From the late 1950s, Brubeck was the jazz musician all the non-buffs tapped a toe to (though with its usual suspicion of celebrity, the hardcore emphatically didn't thank him for his popularity at the time). He experimented with world-musical borrowings and classical/ jazz crossovers when they were otherwise rare. Brubeck intertwined jazz swing with time-signatures that looked like algebra, mingled standard song forms with elegant rondos and fugues.

The music flattered and charmed the white middle-class college audience of the day, and for that reason (and its cool articulation and understated dynamics) it was often denounced as a pale recital-room substitute by those who preferred their jazz to get down and break sweat. The late Benny Green, in particular - a mercilessly witty flayer of those he judged to be jazz heretics - was at his most pungent with Brubeck.

But time, and the eclecticism and fluid collaborations of a shrinking world, have healed Brubeck's estrangement from the jazz audience. Now his pieces are recognised for the harmonically subtle, melodically devious and original works they are, and his most classically oriented works (such as the soft-winds Bach tribute, Chorale) triumph in a treacherous territory in which short-changing jazz or dumbing-down symphonic composition is very hard to avoid.

Brubeck was on stage in London over Christmas, looking a shade stooped and just a little overwhelmed, but playing with a relaxed mischievousness that has grown on him with the years, and with his usual emphatic chordal bounce. He was generally behaving as if his 80th birthday gig was just another step in a long-term plan.

Brubeck's concerts with his four sons, his touring band (including the UK's Alec Dankworth on bass and Bobby Millitello on sax) and the London Symphony Orchestra, were ecstatically received - as befits a man who probably introduced jazz to more people who thought they didn't like it than anybody else. When they all eased into Take Five (Brubeck's most famous jazz hit, though it was composed by his then- saxophonist Paul Desmond), the reception was like a mass exhalation of gratitude for a musical life well lived.

"Bernstein's gone now," says Brubeck's trombone and bass-playing son Chris, "but my hope is that Dave will come to be recognised as someone of that stature too, a giant with a foot in both worlds. He's had criticism for doing that, and it's hurt him - to this day, it's hard for him to get a good review out of the New York Times, even though he keeps outliving their critics. But his is an amazing story. A California cowboy from a town of 100 people growing up to play music for popes and presidents with some of the greatest performers in the world."

Chris Brubeck, and his brothers Darius (piano), Matt (cello) and Dan (drums) all have flourishing musical careers of their own. Darius is an ethno-musicologist and teacher as well as a performer, Matt is an improvising jazz cellist who tours with Sheryl Crow, and Dan leads a variety of jazz and funk groups of his own. Chris Brubeck has confirmed receipt of his father's broad musical horizons by recording an album of pieces in the LSO's company, ranging from Bach to blues to Brubeck Snr, and featuring his exuberant new Concerto for Bass Trombone (which stimulated interest from more of the world's classical trombonists than its composer had thought even existed).

"The LSO is the best in the world for people like us, who don't belong in any one category," says Chris Brubeck. "They're flexible, open, versatile, and they enjoy it all. But it's also a change that's come out of the economic situation. Orchestral players can't afford to lift their noses to the skies and only play Mahler now - we used to get them going 'Oh my god, a jazz group on stage with us', and they'd look so disgruntled sitting there in their evening dress, like waiters at the end of a slow night. But a new kind of musician has evolved."

The Brubeck family's mutual pleasure in its work is pretty evident onstage, and all backstage accounts indicate that it isn't just public relations. Part of Chris Brubeck's delight in the 80th birthday shows is down to witnessing his father's continuing participation in the more open musical climate that his career did more than a little to encourage. "In every culture there's a thing we might call jazz," he says. "This improvised, freer way of making music over a structure, or sometimes not over a structure. It's all coming together with more composed musics as the world shrinks - and it needs to go on developing, even though it's also good to have people such as Wynton Marsalis who want to honour the full range of jazz's deep musical past.

"But Dave saw this coming a long while ago, and he's still unique. There are very few jazz musicians who have gone into the classical world as deeply as he has. When I hear Chorale, it reminds me of the very best of Aaron Copland, something like Appalachian Spring. There's a sort of American honesty to it. When he switched from being a veterinarian major to doing music at the Pacific College in California in the 40s, they told him at the end of the course they were going to flunk him because his sight-reading was terrible.

"But at the same time they were saying he was one of the best music students they'd ever had. In the end they did a deal - they'd give him the degree if he'd promise never to teach. Now they're archiving all his work 60 years later, and he's one of their most famous students. It's a story that characterises him somehow. You can still hear that openness and optimism in him today."

 Chris Brubeck's Bach to Brubeck is out on Koch International Classics. Dave Brubeck's solo album, One Alone, is on BMG/Telarc.
