webTitle: G2: Pass notes on 2001

fields.headline: No: 1790
fields.body:
Age: Don't be silly.

Appearance: Hazy.

Status: First year of the new millennium.

Hang on, that was last year: You poor, gullible fool. We have now completed 2,000 years; ergo we can start the third millennium. The ridiculous celebrations for 2000 were based on nothing more than a predilection for round numbers.

So what does 2001 have to offer? All manner of excitements.

Such as? Presidential elections in Benin, Portugal, Estonia and Cape Verde; Latvia handing over the presidency of the Council of Europe to Liechtenstein; a horse winning the Grand National.

Zzzzzzzzzzzzz: OK, OK, I was pulling your leg. It's more exciting than that. A cardboard cut-out becomes president of the US; the Conservatives poll no votes at all in the election; Tom Hanks wins his 37th Oscar; Bob the Builder becomes head of Railtrack; francs and marks are replaced by the euro (worth an estimated 0.000000017 cents - or half a stale baguette - against the dollar).

Anniversaries: Centenary of the deaths of Verdi and Queen Victoria, who made the mistake of trying to sit through the five-act version of Don Carlos. Fifty years since the first H-bomb.

Good year for: Al Gore; Tony Blair; Ehud Barak (or Ariel Sharon - what do you think we are, Middle East experts?); Lord Salisbury - brought back as Tory leader; Cape Verde, where the presidential election, won of course by Verdi, really puts the country on the map.

Bad year for: Cardboard cut-outs which assume the presidency and/or win Oscars; currency speculators who invest in euros (rather than, say, stale baguettes); Bob the Builder, sacked when he fails to fix it; columnists who spent all of 2000 writing about the (pre-millennium) dome and are now stuck for a subject.

Do mention: Stanley Kubrick.

Don't mention: Stanley Kubrick.

How can he be in both categories? Look, mate, you try writing pass notes after two bottles of Drambuie.

webTitle: G2: Interview with playwright Yasmina Reza

fields.headline: Art and artifice
fields.standfirst: Her play, Art, is still selling out after five years. And now her new work, Life x 3, is packing them in at the National Theatre. So why does Yasmina Reza think humans are so vile?  Simon Hattenstone  meets the playwright - and leaves feeling stung
fields.trailText: Her play, Art, is still selling out after five years. And now her new work, Life x 3, is packing them in at the National Theatre. So why does Yasmina Reza think humans are so vile? Simon Hattenstone meets the playwright - and leaves feeling stung.
fields.body:
I'm knackered. A bit depressed, if you must know. It's not simply the winter cold. Nor the pre-dawn Eurostar trek to Paris, nor the hollow rumble in my belly. Just a feeling in my soul. Even interviewers are prone to existential nausea. Still, in a few minutes I'll be chatting away to a brilliant dramatist, filling my tum with the finest French food, drinking in her famous beauty, feasting my mind on the most elevated French thought. Transcending the blues.

Yasmina Reza is not so much a writer as a cultural phenomenon. In an age when we have turned our back on the cack-handed artifice of so much theatre, her most popular play has packed the West End for five years. Art, which is about three male friends who fall out when one of them buys a white canvas for £20,000, has been translated into 35 languages, grossed close on £200m worldwide and won all the awards worth winning.

Her new play, Life x 3, which is about four people falling out as they discuss astrophysics, is playing to bloated crowds at the National Theatre. Her novel, Hammerklavier, which features a woman who falls out with a man because he doesn't like her necklace, has been described as a profound exploration of intimacy.

Reza, who is 40, seems to be hiding behind curtains in the bar of a grand St Germain hotel, which was her choice for our meeting. She looks like a Spitting Image puppet, both smaller and larger than life. While her body is petite, with its tiny cotton reel of a waist, her face is exaggerated: huge Vaselined lips; long, dipping nose; great, rolling, brown eyes. Her mother is Hungarian, her father was of Russian-Iranian extraction. She is French and Jewish. Somehow her face maps out her history.

She sips at her tea. Her legs are crossed, defensively. Before I know it my host is telling me how rarely she gives interviews, how journalists distort the truth, how tired she is because she is acting in Life x 3, and that combined with the writing, and running a family, looking after her 12-year-old daughter and younger son, giving interviews when you have nothing to say to journalists who will only hear what they want to hear anyway ... If I were more chivalrous I'd apologise for my existence and leave. Instead, I just order myself a sad cup of coffee and fantasise about the gourmet meal that won't be.

Reza used to be an actress, and has just returned to the stage for the first time in more than a decade to play Ines in Life x 3. "It's a surprising role for me to play because Ines is a victim. I'm not considered to be a victim." She says she is much closer to the other female lead, Sonia.

"Sonia takes risks, she's a player. She's very complex, very powerful."

In the play, which offers three versions of the same story, Sonia is having an affair with a successful academic who can make or break the husband she loves, Henri. Reza says the actress playing Sonia in Paris had problems with the role. "I think you can really love a man and take a lover also. It's not a contradiction for me, and it was very difficult to make the actress understand that. She thought if a girl is capable of embracing both men, she is a bitch, she doesn't love her husband. But things are not so simple. In my view, you can be everything at the same moment. Things are never clear in real life, so why should they be in art?"

She parts her lips and smiles the most sensual of smiles. Reza looks as if she could swallow the world. It's the kind of smile you spend years perfecting in a mirror. She says she has a problem with the way we watch her plays - why do we insist on calling them comedies? I feel a little embarrassed, having left Life x 3 thinking it a farce about an evening in with two unexpected visitors and a bawling toddler. Reza patiently explains the error of my ways. "It is about the smallest things, like chocolate fingers, trivial domestic stuff, and also it's a metaphysical play. To my mind it's my most metaphysical play."

That's great, having a metaphysical play about Cheesy Wotsits, I say.

"It's not only about that," she says sans smile. "It's also about stars. There are phases like: 'We are not insignificant ... our time is insignificant, but we are not insignificant.' There are some phrases in this play which I'm very proud of, like: 'Your son has made a wonderful monument and tomorrow he will destroy it. In this world you destroy everything, even yourself.' "

Reza explains that this phrase also has multiple meanings. Yet still the audiences giggle their way through the evening. In Art, they laugh at the way the friends discuss the blank canvas, they laugh at their aspirations and their pretensions, they laugh all the way to the bar, where they discuss whether a blank canvas can be great art. "Laughter is always a problem," Reza says. "Laughter is very dangerous. The way people laugh changes the way you see a play. A very profound play may seem very light. My plays have always been described as comedy but I think they're tragedy. They are funny tragedy, but they are tragedy. Maybe it's a new genre."

Why is Art a tragedy? "Because it is a break-up of a friendship, a rupture between people ... it's a heartbreaking play if you read it." Reza has often said she hates false modesty.

Her tragic vision of life goes way back. "I knew as a young child that everyone would die, that humanity was vile. I had no optimism in human beings. I have no faith in humanity. Our first instincts are vile."

Are her first instincts vile? "Of course. I try to correct them, every day to improve myself." What does she find most vile about herself? "I will not tell you, of course. Like most people I'm not a special monster, but I'm aware of what I could be if I didn't pay attention to myself." As she tells me about our curdled souls, atrophied minds and decaying bodies, I keep wondering when my host is going to ask if I fancy a scrummy little cake to make the interview go down nicely.

She says her morality keeps her vileness in check, and refers me to her novel Hammerklavier. "All the personal questions you ask me are in this book. It is very autobiographical. It was not supposed to be published. It was written for me."

Why did she agree to its publication? "One day I realised I had many pages and reread them and I found them very interesting. I made friends read them and they said: 'Really, but you should publish them. It's not as personal as you think because everyone has a father, everyone has children ...' Now I'm very happy it's a book."

In one of the fragments that make up Hammerklavier, she attends the funeral of her former agent, Marta. The dead Marta tells her off for not bringing flowers, and says she knows why she didn't bother: "Because your laziness got the better of you and because you didn't think it was worth spending a cent on a dead woman." I think I'm going to have a long wait for my cake.

Hammerklavier is astonishing. The tiny chapters were written as scraps of diary, and somehow Reza has convinced herself that the act of stapling these scraps together turns them into a cogent work of fiction. It is occasionally beautiful, often pretentious, always revealing. There is plenty of love in the book - for her dying father, staring at his cancer-stripped body in the mirror and seeing Auschwitz; for her children's demanding whims; for her partner, director Didier Martigny. Yet what seeps through is the vileness she sees within herself and the world.

Reza becomes her own truest character. At one point she writes about the modern theatre audience with utter contempt. "Wherever we go today people applaud at the final note. No silence. Not a single second's retreat. Quick, applaud. Quick, show yourself, quick be part of it, talk about it, bawl out your important verdict ... everyone is so proud of belonging to this odious community, the odious new community of the informed, intelligent public."

I hated Art and Life x 3, and the more I talk to Reza the more I realise why. Reza sits at the top table of the very odious community she condemns. Her plays are the perfect fodder for the chattering classes she claims to despise. The mighty cerebral subjects are simply conceits, showy props. Is she really interested in art or astrophysics? "Not much, no. I think the subjects are not so important in themselves, only the style, the way you deal with them. That makes a playwright, or not." She says the truth lies in the words behind the debates, or the silences; the tragedy in the relationships. Perhaps. But you have to care about characters for their fall to be tragic.

A new expression was recently invented to describe the work of Yasmina Reza: "The big idea lite." She finds it insulting, demeaning, and says accessibility has been mistaken for banality. "I think if people are going to pay to go the theatre, you have to be understood. I don't want to compare myself with the greatest playwrights but Shakespeare, Molière, Racine, all the great ones were very, very accessible. And the fact that they became classics was because they were accessible. My writing is very complex ... but complex and funny, complex and entertaining."

Does she ever lose confidence in her writing? "Not at all." Reza's words, her tone, her body language all convey an invincibility. Only her eyes suggest otherwise. They are permanently wet, as if on the verge of tears. Does she lose confidence in herself? "I'm more confident in myself as a writer. I'm not confident in myself at all." But as a writer? "Yes, I am. Very." She says that Yasmina Reza the writer is very different from Yasmina Reza the mother, lover, daughter. "It may not look like it, but I am shy as a person." I think I would get on better with Reza the person than Reza the author.

Perhaps there is a reason why Reza is so successful today. Maybe her creations have a peculiar resonance in the post-political age. Her characters, including herself in Hammerklavier, are self-obsessed, desperately ambitious for achievement, whatever form that achievement takes. They reek of futility but lack the desperate humanity of Beckett's existential no-hopers.

I ask Reza if there is any cause she fights for, anything that makes her scream with outrage. "No, it's not a way of expressing myself. I don't believe in shouting nowadays, it doesn't work. It was very important to do that when Hitler came to power, but now I don't think there are causes which I could involve myself with. You know, a lot of famous people involve themselves very easily, and I suspect that."

As she says, she has little faith in humanity.

Her created worlds are stiflingly insular, her characters totally self-absorbed. At the end of Hammerklavier, she writes about getting the Eurostar back from London to Paris. She looks out of the window and for a second allows her imagination to stray. "We pass the sad brick houses alongside the tracks. Who lives in them? Who wakes each morning to look upon this low horizon of bricks, chimneys, and bewildering walls? A few yards ahead, I'll think no more of them. I'll be thinking of the things that are travelling with me and don't leave me. For the world is not outside the self. Outside the self is the illusion of the world, not the world."

I'm starving.

Reza stands up to leave, and asks if I'm staying in Paris. No, I say, I'm getting the Eurostar back later today. She looks pleased. "Ah, you came just for me?" Then disappointed. "It's a pity, you could have come to see me in the play tonight." And with that, she disappears.

As I gather up my belongings, the waiter catches my eye. "Ah monsieur, you will be wanting to pay the bill," he says.
fields.bodyText: I'm knackered. A bit depressed, if you must know. It's not simply the winter cold. Nor the pre-dawn Eurostar trek to Paris, nor the hollow rumble in my belly. Just a feeling in my soul. Even interviewers are prone to existential nausea. Still, in a few minutes I'll be chatting away to a brilliant dramatist, filling my tum with the finest French food, drinking in her famous beauty, feasting my mind on the most elevated French thought. Transcending the blues. Yasmina Reza is not so much a writer as a cultural phenomenon. In an age when we have turned our back on the cack-handed artifice of so much theatre, her most popular play has packed the West End for five years. Art, which is about three male friends who fall out when one of them buys a white canvas for £20,000, has been translated into 35 languages, grossed close on £200m worldwide and won all the awards worth winning. Her new play, Life x 3, which is about four people falling out as they discuss astrophysics, is playing to bloated crowds at the National Theatre. Her novel, Hammerklavier, which features a woman who falls out with a man because he doesn't like her necklace, has been described as a profound exploration of intimacy. Reza, who is 40, seems to be hiding behind curtains in the bar of a grand St Germain hotel, which was her choice for our meeting. She looks like a Spitting Image puppet, both smaller and larger than life. While her body is petite, with its tiny cotton reel of a waist, her face is exaggerated: huge Vaselined lips; long, dipping nose; great, rolling, brown eyes. Her mother is Hungarian, her father was of Russian-Iranian extraction. She is French and Jewish. Somehow her face maps out her history. She sips at her tea. Her legs are crossed, defensively. Before I know it my host is telling me how rarely she gives interviews, how journalists distort the truth, how tired she is because she is acting in Life x 3, and that combined with the writing, and running a family, looking after her 12-year-old daughter and younger son, giving interviews when you have nothing to say to journalists who will only hear what they want to hear anyway ... If I were more chivalrous I'd apologise for my existence and leave. Instead, I just order myself a sad cup of coffee and fantasise about the gourmet meal that won't be. Reza used to be an actress, and has just returned to the stage for the first time in more than a decade to play Ines in Life x 3. "It's a surprising role for me to play because Ines is a victim. I'm not considered to be a victim." She says she is much closer to the other female lead, Sonia. "Sonia takes risks, she's a player. She's very complex, very powerful." In the play, which offers three versions of the same story, Sonia is having an affair with a successful academic who can make or break the husband she loves, Henri. Reza says the actress playing Sonia in Paris had problems with the role. "I think you can really love a man and take a lover also. It's not a contradiction for me, and it was very difficult to make the actress understand that. She thought if a girl is capable of embracing both men, she is a bitch, she doesn't love her husband. But things are not so simple. In my view, you can be everything at the same moment. Things are never clear in real life, so why should they be in art?" She parts her lips and smiles the most sensual of smiles. Reza looks as if she could swallow the world. It's the kind of smile you spend years perfecting in a mirror. She says she has a problem with the way we watch her plays - why do we insist on calling them comedies? I feel a little embarrassed, having left Life x 3 thinking it a farce about an evening in with two unexpected visitors and a bawling toddler. Reza patiently explains the error of my ways. "It is about the smallest things, like chocolate fingers, trivial domestic stuff, and also it's a metaphysical play. To my mind it's my most metaphysical play." That's great, having a metaphysical play about Cheesy Wotsits, I say. "It's not only about that," she says sans smile. "It's also about stars. There are phases like: 'We are not insignificant ... our time is insignificant, but we are not insignificant.' There are some phrases in this play which I'm very proud of, like: 'Your son has made a wonderful monument and tomorrow he will destroy it. In this world you destroy everything, even yourself.' " Reza explains that this phrase also has multiple meanings. Yet still the audiences giggle their way through the evening. In Art, they laugh at the way the friends discuss the blank canvas, they laugh at their aspirations and their pretensions, they laugh all the way to the bar, where they discuss whether a blank canvas can be great art. "Laughter is always a problem," Reza says. "Laughter is very dangerous. The way people laugh changes the way you see a play. A very profound play may seem very light. My plays have always been described as comedy but I think they're tragedy. They are funny tragedy, but they are tragedy. Maybe it's a new genre." Why is Art a tragedy? "Because it is a break-up of a friendship, a rupture between people ... it's a heartbreaking play if you read it." Reza has often said she hates false modesty. Her tragic vision of life goes way back. "I knew as a young child that everyone would die, that humanity was vile. I had no optimism in human beings. I have no faith in humanity. Our first instincts are vile." Are her first instincts vile? "Of course. I try to correct them, every day to improve myself." What does she find most vile about herself? "I will not tell you, of course. Like most people I'm not a special monster, but I'm aware of what I could be if I didn't pay attention to myself." As she tells me about our curdled souls, atrophied minds and decaying bodies, I keep wondering when my host is going to ask if I fancy a scrummy little cake to make the interview go down nicely. She says her morality keeps her vileness in check, and refers me to her novel Hammerklavier. "All the personal questions you ask me are in this book. It is very autobiographical. It was not supposed to be published. It was written for me." Why did she agree to its publication? "One day I realised I had many pages and reread them and I found them very interesting. I made friends read them and they said: 'Really, but you should publish them. It's not as personal as you think because everyone has a father, everyone has children ...' Now I'm very happy it's a book." In one of the fragments that make up Hammerklavier, she attends the funeral of her former agent, Marta. The dead Marta tells her off for not bringing flowers, and says she knows why she didn't bother: "Because your laziness got the better of you and because you didn't think it was worth spending a cent on a dead woman." I think I'm going to have a long wait for my cake. Hammerklavier is astonishing. The tiny chapters were written as scraps of diary, and somehow Reza has convinced herself that the act of stapling these scraps together turns them into a cogent work of fiction. It is occasionally beautiful, often pretentious, always revealing. There is plenty of love in the book - for her dying father, staring at his cancer-stripped body in the mirror and seeing Auschwitz; for her children's demanding whims; for her partner, director Didier Martigny. Yet what seeps through is the vileness she sees within herself and the world. Reza becomes her own truest character. At one point she writes about the modern theatre audience with utter contempt. "Wherever we go today people applaud at the final note. No silence. Not a single second's retreat. Quick, applaud. Quick, show yourself, quick be part of it, talk about it, bawl out your important verdict ... everyone is so proud of belonging to this odious community, the odious new community of the informed, intelligent public." I hated Art and Life x 3, and the more I talk to Reza the more I realise why. Reza sits at the top table of the very odious community she condemns. Her plays are the perfect fodder for the chattering classes she claims to despise. The mighty cerebral subjects are simply conceits, showy props. Is she really interested in art or astrophysics? "Not much, no. I think the subjects are not so important in themselves, only the style, the way you deal with them. That makes a playwright, or not." She says the truth lies in the words behind the debates, or the silences; the tragedy in the relationships. Perhaps. But you have to care about characters for their fall to be tragic. A new expression was recently invented to describe the work of Yasmina Reza: "The big idea lite." She finds it insulting, demeaning, and says accessibility has been mistaken for banality. "I think if people are going to pay to go the theatre, you have to be understood. I don't want to compare myself with the greatest playwrights but Shakespeare, Molière, Racine, all the great ones were very, very accessible. And the fact that they became classics was because they were accessible. My writing is very complex ... but complex and funny, complex and entertaining." Does she ever lose confidence in her writing? "Not at all." Reza's words, her tone, her body language all convey an invincibility. Only her eyes suggest otherwise. They are permanently wet, as if on the verge of tears. Does she lose confidence in herself? "I'm more confident in myself as a writer. I'm not confident in myself at all." But as a writer? "Yes, I am. Very." She says that Yasmina Reza the writer is very different from Yasmina Reza the mother, lover, daughter. "It may not look like it, but I am shy as a person." I think I would get on better with Reza the person than Reza the author. Perhaps there is a reason why Reza is so successful today. Maybe her creations have a peculiar resonance in the post-political age. Her characters, including herself in Hammerklavier, are self-obsessed, desperately ambitious for achievement, whatever form that achievement takes. They reek of futility but lack the desperate humanity of Beckett's existential no-hopers. I ask Reza if there is any cause she fights for, anything that makes her scream with outrage. "No, it's not a way of expressing myself. I don't believe in shouting nowadays, it doesn't work. It was very important to do that when Hitler came to power, but now I don't think there are causes which I could involve myself with. You know, a lot of famous people involve themselves very easily, and I suspect that." As she says, she has little faith in humanity. Her created worlds are stiflingly insular, her characters totally self-absorbed. At the end of Hammerklavier, she writes about getting the Eurostar back from London to Paris. She looks out of the window and for a second allows her imagination to stray. "We pass the sad brick houses alongside the tracks. Who lives in them? Who wakes each morning to look upon this low horizon of bricks, chimneys, and bewildering walls? A few yards ahead, I'll think no more of them. I'll be thinking of the things that are travelling with me and don't leave me. For the world is not outside the self. Outside the self is the illusion of the world, not the world." I'm starving. Reza stands up to leave, and asks if I'm staying in Paris. No, I say, I'm getting the Eurostar back later today. She looks pleased. "Ah, you came just for me?" Then disappointed. "It's a pity, you could have come to see me in the play tonight." And with that, she disappears. As I gather up my belongings, the waiter catches my eye. "Ah monsieur, you will be wanting to pay the bill," he says.

webTitle: Women: Why January is a great month

fields.headline: In the bleak midwinter
fields.standfirst: Christmas has been and gone, and the new year already feels old. As January stretches out ahead of us, a sea of cold, grey days, Jenny Turner, AL Kennedy and  Anna Davis  find reasons to be cheerful
fields.trailText: Christmas has been and gone, and the new year already feels old. As January stretches out ahead of us, a sea of cold, grey days, Jenny Turner, AL Kennedy and Anna Davis find reasons to be cheerful.
fields.body:
Miss Thrifty, my friend and mentor, is extremely fond of January. Och, she says, stop your moaning. No sunshine means no sunburn on your complexion. And your armpits won't get as sweaty either, in the cold. You save on sunscreen, you save on deodorant. No argument there, then. For stingy women who are prone to vanity, January is clearly great.

Like Miss Thrifty, I'm very happy that it's this time of year. I like the bleakness, the emptiness, the quiet. I like the way everything is grey. I dread Christmas - the X-fest, as we call it in my house - so I am delighted that it is finally over. I don't like New Year, either, which is why we call it Hog. Over the season, I don't go on and on about these hatreds. I behave myself, I join in. So now I enter the new year loaded down with Brownie points. As sure as Dionysian revels follow periods of repression, it's time for me to get my fun.

The opening rites of January are simple. I make myself a jug of lemon juice in water and a soup of lovely roots. You take onions, carrots, leeks and potatoes. You boil them until they're soft. You add parsley, or a stock cube, or some bonito flakes and miso, if you want to pretend you are eating a 21st-century global-free-trade-type dish. You eat it two or three times daily. You get on with the things that really matter in between.

First, you get rid of all your Christmas presents. Apart from the ones you actually like, of course, which probably will be the ones you had to buy them for yourself. In my house, useless-but-neutral presents - soaps and sweetmeats - go into a stiff-sided lockable suitcase until it's time to hand them on to somebody else. Hateful presents - politeness forbids me from going further - go straight to the Barnardo's shop. It's great to see that candle, those sachets, meant so thoughtfully for you, out there among all the other ones on the open shelf.

Then you get rid of any tat you have put up around your lodgings. A month ago, I saw these super gingerbread angels in one of London's fancier cake shops, priced a ridiculous £4.95. I decided I could do better. I bought a cutter from John Lewis for 49p. I riffled through the papers and cut out Nigella Lawson's picture byline to stick on with a blob of icing for the angel's face. I enter the New Year with a pile of slightly burnt Mr Blobby biscuits and a heap of curling Nigellas. It breaks my heart to be sweeping them into a bin-bag. It breaks my heart, but I do it just the same.

Third, you stave off a winter depression with the aid of Miss Thrifty's two-pronged attack. On the one hand, you partake of regular exercise, anything you like. Just do something you need to take a shower after. That way, you know you're sloughing something off. At the same time, you engage with a nice solid piece of Germanic literature or music. Schubert's Winterreise is excellent, full of snow and heartache and solid structure. Mozart operas are magnificent - psychologists claim to have proved scientifically that Mozart is good for the mind. Rilke works, and so does Goethe.

The aim, according to Miss Thrifty, is to keep your brain as spruce as you can. That way it is less likely to slip into a trough.

Finally, you find yourself a decent Burns night party to go to. Burns night, January 25, is the sensible person's winter festival. Instead of celebrating the lush lowland England of chubby birds and fruity puddings, Burns night remembers the harsher, bleaker Britain of snow-swept rocky upland slopes. You eat sheep's offal bulked out with oatmeal, mashed swede and mashed potato.

You read poems, you sing songs and you dance. Burns night is perfect for people who feel they failed at the X-fest. It's not a lot of bother, boiling a haggis with its neeps and tatties. It's no, as Miss Thrifty says, an awfy lot of expense. It is best of all for those of us who know that we failed because somewhere, in our puritanical heart of hearts, we never really wanted to succeed.

January is the month during which all sensible people are content to dwell in darkness, nursing the energies, waiting for the spring. Every horrible day that passes, we're in daylight a little longer. Every cloud, every hailstorm, is a harbinger of the sun. One day soon, you'll see a pallid little shoot emerging. As Miss Thrifty turned to me and said once: you think it's a shrivelled up old onion, it turns out to have been a daffodil all along.
Jenny Turner

Christmases: I've seen 35 of them now and I've had enough, more than enough. Roll on January: in fact, roll on February, just to be safe. And don't give me the usual excuses, I've heard them all before - Christmas may be an obscene and degrading celebration of unnecessary consumption, ill-temper and stress, but it's for the kids. Well, I don't have any. Or, no, what we really meant was, it's for the family. Well, I don't have one of those, either. So as far as I'm concerned, Christmas is that special, crispy, imitation snow-spangled time when corrosive isolation meets sterile inadequacy across a field of shitty television and free-floating sentiment, and then has a good stab at reaming out your soul. Which would make my personal motto - Christmas: it's bloody depressing.

Traditionalists will point out that Christmas is supposed to be about the baby Jesus and the Wise Men and the little, more or less symbolic, lambs. But if we're going to get genuinely traditional about this, we know the current date for Christmas Day was picked with the sole intention of ousting an earlier, pagan bash. And, frankly, the entire occasion makes much more sense to me when I consider it as a product of Druid or Roman custom.

When I was a child trying to get through Christmas - the time, you will recall, set aside especially for me and other nippers - the annual emotional assault course was little short of appalling. I spent my days dodging more or less psychotic family tiffs - presumably because this was also a time for the family. I tried, and failed, to avoid seasonal infections, endured endless sullen meals around an apparently never-decreasing avian corpse, and found myself alternately interrogated and given whisky-breathed kisses and damp coins by an unremitting stream of visitors. At any other week in the year, the social services would have been called out within minutes.

Beyond swamping me with a precocious understanding of life's arbitrary brutality, Christmas made me feel both paranoid and put-upon. But if I had understood that it was bequeathed to me by religious cults who loved nothing better than burning people alive and collecting severed heads, everything would have seemed at least logical, although - obviously - no less malign.

In my experience, Christmas has always been grisly but, unlike compulsory amputation or the crushing of a loved one by a rogue meteorite, it is a trial that demands constant, and preferably illuminated, displays of merriment. January may hobble in, hung over and slightly shame-faced, but it won't require party hats, an ounce of tinsel or the slightest attempt at bonhomie.

It is a quiet, dark, properly restful month, full of calming occupations - getting pine needles out of carpets, throwing away or palming off ugly gifts, picking which minor amputation will get your weight down to November's level. And it includes that lovely, pointless tradition of promising to be a better, nicer, improved sort of person from now on, in the context of a rosily dimpled future. Naturally this convinces no one, not even you, but it is good to open the year with a gentle disappointment - all the others will be far more grotesque and, most likely, not of your own making.

As a self-employed person, I have a particular fondness for January because it marks the point when everyone else gets their shoulders back to the grindstone and their noses to the wheel - or whatever it is salaried people do, I've never been quite clear, it seems to involve lots of tea breaks and dawdling. Every year, I struggle through December, trying to wheedle meaningful collaboration out of various people employed in various offices, and every year my hopes of getting anything useful done (or paid for) drop away as the days pass and seasonal depression, apathy, liver failure or festive chemical castration take their annual toll.

Naturally, I beaver away between Christmas and New Year, secure in the deeply irritating knowledge that the majority of the population is either lolling in a semi-coma in front of Ice Station Zebra or creeping off to try to burn unwanted synthetic pullovers without succumbing to the resultant toxic smoke. In January, everyone who gets paid for being on holiday shuffles back to their desk and lets me get on with placating the Inland Revenue at the end of the month. And that, I have to say, is about as happy as I expect the new year to get.
AL Kennedy

It is my 11th birthday, January 2 1982, and I am going to have a disco in the hall of the college where my dad teaches. During term-time, Dad runs discos for the foreign students, but tonight he's going to run one for me. He has proper flashing lights and a disco turntable, and it will be fab. This wouldn't be possible if my birthday were at any other time of year, but I am a January child. My birthday falls within the 12 days of Christmas when the college is shut.

I have invited everyone in my class except for people I hate. All records by Adam and the Ants will be banned for the evening because I hate them. There will be a dancing competition. I'll win it because I'm going to dance to Tainted Love with Stephen Foster, the most gorgeous boy in the class. The prize is a rainbow pack of felt-tip pens. I will share them with Stephen and we will draw hearts on each other's wrists.

The hall is all set up and Dad has assumed his place at the turntable. Mum is at the bar, pouring cherryade into paper cups. I am wearing my excellent new drainpipe jeans and legwarmers. Through the window, I can see the first people arriving, walking up the path with their parents.

I love being a January child because my birthday comes at the start of a whole new year when everything is untried and exciting. The air is full of magic. This is the time of year for wishes and dreams.

It's 9 o'clock, according to my birthday watch, and my disco is almost over. My little brother Rhidian just won the dancing competition - this result was rigged by Dad, who appointed himself judge without my consent.

None of the boys would dance with the girls. In the middle of the room, Ben Wilkins and his gang are capering about to Stand and Deliver by Adam and the Ants. They are pretending to be "dandy highwaymen" and have drawn lines across their noses with felt-tips (Mum decided to break up the rainbow set and give everybody one each).

Stephen Foster isn't here. I watched the door for ages until Mum asked me what on earth the matter was. When I told her, she went to the payphone to call Stephen's parents. Apparently his auntie and uncle came to visit for New Year and he had to stay at home.

Having a January birthday is the pits.

On January 5, I go back to school. I'd been dreading it but actually it's not so bad. Everyone is wearing new clothes and shoes, and they're all talking about how excellent my disco was. Stephen Foster is in love with Pippa Keene, but he's not so great, really. I think I just wanted someone to be King to my Disco Queen. I wouldn't admit it out loud but it's quite nice to be getting on with a bit of work again; getting on with the things in my life that are real.

Nineteen Januarys have passed since my 11th birthday disco and now, in 2001, I'm about to hit 30. People have always commiserated with me about having a birthday on January 2. It's a terrible time for celebrations. Everyone's binged-out and spent-out or still away on their new year city-breaks and ski-trips or trying to keep dull dull dull resolutions about dieting, booze and fags.

Being a January child means I'm cursed with the Capricorn star sign. I'm quick to say that astrology is guff but it niggles me that I'm classified as a "slow but steady wins the race" person; someone who likes a tidy house and is careful with money. Dull dull dull. But how could it possibly be any other way? This is January we're talking about.

If January were a meal, it would be a particularly abrasive kind of muesli. If January were a film, it would be an educational documentary. If January were a colour, it would be magnolia. If January were a sport, it would be arm-wrestling.

And yet we need January. We do. I thought my 11th birthday disco would make my wishes come true - but January is not a time of romance and wish fulfilment. It's a time for the bursting of bubbles, many of which need to be burst. If every month was like lazy, seductive August, we'd never get anything done. By the time flatulent December is blown out, we're glad of January with its Protestant work ethic; January, the chiselling month. The days are inching outwards again and that's not a bad thing. All the better for a Capricorn like me - a child of January - to get down to some chiselling.
Anna Davis

Naturally this convinces no one, not even you, but it is good to open the year with a gentle disappointment - all the others will be far more grotesque and, most likely, not of your own making. As a self-employed person, I have a particular fondness for January because it marks the point when everyone else gets their shoulders back to the grindstone and their noses to the wheel - or whatever it is salaried people do, I've never been quite clear, it seems to involve lots of tea breaks and dawdling. Every year, I struggle through December, trying to wheedle meaningful collaboration out of various people employed in various offices, and every year my hopes of getting anything useful done (or paid for) drop away as the days pass and seasonal depression, apathy, liver failure or festive chemical castration take their annual toll. Naturally, I beaver away between Christmas and New Year, secure in the deeply irritating knowledge that the majority of the population is either lolling in a semi-coma in front of Ice Station Zebra or creeping off to try to burn unwanted synthetic pullovers without succumbing to the resultant toxic smoke. In January, everyone who gets paid for being on holiday shuffles back to their desk and lets me get on with placating the Inland Revenue at the end of the month. And that, I have to say, is about as happy as I expect the new year to get. AL Kennedy It is my 11th birthday, January 2 1982, and I am going to have a disco in the hall of the college where my dad teaches. During term-time, Dad runs discos for the foreign students, but tonight he's going to run one for me. He has proper flashing lights and a disco turntable, and it will be fab. This wouldn't be possible if my birthday were at any other time of year, but I am a January child. My birthday falls within the 12 days of Christmas when the college is shut. I have invited everyone in my class except for people I hate. All records by Adam and the Ants will be banned for the evening because I hate them. There will be a dancing competition. I'll win it because I'm going to dance to Tainted Love with Stephen Foster, the most gorgeous boy in the class. The prize is a rainbow pack of felt-tip pens. I will share them with Stephen and we will draw hearts on each other's wrists. The hall is all set up and Dad has assumed his place at the turntable. Mum is at the bar, pouring cherryade into paper cups. I am wearing my excellent new drainpipe jeans and legwarmers. Through the window, I can see the first people arriving, walking up the path with their parents. I love being a January child because my birthday comes at the start of a whole new year when everything is untried and exciting. The air is full of magic. This is the time of year for wishes and dreams. It's 9 o'clock, according to my birthday watch, and my disco is almost over. My little brother Rhidian just won the dancing competition - this result was rigged by Dad, who appointed himself judge without my consent. None of the boys would dance with the girls. In the middle of the room, Ben Wilkins and his gang are capering about to Stand and Deliver by Adam and the Ants. They are pretending to be "dandy highwaymen" and have drawn lines across their noses with felt-tips (Mum decided to break up the rainbow set and give everybody one each). Stephen Foster isn't here. I watched the door for ages until Mum asked me what on earth the matter was. When I told her, she went to the payphone to call Stephen's parents. Apparently his auntie and uncle came to visit for New Year and he had to stay at home. Having a January birthday is the pits. On January 5, I go back to school. I'd been dreading it but actually it's not so bad. Everyone is wearing new clothes and shoes, and they're all talking about how excellent my disco was. Stephen Foster is in love with Pippa Keene, but he's not so great, really. I think I just wanted someone to be King to my Disco Queen. I wouldn't admit it out loud but it's quite nice to be getting on with a bit of work again; getting on with the things in my life that are real. Nineteen Januarys have passed since my 11th birthday disco and now, in 2001, I'm about to hit 30. People have always commiserated with me about having a birthday on January 2. It's a terrible time for celebrations. Everyone's binged-out and spent-out or still away on their new year city-breaks and ski-trips or trying to keep dull dull dull resolutions about dieting, booze and fags. Being a January child means I'm cursed with the Capricorn star sign. I'm quick to say that astrology is guff but it niggles me that I'm classified as a "slow but steady wins the race" person; someone who likes a tidy house and is careful with money. Dull dull dull. But how could it possibly be any other way? This is January we're talking about. If January were a meal, it would be a particularly abrasive kind of muesli. If January were a film, it would be an educational documentary. If January were a colour, it would be magnolia. If January were a sport, it would be arm-wrestling. And yet we need January. We do. I thought my 11th birthday disco would make my wishes come true - but January is not a time of romance and wish fulfilment. It's a time for the bursting of bubbles, many of which need to be burst. If every month was like lazy, seductive August, we'd never get anything done. By the time flatulent December is blown out, we're glad of January with its Protestant work ethic; January, the chiselling month. The days are inching outwards again and that's not a bad thing. All the better for a Capricorn like me - a child of January - to get down to some chiselling. Anna Davis

webTitle: Saudi Arabia backs plan to restrict oil production

fields.headline: Saudi Arabia backs plan to restrict oil production
fields.trailText: Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil producer, yesterday raised the threat of a rebound in world energy prices this year, when it backed moves for the oil exporters' cartel, Opec, to restrict production.
fields.body:
Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil producer, yesterday raised the threat of a rebound in world energy prices this year, when it backed moves for the oil exporters' cartel, Opec, to restrict production.

The six nation Gulf Cooperation Council which includes the Saudis, yesterday called on Opec to authorise output cuts at its next meeting in mid-January.

"The GCC supreme council instructed their oil ministers to work to reduce production levels at Opec's next meeting and take any other measures to maintain equilibrium in the market and achieve the targeted price," the council's final communiqué said.

The six Arab Gulf states control more than half of the world's oil reserves and their policies are crucial to global prices. Dealers have been watching Saudi Arabia closely as its position is seen as critical in securing agreement among the 11-member cartel.

"The oil market situation has been on everyone's mind during the summit's deliberations," one delegate said.

Oil exporters are desperate to put a floor under crude prices which fell to a six month low of $25 a barrel in the run-up to Christmas. The more hawkish members of the cartel like Kuwait, Indonesia and Libya already favour quota restrictions to prevent a repeat of the price collapse two years ago, when world crude prices fell to below $10 a barrel.

Venezuela's president, Hugo Chavez, last week called on the oil cartel to "go to battle" to defend the price of oil, while Indonesia said it would propose an output reduction of between one and 1.5m barrels per day at the next Opec meeting.

Opec is now suffering from the success of its moves last year to quell rising world oil prices. The cartel, which controls two-thirds of global oil exports, jacked up production four times last year by a total of 3.7m barrels.

After reaching a post-Gulf war high in October, prices have dropped by a nearly a third, bringing relief for hard pressed motorists throughout the west and reducing the chances of a sharp slowdown in the world economy this year.

The resumption of Iraqi oil sales to Europe has also helped turn prices lower despite severe winter weather in both the US and continental Europe. Temperatures are running below seasonal norms on both sides of the Atlantic, preventing energy prices from falling even further.

But oil exporters fear that prices could collapse when peak winter demand eases. Prices are currently at the lower end of Opec's target $22-$28 a barrel range and further falls could prompt an automatic production cut before the January 17 meeting.

webTitle: WH Smith drops go-it-alone distribution idea

fields.headline: WH Smith drops go-it-alone distribution idea
fields.trailText: WH Smith is this week expected to announce it has abandoned controversial plans to set up its own national distribution system.
fields.body:
WH Smith is this week expected to announce it has abandoned controversial plans to set up its own national distribution system.

The high street retailer sparked outrage after announcing it wanted to bypass local wholesalers and exclusively supply its own chain and leading supermarkets.

However, it is understood to have now conceded defeat, after a series of meetings with industry associations, in return for a number of concessions.

Senior executives at WH Smith and magazine industry representatives, including the Periodical Publishers Association, have been locked in talks over the past fortnight in an effort to hammer out a deal to end the dispute.

A full press release, which could be put out tomorrow, is expected to give details of a new industry-wide distribution system.

Weekend reports suggested these new plans would include centralised points of contact between retailers and wholesalers, as well as single invoicing, fewer deliveries and standardised wholesale systems implemented across Britain.

Magazines and newspapers are at present distributed through a network of local wholesalers to shops across the country.

It was feared the plan by WH Smith, although initially just relating to the supply of magazines, could be extended to newspapers as well.

Research suggested up to 12,000 local newsagents would face the risk of closure if this was the case as they would be unable to bear any extra distribution costs.

Industry sources say the agreement is a clear victory for Associated Newspapers, publisher of the Daily Mail, which said it would terminate its multi-million pound contract with WH Smith in protest at its plans.

It is thought the six-month notice served on WH Smith by Associated will now be scrapped as a result of the successful talks.

But it remains unclear how badly the reputation of WH Smith will be affected by the souring of relations over recent months.

Some industry figures have been quoted as saying the retailer's actions had "destroyed" the goodwill built up over many years of trading and which may never be replaced.

No one was available for comment at either Associated or WH Smith last night.

webTitle: Airbus in a flap over jumbo's first flight

fields.headline: Airbus in a flap over jumbo's first flight
fields.trailText: Aircraft maker Airbus has found itself in the middle of a row over the inauguration of the world's largest jumbo jet.
fields.body:
Aircraft maker Airbus has found itself in the middle of a row over the inauguration of the world's largest jumbo jet.

Airline Emirates, the first customer to order the renamed A380, formerly known as the A3XX, has protested to Airbus after it found it may not be the first airline to fly the aircraft commercially.

Industry sources said last night that Singapore Airlines will be the first, even though it ordered the A380 after Emirates. Singapore is a much larger airline and has been given priority by Airbus over its Middle East rival.

The row has not yet become public because Emirates hopes that the issue will be resolved by negotiation. But senior executives from the airline based in Dubai feel let down by Airbus, the European manufacturer with headquarters at Toulouse, to which France, Britain, Germany and Spain belong.

Emirates' senior managers have told Airbus that they deserve better treatment because the company was prepared to commit itself to the project when Airbus was concerned that it would not get the support it wanted and that the project might collapse.

Emirates commitment to the 565-seater aircraft produced a ripple effect throughout the world's other airlines, among them Singapore, Air France and Qantas during last year. Airbus has now been able to commit itself to the project, with the first commercial flight due in 2006.

Jubilant Emirates executives said that the first A380 would land at Heathrow but were shocked when they heard that the prestigious first flight would be offered to Singapore.

Airbus executives are working on a compromise acceptable to Emirates, which has placed 10 firm orders for the aircraft, valued at £2bn. The most likely solution is a simultaneous launch of the plane by Emirates and Singapore, both landing at Heathrow.

Since the distance between Dubai and London is shorter than that between Singapore and London, the Emirates flight would land first. The airline would therefore be able to claim it as the inaugural commercial flight.

The launch of the A380 has been surrounded by a considerable marketing hype on its potential to bring about a revolution in flying. This is based on the extra space it will provide, with drawing-board plans for duty-free shops, sleeping cabins and pianists playing baby grands for first class passengers.

The aircraft will bring a considerable increase in jobs throughout the industry. Britain will make the wings for the plane at plants in north Wales and at Filton near Bristol, where more than 20,000 new jobs will be created.

webTitle: Monday briefing

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Sunday Telegraph
fields.body:
Sunday Telegraph

J Sainsbury is poised to become the latest entrant into the mobile phone market by launching its own service, Sainsbury's One. Bills for the service, which will operate over BT Cellnet 's network, will provide an analysis of how much calls would cost on all four UK networks. Sainsbury's One would then charge the lowest rate. The service will target the 12m holders of the supermarket group's Reward loyalty card.

Extreme Group, which produces and distributes TV sports programmes, is to float in the first half of the year valued at around £50m. The company is chaired by Chris Akers, founder of Sports Internet, and is likely to use the proceeds to expand in America.

Carcraft, Britain's largest secondhand car dealership, has been put up for sale by its private equity owners with a £200m price tag.

Israeli technology firm Brightcom, which designs chips and software for wireless technology Bluetooth, is planning a $400m float in London.

Sunday Times

Lloyds TSB is preparing to lodge an application with the competition commission to take over Abbey National. It is likely to file its case early in the new year. If it does not succeed in a last ditch attempt to persuade Abbey to agree to a deal, it is prepared to launch a hostile offer.

Britain's economy is set for its ninth consecutive year of growing faster than 2%, despite fears of an American-led slowdown. Forecasters believe growth will be lower than the 3% estimated for 2000, but that expansion will continue.

The director of a failed timeshare company called Sunweeks International is being investigated by the official receiver amid claims the business made false statements to entice customers to part with up to £5,000 each.

The auction to buy Go, British Airways' low cost subsidiary, has gone flat, and the company fears it may now only get £100m for the airline. Executives had believed the operation, run by Barbara Cassani, could fetch up to £300m, but enthusiasm among potential buyers has waned.

Sunday Business

Nearly 2,000 staff at high street chain C&A will lose their jobs when the company pulls out of Britain in January. This is far more than originally expected.

Leisure group Chorion plans to expand its Tiger Tiger nightclub chain across Europe.

Union chief Sir Ken Jackson launched a scathing attack on the way the European Commission has dealt with the aid package being considered for the Nissan car manufacturing plant in Sunderland.

The City fund management divisions of Deutsche Bank and Legal & General each gained £10bn of new institutional business during 2000, with Phillips & Drew and Schroders the biggest losers.

ING Barings is likely to close its New York operations as well as Barings in London, after no buyers were found.

Observer

Despite hopes that manufacturing would recover in 2000, the year saw the shedding of 100,000 jobs, output falling across most sectors and captains of industry reeling from one disaster to the next.

Mail on Sunday

Department store partnership John Lewis has conceded that it will have to stay open more than five days a week if it is to meet fierce high street competition.

Coal production looks on the way up again after years of decline, with RJB Mining planning to open a deep mine at Thorne near Doncaster, South Yorkshire.

Sunday Express

Tour operators, department stores and car companies are in line to benefit from a massive consumer spending spree in 2001 as £21bn worth of Tessas mature.

IoS

Employers who monitor their staff's emails and record their phone calls - practices common in the financial services industry - could be breaking the law, according to a group of senior lawyers.

webTitle: £117m ad spend after divorce puts accent on ads

fields.headline: £117m ad spend after divorce puts accent on ads
fields.trailText: Five months after its divorce from the accountancy firm Arthur Andersen, Andersen Consulting will roll out its new name today at the start of the biggest business-to-business rebranding campaign ever conducted.
fields.body:
Five months after its divorce from the accountancy firm Arthur Andersen, Andersen Consulting will roll out its new name today at the start of the biggest business-to-business rebranding campaign ever conducted.

Accenture, a combination of the words accent and future, was conceived by one of the firm's Norwegian employees, Kim Peterson.

The company, which has more than 65,000 people in 48 countries, will seek to establish its new identity through newspaper and TV advertising, plus sponsorship of formula one motor racing, golf and soccer, in a campaign costing $175m (£117m) in advertising alone.

Vernon Ellis, Accenture's London-based international chairman, said: "It will be a big effort but it's just a name change. The trick will be to make people remember who we are. We think you will find it hard to get away from the advertising and other things that will get into your consciousness."

Under the terms of the firm's divorce, Arthur Andersen will retain the rights to the Andersen Consulting brand.

The firm split from Arthur Andersen because the accountancy firm had set up its own strategic consultancy arm, making it a competitor to Andersen Consulting.

The Accenture partners are now examining a partial flotation as a way of retaining top-quality staff, who could then be rewarded with stock options, and raising capital for expansion.

Mr Ellis said collapsing hi-tech share valuations would not stand in the way of a partial public offering.

"I have always felt that at the height, some of these valuations, particularly of the smaller companies, were silly... it was impossible to see rationale for them. The adjustment was absolutely necessary because it pricked the balloon of momentum pricing." He welcomed "a greater sense of reality" in e-commerce.

webTitle: New year slowdown starts early

fields.headline: New year slowdown starts early
fields.trailText: The year 2000 was a vintage one for the global economy which grew more than 4%, the fastest pace of expansion for more than a decade. Financial markets ought to have celebrated. Yet all around the world they were in despair.
fields.body:
The year 2000 was a vintage one for the global economy which grew more than 4%, the fastest pace of expansion for more than a decade. Financial markets ought to have celebrated. Yet all around the world they were in despair.

By mid-December only eight out of 40 stock markets covered by the Economist's weekly economic indicators were above their level of a year ago. The reason? Stock markets were looking forward to 2001, not backward. They clearly believe this year will be a stinker.

The immediate cause of the anxiety is, of course, the uncertainly surrounding the fate of the US economy, the world's largest and the main engine of global growth in the aftermath of the Asian crisis. After a record breaking boom lasting a decade, growth is now slowing rapidly towards a more sustainable rate amid a rash of profit warnings. Instead of last year's 5%, it will probably be no more than 3% in 2001.

While a slowdown of that order could ultimately prolong the length of the upswing by easing some of the stresses and strains which have developed, notably the yawning current account deficit and the negative savings ratio, the nagging question for financial markets now is: will it become a recession?

If America catches a cold, the rest of the globe runs the risk of getting double pneumonia. Britain, in particular, would suffer because of the web of trade and financial market connections between the two countries.

There is certainly a significant risk of a hard landing in the US, though not for the usual reason. Booms normally end in bust because booms generate excess demand and inflation which then has to be squeezed out of the system by higher official interest rates. Although both inflation and interest rates have risen in the past year, they have done so only modestly, certainly not enough to send the global economy into a tailspin.

No, the real cause of the recession - if we get one - will be a combination of over-investment in IT and tough competition which is preventing rising costs being passed on in price rises, with the resulting contraction of profit margins.

"It is then stock market crashes, loan losses, bad loans and bankruptcies which do the damage, causing contemporaneously monetary contraction rather than being its lagged result," says Brian Reading of Lombard Street Research in an end of year note published last week.

Optimism reigns

For what it is worth, most forecasters are confident that a hard landing in the US can be avoided. They have faith in Alan Greenspan, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, cutting interest rates at just the right time and in just the right quantity to keep the ball rolling.

He did it in 1998 when the global economy stood on the edge of a precipice and he will do it again in 2001, according to US investment banks Merrill Lynch and Goldman Sachs, which are both backing the soft landing scenario.

Credit Suisse First Boston also takes comfort from the fact that slowing US growth will in itself help to support global growth because it is already bringing down oil prices and the dollar, which together with lower interest rates, will nip a nascent credit crunch in the bud. "The tightening of credit conditions is starting to act as a significant drag on growth in the US, but has not yet become systemic and has hardly spread to Europe," says the firm. "The prospect of easier monetary conditions, and the positive effect on non-oil companies' profits from lower oil prices, will not reverse the tighter conditions overnight but will greatly reduce the risk of their becoming systemic, and limit the likely spill over to Europe."

Perhaps a more worrying threat to the outlook for the global economy is the rapidly deteriorating situation in Japan, the world's second largest economy, still struggling to get to grips with the bursting of its asset price bubble 10 years ago. Although it managed anaemic growth in 2000, end of year figures showed plunging industrial output, retail sales falling for the 44th straight month and unemployment at an eight-month high, suggesting that a descent back into full-blown recession cannot be ruled out.

The Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, went on a walkabout in a shopping district in Tokyo last Wednesday, to highlight the continued weakness of personal consumption, which accounts for 60% of gross domestic product.

He bought a pair of shoes for his forthcoming trip to Africa and a bag of carrots, but it will take much greater largess by consumers to establish a self-sustaining recovery.

The global economy has done very nicely without much of a contribution from Japan over the past decade but that is only because the US has compensated by growing so strongly. If Japan goes into reverse at the same time as the US economy is slowing, everyone will feel the pinch.

Of the three big industrialised economies, euroland seems to have the best prospects over the next year or so. Cyclically less advanced than the US, it has plenty of slack in the labour market and is slowly but steadily undertaking structural reforms which will make it more globally competitive.

Not least of these reforms will be a major round of tax cuts in Germany, France and Italy which this year are expected to boost euroland GDP by 0.5% percentage point.

While euroland will undoubtedly suffer from the slowdown in the US, it has none of the imbalances that plague the US economy and should for once outperform its transatlantic rival - assuming the European Central Bank is prepared to cut interest rates if necessary.

Rising stars

However, the star performer of 2001 could well be the economies of the Middle East and north Africa. This year's slowdown in growth in the advanced economies owes much to last year's surge in the price of oil, which forced up producers' costs and reduced the purchasing power of consumers.

But what caused protests on the streets of Europe lined the pockets of the governments of the big oil producing countries, which are now starting to spend again. The Economist Intelligence Unit says this will transform the economic outlook because such spending feeds through to the rest of the non-oil economy and helps to boost corporate profits.

As a result, the EIU expects economic growth in the Middle East and north Africa to accelerate to 4.7% in 2001, making it the fastest growing region in the world. The fastest growing country is expected to be New Guinea, a one-off ranking due to rapid expansion of its oil sector.

Another region which could surprise on the upside is Latin America, where, having finally shaken off the impact of the Asian financial crisis, Brazil is forecast to strengthen, acting as a locomotive for surrounding countries, although its pulling power will be offset by Mexico, which is likely to slow in line with its next door neighbour, the US.

Overall 2001, looks like being a reasonably healthy one for the global economy. Although fears of recession in America could yet become a self-fulfilling prophecy, the odds are still on continued growth.

Barring a hard landing in the US, global GDP is likely to expand by more than 3%. After growth of more than 4% last year, it will not feel very fast but it is likely to be more evenly distributed. Whether it will translate into a recovery of equity prices remains unclear. Assuming unchanged profit shares in GDP, steady growth normally means a bull not a bear market.

But fierce global competition may well continue to keep the lid on price rises and keep profit margins tight, hence depressing share prices. Producers will not like it but consumers will be happy - as long as they keep their jobs.

webTitle: Film: The best prayer scene

fields.headline: The best prayer scene
fields.standfirst: Meet The Parents
fields.trailText: Meet The Parents
fields.body:
About to have dinner at his prospective in-laws', Greg Focker (Ben Stiller) looks up as family patriarch Jack Byrnes (Robert De Niro) turns to him.

"Greg - would you like to say grace?"

There is an awkward silence before Greg's fiancée Pam (Teri Polo) answers on his behalf.

"Oh Dad... Greg's Jewish."

"You're telling me that Jews don't pray, honey?"

Jack turns again to Greg.

"Unless you have some objection."

"No, no, no, I'd love to," Greg blusters. "Come on Pam, it's not like I'm a rabbi or something. I've said grace at many a... dinner table."

He clasps his hands together. The Byrneses follow suit.

"Let's see. OK."

Greg affects a deep, booming voice.

"Oh... Dear God. Thank you. You are such a good God."

Jack opens his eyes, peering inscrutably at Greg.

"You are thoughtful. Kind. Gentle. And... accomodating. God. And we thank you, oh.... sweet, sweet, Lord... of hosts. For the... ah... smorgasbord you have so aptly laid at our table this day. And each day. By day. Day by day, by day."

By now, the entire family are staring at Greg.

"Oh... Dear Lord. Three things we pray to thee. To see thee more clearly. To hear thee more dearly. To... follow thee... more nearly. Day, by day, by day."

Greg prizes his hands apart.

"Amen."

"Amen."

"Thank you Greg," Jack smiles. "That was very interesting."

See also: The Apostle, Carrie, Heathers, Breaking The Waves, Magnolia

Don't see also: Ishtar

Pointless trivia: Ben Stiller's last film Keeping The Faith found him playing a rabbi, Jacob Schram.

webTitle: Equitable in new inquiry

fields.headline: Equitable in new inquiry
fields.standfirst:
Troubled mutual faces action over doubling of cash-in penalty
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Equitable Life, the troubled insurance company, is under investigation by regulators amid claims it acted unfairly by doubling the penalties it imposes on those wishing to cash in their policies early.
fields.body:
Equitable Life, the troubled insurance company, is under investigation by regulators amid claims it acted unfairly by doubling the penalties it imposes on those wishing to cash in their policies early.

The office of fair trading last night confirmed it has launched an inquiry after being contacted by a disgruntled policyholder.

Investigators have already written to senior executives at Equitable requesting a copy of its contract terms and given them a deadline of January 10 by which to respond.

If the contract is found to be weighted in Equitable's favour the OFT can demand parts are amended or removed and can apply for a high court injunction if its requests are rejected.

The inquiry centres on the fact the company raised the exit penalty from 5% to 10% after it was forced to shut for new business in December. The closure followed the collapse of takeover talks with Prudential amid fears of a £5bn black hole in Equitable's finances.

The increase in the exit penalty effectively locks in many of the company's policyholders.

A spokesman for Equitable said the company would help with any inquiry and confirmed the level of the penalty has stood at 10% for just under a month with policyholders advised of the change by letter.

The move, he said, was made to "protect the fund for those policyholders that are staying in the fund" as there was likely to be a "level of uncertainty" over the period.

The complaint against Equitable has been brought under the "unfair terms in consumer contracts" legislation and will be examined by officials within a specialist unit of the OFT.

It is likely to take some weeks to complete the inquiry as investigators plan to examine the entire contract to ensure it is not weighted against the consumer.

"We are giving this our priority as much as we can but we are dependent on getting information," said an OFT spokeswoman.

"We wrote to the company a couple of weeks ago and are talking to the financial services authority. If there is no response early in the new year we would approach them again. If a company continued to not respond then ultimately we could take them to court."

The outcome of the inquiry could have grave consequences for the mutual which is already financially weak.

Last July it was put up for sale after losing a landmark case over treatment of guaranteed annuity pension policies

The FSA, criticised for allowing Equitable to carry on trading, is carrying out an internal review of its regulation of the company from January 1 1999 to December 8 2000. The review is expected to take some months to complete.

According to separate weekend reports, the FSA fears people may get caught up in a fresh scandal with some independent advisers trying to persuade Equitable pension holders to switch their cash into expensive new schemes.

It was also reported that dozens of MPs may lose money because part of their parliamentary pensions was invested in Equitable Life.

The main pension for members of the House of Commons is a contributory scheme but those choosing to make additional payments have put their savings into Equitable under a group scheme.

Equitable's spokesman said he was unable to comment on individual cases.

webTitle: Banks ditch charges for cash machine withdrawals

fields.headline: Banks ditch charges for cash machine withdrawals
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Consumers will save an estimated £270m a year from today when most leading banks and building societies ditch charges for withdrawing money from cash machines.
fields.body:
Consumers will save an estimated £270m a year from today when most leading banks and building societies ditch charges for withdrawing money from cash machines.

Only the Barclays subsidiary Woolwich and the former building society Alliance & Leicester will continue levying a £1 fee on users of their machines in out of the way spots where machines might not otherwise be installed. Barclays said last night it would refund the £1 charge for its own customers or those of the Woolwich, and that over time, Barclays would be "exiting" from out of the way locations.

The dropped charges for cash machine withdrawals follows a furore between the leading high street institutions last year which threatened the existence of the Link network that connects the hole in the wall machines up and down the country. The charges being abandoned are known as disloyalty fees, levied by banks and building societies on their own customers when they use their rivals' cash machines.

However, while the charges - which ranged from 50p £1.50 - are being dropped, industry observers suggest that it will only be matter of time before the big banks begin to reimpose them. The larger banks insist that they do not make profits from running their cash machine networks, and say they plough millions of pounds a year into them.

The abolition of disloyalty fees was the result of a heated row between Barclays bank and Nationwide Building Society which followed an attempt by Barclays to introduce an entirely new charging structure. Barclays was the first of the big players to abandon the disloyalty fee it levied on its own customers but wanted to do so at the expense of its rivals' customers.

The bank, which became embroiled in a number of controversies last year such as branch closures and the size of its top executives' pay deals, wanted to introduce a £1 surcharge every time one of its rivals' customers used one of its cash machines.

This move prompted the threat of legal action from Nationwide, which has a much smaller cash machine network and does not charge its customers for withdrawing cash from hole in the wall machines. To keep the use of machines free, Nationwide would either have had to charge its customers the £1 fee levied by Barclays or pick up the bill itself.

After a protracted argument and the intervention of MPs, the members of the Link network agreed to abolish charges altogether. Barclays never introduced the "surcharge" although that method of charging is being used by Woolwich, which it bought last year, and Alliance & Leicester, in locations where machines would not otherwise be situated. New cash machine installers are also expected to charge at non-bank branded machines.

Nationwide estimates that consumers will save £270m a year as result of the abolition of charges for cash machine withdrawals. The banks and building societies have taken steps to try to notify customers of potential charges they might face when using cash machines by posting messages on the cash machine screens.

webTitle: Homeowners think prices will go up

fields.headline: Homeowners think prices will go up
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: British homeowners are more optimistic that the value of their biggest asset will continue to rise in 2001 than homeowners in France and Germany, a survey shows today.
fields.body:
British homeowners are more optimistic that the value of their biggest asset will continue to rise in 2001 than homeowners in France and Germany, a survey shows today.

In Britain, two out of three homeowners expect house prices to increase, compared with 61% of French homeowners and 50% of those surveyed in Germany, where 13% expect prices to fall.

The survey conducted for the Halifax by NOP found that homeowners in all three countries are confident about their own prospects despite predictions that the US slowdown could curb global growth next year.

A majority in all three countries expect their standard of living to remain the same, even though less than half believe that their national economy will continue to grow at the same pace this year as last.

UK homeowners were the most optimistic about their personal financial prospects but were also the most pessimistic about the outlook for the overall economy.

Almost 25% of UK respondents predicted their standard of living would improve, compared with 18% in France and 20% in Germany. However, more than a third of those surveyed in the UK expect the economy to take a turn for the worse in 2001, compared to 23% of those surveyed in France and 24% in Germany.
